name: President. –
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 25 February 2016. President Schulz cannot be with us this evening. He was invited to join the European Council at its meeting taking place today in Brussels, and therefore he cannot be here. Instead you have me. I hope I will live up to the same standard as President Schulz.

name: President. –
text: The final draft agenda as drawn up pursuant to Rule 149 by the Conference of Presidents at its meeting of Thursday 3 March 2016 has been distributed. The following changes have been proposed: Monday: no changes proposed Tuesday: The ECR Group had asked that the report by Mr Kirkhope on the use of passenger name record data (EU-PNR) be added at 8.30, as the first item in the morning. If the item is added to our agenda, the vote would take place on Thursday.

name: Timothy Kirkhope
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, under Rule 152(1) I am requesting that the EU—PNR Directive, which is legally and technically ready, be voted this week. This request and a possible roll call vote today is not about the merits of PNR; those have been debated. Today is simply about giving this House its right to vote without an undue delay. Some in this House talk a lot about democracy and transparency, but at the end of the day this Parliament loses credibility with the backroom deals of a few who try to manipulate our agenda to further their own political aims and priorities. The public loses faith in politics because of games, tactics and vested interests. We are a democracy; if you do not like something you vote against it and then you justify that to your electorate. You do not delay or stop it from being voted at all. My request is simple: please give me my right as rapporteur and elected Member, representing my constituents, to have a vote on this directive this week. I agree with the proposal that there should be a debate at 8.30 tomorrow morning and a vote later this week. That is my proposition.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: Madam President, the security of the European Union is seriously being called into question by the most insane form of terrorism that has been known. Thousands of European citizens are taking part in these attacks, most of them going to train in the Middle East and returning home. Over the past ten years, hundreds of Europeans have fallen into these conditions. It is generally believed that it is by developing a common European air passenger file that we will be able to trace their movements as best as possible and prevent future attacks. We worked there for three years. On such a sensitive issue, the 28 governments have agreed and our competent committee, which has worked this agreement, has given its own approval. This agreement balances the requirements of security and the requirements for safeguarding individual freedoms. Some of our colleagues had hoped that at the same time the negotiations on the regulation on the protection of personal data would be advanced. This precondition is now lifted. Meanwhile, further massacres have taken place in Paris and since then the threat has continued to escalate with the chaos of migration. In these circumstances, it is a real race of speed that is being waged between the terrorists and our democracies. We can no longer advance procedural arguments to delay our decision. As the rapporteur has said, it is now that every group, every Member must take responsibility and, publicly to European citizens, say what priority it gives or does not give to the fight against the most barbaric form of terrorism.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: – Madam President, in general terms I appreciate Mr Lamassoure's arguments, but I believe that the concept of 'procedural arguments' does not correspond to the position of those of us who consider that this matter cannot be separated from data protection. I would like to point out that this is not only the position of one political group or another, but that there has been a fairly established consensus in the European Parliament for months on the desirability of providing instruments for security but also for the protection of personal privacy. And so our position has not simply been strategic, of preserving one issue so that the other is also approved, but is a matter of values. And that is why, when Mr Kirkhope has pointed out that European citizens expect us to provide them with security, an important part of this Parliament has to say that they also expect us to protect their privacy, and for that reason we are not against the adoption of the PNR: we are in favour of it being approved at the same time as data protection , because it's the balance we need to preserve security and freedom.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The European Union's policy on Turkey has been short-sighted in recent years, to say the least, and it took tens of thousands of refugees to remind us of how important that country is to the European Union. However, we are now in danger of making a really short-sighted policy towards Turkey. Not that we are against seeking an understanding with the refugees – that must be the case. However, we in the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance consider it totally irresponsible for us to enter a new phase of negotiations now, ignoring the internal escalation in Turkey and the abandonment of any rule of law.  The violent – it must be said – occupation and takeover of Turkey's largest daily newspaper last weekend, and in fact just before the summit in Brussels, cannot be accepted. We need to discuss this in this House, we need to discuss it with Mrs Mogherini.  Nor can it be accepted that the escalation in south-eastern Turkey should continue unwaveringly. There are two sides involved. But this spiral of escalation must be brought to an end. What Kati Piri, Knut Fleckenstein and others, including my colleagues, have reported from the south-east is totally unacceptable. Now that, on the sidelines of the summit, there is a constant talk of recognising Turkey as a safe third country, I ask you: can we allow this to happen without debate? What we are seeing is already showing that many Turkish citizens will need political asylum in the near future if we do not now explicitly try to address this from our side. I would ask you to support our request not just to discuss these issues within the summit discussion, but to explicitly discuss these issues in the perspective of the new negotiating initiative with Turkey that has been launched.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I am speaking in support of Mrs Harms' proposal. I came back yesterday from Turkey. The testimony we have received there is overwhelming. It is true that journalists are persecuted: at least 67 journalists, according to government sources, including those of Zaman, the main opposition newspaper under guardianship, who appeared yesterday by curiously displaying a pro-government line, but also journalists from Cumhuriyet, another opposition newspaper. We visited the Armutlu district, the main Alevi district of Istanbul, where we met the family of young Dilek Dogan, who was coldly murdered by the police as she returned to her apartment. There are also academics: 300 have just been charged with terrorism simply because they have denounced the situation in the South-East. Precisely the South-East, where there are more than 768 Kurds who have been murdered since July, including 98 children and 87 women - terrorists probably! 255 in Cizre in conditions that are unbearable, which are even unworthy of international law of war. We all fear that this will happen again in Sour, the historic capital, the historic old town, where the main Armenian church in the region is located. We are therefore asking for a debate and we believe that it is time to have one on the human rights situation in Turkey.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Madam President, we are very concerned about the situation of the press in Turkey and the demented agitation of universities. But we do not consider it necessary to have a separate debate tomorrow, as the Green Group proposes. The reason is very simple: on Wednesday morning, if you look at the agenda, we have a debate on Turkey, and in particular on today's meeting between the 28 heads of state or government and the Turkish Prime Minister. In fact, the President of our Parliament has just sent us a note about 30 minutes ago explaining that the question of Zaman in particular has already been raised by himself and by the representatives of the Member States.

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As a group, we asked for the item on the situation in Kazakhstan to be postponed during the topical and urgent debate on Thursday, namely the April part-session, and instead to include a debate and a resolution on violations of human rights obligations in the context of the forced eviction of the Calais Jungle. You all know that since last week, many shelters in the Calais refugee camp have been forcibly evacuated. Volunteers and NGOs on the ground have also reported that there has been a high level of violence by the French security forces, who have taken people out of their homes, even though it has actually been assured that they will proceed gradually and refrain from any use of force. That is precisely why we want this debate here. We know that many people are desperate. You have certainly also seen the pictures of people having their mouths sewn as a protest against the eviction. I think it would be important for us as a Parliament to agree on this. Finally, i end there has always been something of a rumour that there is a gentlemen's agreement, that there should be no discussion of human rights violations within the European Union within the topical and urgent debate, but that there must be extra agenda items for this. I would like to speak here with the President of Parliament, who has stated that human rights violations cannot be geographically divided. And if we have a specific item on the agenda on human rights violations, then we should also have an open ear and clear eyes on it, especially when human rights violations within the EU are to be addressed, and we should do so here too.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I am very grateful to Ms Zimmer for suggesting this because I think it is indeed essential that we take very seriously violations of human rights in our own continent and I believe that is exactly what is happening in the Calais camp. I visited there myself quite recently and I was really shocked to see the way the British and French Governments were not taking seriously the needs of the asylum seekers who were there.  We believe very strongly that the British Government should be registering refugees in that camp and should not be relying on the fact that Britain is outside Schengen and that they cannot reach Britain to register. We believe a lot of the refugees there actually have rights to come and be reunited with their families in Britain under the Dublin Agreement and my government is simply not taking those rights seriously.  I believe that the destruction of their homes is actually a violation of their right to shelter under the UN Convention on Human Rights and I think it is very essential that as a parliament we take seriously these violations of human rights within our own continent, so I entirely support the proposal that we should debate this as one of the urgencies.

name: Diane James (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I cannot support the suggestion in this proposal this afternoon for the following reasons: the Calais jungle is a result of the Le Touquet Agreement, which is an accord between the French Government and the UK Government, and the European Union has no right to interfere with that.  Secondly, the enforced closure of part of the migrant camp, the Jungle, was on the basis of a French decision taken in a French law court. We have no right whatsoever to interfere with French judicial process. The third item – and I would like to ask everyone to take this into consideration – is that one of the many reasons why the migrants reacted as they did was one anarchist supported by a British charity, and I do not think we ought to support anarchists’ and activists’ work.  The last point is that a lot of these migrants do not want their fingerprints to be taken. That was another reason why they reacted with the violence they did. There is absolutely no way this Chamber should take any stance on this position. It is down to a situation between the UK and French Governments.

name: James Nicholson (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I rise to express my consternation that the crisis in the pigmeat sector has been put up for debate at 15.00 on a Thursday afternoon.  When pig farmers throughout Europe are facing serious financial difficulties, this is a slap in the face that the Conference of Presidents has given to the coordinators of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development who asked for this debate – to actively highlight this – and when we will not even have a Commission representative there. So this is totally unacceptable and I hope you will have a rethink.

name: President. –
text: Mr Nicholson, it was a decision of the Conference of Presidents, but we hear your words. (The order of business was thus established)

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Marc Tarabella, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in the educational establishments (COM(2014)0032 – C7-0025/2014 – 2014/0014 (COD)) (A8-0006/2016).

name: Marc Tarabella
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is with great pride that I am here today to present the new scheme to help distribute fruit and vegetables and milk in schools, the culmination of a year and a half of work. This result is the result of intense collaboration with the rapporteurs of the political groups, whom I would like to thank: Mrs Sofia Ribeiro, Mrs Ulrike Muller, Mr James Nicholson, Mr Bronis Ropé, Mr Marco Zullo and Mr Matt Carthy. I would also like to welcome the european Commission teams, which had made an excellent proposal under the leadership of Mr Joost Korte, and the Luxembourg Presidency, represented by Mr Franck Schmidt, with whom we have worked closely. In general, the new programme is based on two pillars: on the one hand, the health of children and the learning of healthy eating habits from an early age via school, and, on the other hand, support for farmers. In the first pillar, we ensured that the distribution of fresh produce - fruit, vegetables and milk - was an obligation for the Member States participating in the programme. The Member States participating in this programme - I would remind you that this participation is voluntary - will have the opportunity to expand the list of products, but under very strict conditions. For example, we have secured a ban on artificial sweeteners and flavours, as well as strengthening the role of national health authorities. I would remind you that one of the main objectives of this new programme is to combat childhood obesity and improve the health of children. Educational measures, now compulsory, will aim to bring children closer to agriculture, while teaching them good eating habits from an early age. Let us not forget that school plays an important role when it comes to training young people in life and encouraging them to develop healthy eating habits. The new programme also aims to encourage local and regional production, short circuits, organic products and thus support small local farmers by also promoting seasonality. Moreover, Parliament's powers are strengthened from this negotiation, since the Council wanted the application of Article 43, paragraph 3, which excluded us from important parts of this issue. Finally, we got in the negotiations base 43, paragraph 2, which gives us full co-decision. I fought and managed, with the help of all the shadow rapporteurs, to safeguard the prerogatives of this Parliament. With regard to the budget in particular: we have obtained an increase in the eur 20 million envelope for the Milk Programme to a hundred million, so that it is painless for countries that have used it very well for a long time and that they are not penalised by a distribution that will also apply to countries that did not have historical references. I am thinking of Croatia, in particular. With regard to transfers between the two programmes: Parliament and the Council agreed on a 20% transfer between the two programmes, with an additional 5% for the outermost regions. Some countries wanted 50% or even 100%. It would not have made sense, because one program would have been emptied for the benefit of the other. A European Commission report on the application of transfers was also awarded in 2023. We have also made the allocation of budget envelopes between Member States fairer. Two criteria for the whole programme: the share of children aged 6 to 10 in the Member States, but also the degree of development and the region of the Member State. For milk, we will take into account the historical use of program funds, as I said, with obviously - we have not forgotten - countries that did not have a historical reference or, at least, that had less. Clearly, the visibility of programmes and the reduction of administrative burdens represent further progress achieved by Parliament, always pursuing the same objective: to enable more children and schools to benefit from this programme. For all these reasons, I call on all colleagues to support this report, which aims to improve children's health, encourage food education and support agricultural production, which is, as you know, in difficulty, particularly in the fruit and vegetable sector.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to congratulate all, and in particular Mr Tarabella and the shadow rapporteurs, for the substantial efforts invested to conclude this file successfully.  I am sure Mr Tarabella will agree, and the shadows will agree, that it is an understatement to say that this process was complex and challenging since many sensitive issues had to be tackled, such as the legal basis of the proposal, the range of products to distribute, the budget of the programme, as well as the transfers between allocations for milk and fruit and vegetables.  After long and intensive discussions we finally secured a balanced agreement, not least thanks to the input and efforts of Parliament. This progress could have been achieved only with constructive cooperation and a flexible position from all sides. I have personally done my part in defending this scheme’s continuation and I thank Parliament for having done a great job in helping me to secure the future of the scheme. Parliament has played an important role in strengthening the health aspects of this scheme, in particular by ensuring that sufficient priority and prominence is given to fresh products. Members also took a solid position in relation to the objectives of the programme: to ensure that children learn to appreciate the real taste of products without substances used to enhance this taste. With your support tomorrow in the vote you will confirm an investment of EUR 250 million per year for the benefit of children and their attitude towards agriculture, and for healthy eating. This means over a six-year period a fixed budget of EUR 1.5 billion. The adoption of the new scheme comes at a very important time for our farmers, who are facing very difficult circumstances, particularly in the dairy sector, and the increased budget for milk can enhance demand by building healthy eating habits for the future. I am looking forward to a rapid conclusion of the first reading.

name: Albert Deß
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Thank you to all those who have contributed to the fact that an improved school milk and school fruit programme can be offered throughout Europe. I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs in particular. In five trialogues, a result has been achieved with which, in my opinion, all those involved can live well. It is now a question of the programmes being implemented swiftly in the Member States. A key point of the new regulation is that the previously separate programmes are grouped together. It is now also possible to move and transfer a certain part of the funds between the two programmes – And I think that is a good thing.  It is gratifying that Parliament has managed to increase the school milk programme by a further EUR 100 million to EUR 100 million and EUR 150 million for the school fruit programme. As Marc Tarabella has mentioned, this will preserve the funds available so far, at least in all Member States, and it will also take account of the special situation in Croatia and the outermost regions. I think it is important that our children and pupils are introduced to our excellent products in schools, and it is envisaged that certain funds may be used for pedagogical training. I also think this is necessary so that our children learn again that the milk does not come from the purple cow, but from black-coloured or brown-coloured cows. My group will certainly vote in favour by a large majority.

name: Paolo De Castro
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the programme for the distribution of fruit and milk in schools is one of the most important educational actions put in place by the Union to encourage young Europeans to eat healthily, to know and to consume the traditional products of our land.  I would therefore like to thank my colleague Marc Tarabella and our entire negotiating team for their excellent work and the important result achieved, not least in guaranteeing the European Parliament its fundamental democratic role as co-legislator. That is why I would also like to thank the Commission, which has maintained the Position of the European Parliament to the end.  Despite the Council's decision to call into question important points of the initial proposal, it has in fact been possible to reach an ambitious agreement introducing broader educational measures, combined with a fairer distribution of funds among the Member States. This European plan is therefore a strong path that aims to make food culture one of the cornerstones of the Union's policies dedicated to the younger generation.

name: James Nicholson
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on an excellent job. There were a few hiccups on the way, but he certainly proved himself to be an excellent rapporteur. I think that all involved were certainly extremely happy with the way it went.  I welcome the proposal. I think it will be good and I am sure that it will also send a strong message, not only to the dairy sector, but also to the fruit sector. Certainly the decisions that were made – and the Parliament made a large contribution – just prove that, when you work together, an awful lot more can be achieved than maybe was initially thought possible. Speaking for my own region I certainly look forward to that and I know the majority of the ECR Group will be voting for this.  I believe that your proposal will go through. I am delighted that the overall budget part of the scheme has been extended and that the Commission and Parliament were able to find a way to do that. I have to say that I am glad we are having this debate this evening, but I feel it is very unfortunate that we are not having the debate on pigs immediately, when the Commissioner is here.  When pig farmers are being destroyed throughout Europe, this Parliament did not see fit to put on that debate when we had the Commissioner and everybody here. This is by no means wishing to show disrespect for the rapporteur, who has done a tremendous job. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Dear colleague, I would like to ask you something. I completely agree that this is a very important educational programme for children, but the title of this report and the fact that we are emphasising bananas – we speak about fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk – do you not think that we should emphasise European fruit products, such as the apple? We could say supply of fruit, vegetables, apples and milk, because bananas come from imports. We should help to sustain European production, do you not think so?

name: James Nicholson (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – I thank my colleague for that excellent question. I am quite happy to include all fruit, the names of all fruits – pears, strawberries – as all fruit is good for you, so I do not have a problem with that. I come from the county of Armagh in Northern Ireland and as you will know full well, Madam President, we are known as the apple county of the island of Ireland, from Northern Ireland, so certainly I would take great pleasure if I were able to promote the noble apple better in any way.

name: Ulrike Müller
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I would also like to thank Marc Tarabella very much for the excellent fights he has delivered in our trialogue. He has really called for Parliament's powers, and I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their cooperation. We have succeeded in bringing about the merger of the aid scheme for school milk, school fruit and vegetables. I would like to see a strong vote in plenary. We have set out to cut red tape, and we should succeed in doing so. We have achieved an increase in funding, which was not clear at the beginning either. With this programme, we are now reaching 30 million children aged six to ten, who are reached every week with a free supply of milk and fruit. Two things were very important to me: firstly, that we also included the list of processed products. The second was the accompanying educational measures for nutrition education. In the future, housekeeping masters and nutritionspecialists in schools will also be able to teach their children nutrition and knowledge.  After all, mistakes have crept in in our education system: our children no longer have everyday competence. They no longer know how to deal with staple foods and what to actually prepare from staple foods for high-quality food. This is an important basis and an important element that we have now anchored here in the merging of the programmes. I am very glad that the accompanying educational measures are also effective for the benefit of our children. We are pleased to agree with this trialogue. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. Thank you, Madam President. Of course, I too agree that children's health is a priority and I congratulate Marc Tarabella. My question and the vagueness is about additional funds or higher aid for children between 6 and 10 years of age. Why 10 and not 14? How did this category "between 6 and 10 years" be established? As far as I'm concerned, it had to be wider. Thanks.

name: Ulrike Müller (ALDE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you very much for your question, ladies and gentlemen. In general, of course, we would all be in favour of giving the children this food longer. However, this is about children between first and fourth grades in primary school. At the end of the day, it is always a question of money and resources. We now have EUR 1.5 billion in six years. I believe that this is a good number, there are some things that can be done and, if they wish, the Member States can still co-finance anyway.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: gue/NGL Group. Madam President, I thank Mr Tarabella for his work.  We are positively assessing that the European Union will continue to support the promotion and distribution of fruit, vegetables, bananas and dairy products in schools, as a way of raising children's awareness of the role of fresh food products and also as a way of making known the origin of food. I think it is very good that the possibility of encouraging purchases of local and organic products has also been introduced. In order to raise awareness of how food is produced and how they contribute to the economy and to keeping the rural environment alive, priority should be given to the distribution in schools of local seasonal and ecological products and visits to farmers and farmers and also to local markets, under development of Article 1 and Nine of this report, should be given priority.

name: Bronis Ropė
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Dear Commissioner, honourable colleagues, I would like to begin by thanking Mr. Marc Tarabella (the rapporteur) for his excellent work. In the preparation of this report, I was the shadow rapporteur for the Greens and I must note, although we were not very much in the early world, but we managed to draw up a really good document. What is good and deserves the unconditional support of the European Parliament? Let's start with the fact that it sets goals for the formation of quality eating habits for pupils and guidelines for good management of the programme. The new regulation has succeeded in broadening the list of products supplied to schools for the purpose of developing healthy eating habits. Sometimes maybe even too much. I still can't understand how you can eat olive oil or what healthy food habits can be shaped by drinking chocolate milk? But let us leave this to the knowledge of the individual Member States. What is more important is that we have probably succeeded for the first time in european union legislation that flavour enhancers such as monosodium glutamate are wrong. We have succeeded in anticipating that European Union funds will not be used to finance food products with these unhealthy additives. It is difficult to believe with common sense alone, but it is unlikely that such a ban would have existed so far. We have also managed to improve the entire management of the support programme. The new document clarifies the criteria for allocating funds among Member States. Member States will be able to use support funds more flexibly. We have also successfully included provisions to promote short supply chains. In addition, in the context of good governance, greater involvement of local and regional authorities in the programme-making and implementation process is envisaged. This is very important because it is local authorities that are generally better off than the central ones of the specific needs of the local population.

name: Marco Zullo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mr Tarabella for his excellent synthesis work and also for the way in which he conducted the negotiations to the trialogue, which made it possible to bring home a good result from our point of view.  First of all with regard to the budget, then the appropriate amount of funds allocated to the school fruit and milk distribution programme. But, secondly, the goal of this program is very important, which is to educate young people to consume fresh products, limiting the use of added sugars and salts.  In fact, a continent where 26% of adults are overweight, it is absolutely essential to start from schools to teach and make it clear how to proceed with healthy, responsible and sustainable eating.  Now, when it comes to implementing the programme, we must not train ourselves but make sure, in our Member States, that this programme is implemented as correctly as possible and that all the necessary controls are also implemented. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 149(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support We have also heard from Mr Tarabella and others that this is a very important goal, which is good for children's health, good for the European food industry, for agriculture. My question, Congressman, is whether you agree with me that it is also our duty to present such a programme as a joint action of the European Union. So, to be good for the European Union as a whole. Because it is strange to me that there are political forces who are constantly using and emphasizing only the negatives of the European Union, and not such highly successful programmes.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: Answer to a blue card question. I believe that it is essential to work on the education of children in general, so that today's young people, who will be the adults of the future, arrive in the world of work and in the world in general in complete awareness, which will help us all, regardless of the diversity of points of view expressed today.

name: Edouard Ferrand
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am very pleased to see that the work done here in the European Parliament is often of much better quality than the European Commission is proposing. On this report, I would simply say that the continuation of the programme of distribution of fruits, vegetables, bananas and dairy products in schools is a good thing, and even a very good thing. Nevertheless, I note that it still faces serious difficulties. It also allows member countries to implement the programme in the way they wish and to promote the use of local products. We therefore call on us to support this programme, this report, and to ensure that there is always the maintenance of short circuits, local supplies and products from European agriculture.

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that this agreement being discussed today on the distribution of fruit and milk in schools is very beneficial for the European Union, for the Member States, for the agricultural and livestock sector but, above all, for European children and young people, who, through this excellent programme, have the possibility of improving their food culture and , with this, their levels of well-being.  For me, it has been very good that the volume of the child population be taken into account when sharing these funds should be included in the agreement. Also, of course, that there is that extra 20 million in milk endowment because, of course, it could not be otherwise: we expand the money because we expand the products that can be used. And, of course, the transfer of that 20% of funds between milk and fruit and vegetables gives Member States the opportunity to adapt the budget to the productive reality of each Member State.  So welcome are all those points of the agreement; also the introduction of foods such as processed fruits, because let us not forget that we have to make young people, European children, these products accessible and appetizing, either in their fresh form or in a transformed way: cheeses, yogurts or drinks. For the future we will leave the introduction of foods such as olives, honey or olive oil, which would deserve to be within this agreement but, for the time being, we have not succeeded. We'll keep trying: it'll be for the future. Let this agreement be implemented as soon as possible. Congratulations! (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Peter Jahr (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I have a demand for cutting red tape. Here I could say, "I hear the message, but I lack faith." Mrs Garcia, what do you think, should we not ask the Commission for a report on implementation and an experience report, so that the Member States are almost forced to implement this programme without red tape? We have taken good decisions; now the Member States should finally take a non-bureaucratic approach. I have my doubts about that. We want young people to eat a really healthy diet.

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – Dear colleague, Mr Jahr, I think the really important thing is that member states are encouraged to implement the programme, which is currently voluntary but should be compulsory. Member States should be forced to make this effort to accept that children, young people, have to improve their food customs. It is the eternal problem we always have: bureaucracy in this European Union. I believe that there has to be an average path between managing public money and streamlining procedures. That's what I agree with you on.

name: Maria Noichl (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to join the previous speakers in their support. Three important points have been reached, namely: programmes that have been running successfully for many years have been summing up, the funds have been increased and there has been an improvement in the legal basis, and in particular the legal basis for Parliament. My announcement today is also to make the goal even clearer. The aim of these programmes is quite clear that sensory learning is also required. At school you always learn with your head, with your heart and with your hand – as it is called. But you also have to learn with your mouth. You have to learn how things really taste right when they are really ripe, when they are really good. In other words, sensory learning is at the heart of it: it is clear that taste creation is being promoted.  In times of fast food, taste formation is getting under the wheels more and more. Children only taste very sweet and quite salty, and the intermediate tones taste them too little. Taste formation is one of the most important goals, besides health and, at the end of course, of course, the change in behaviour. These children who get fruit and vegetables at school are our later consumers, are our later buyers. These children should learn quality from the beginning and later also buy high-quality products.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Speaking in the debate on the Milk at School and Fruit at School programmes, I would like to point out that, in my opinion, they are effectively changing the eating habits of children and young people. The former has been around for nearly forty years and is attended by nearly twenty million children. The latter is much shorter, but also attended by about ten million students.  Therefore, the Commission's initiative to implement both programmes under a common legal and time frame deserves parliament's strong support, especially as this means simplifying the procedures for accession and participation in both programmes. This, in turn, will encourage an increase in the number of beneficiaries of both schemes, increasing the number of young people using them, and thus in the future the number of consumers of milk and processed products, as well as fruit and vegetables, which will create additional demand for European agricultural products. Finally, I would like to thank the Commission for its decision to increase the funding for the School Milk programme by EUR 20 million, which has resulted in eur 100 million for this programme and EUR 150 million for the School Fruit Programme.

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I cannot help detecting a bit of mission creep here, because health should be a competence of the Member State and yet this scheme is being pushed for health reasons. Perhaps I am being a bit cynical, but I cannot help feeling that the EU is trying to get its way into every aspect of our lives. I am also interested to see that the schools that go into the scheme have got to erect ‘gratitude plaques’– in other words, the picture of the blue background and the yellow stars to say how grateful everyone must be to the EU. As the children drive to school they will see gratitude plaques in the fields – the farmers have their environmental schemes – and then they go into school and there are more gratitude plaques, and this is all going to happen during our referendum campaign about British membership of the European Union. Call me cynical. I hope that the milk in the schools will be British milk and not Irish milk, but we shall wait and see, and of course the British apple grower will not be very pleased if his product is not mentioned and bananas are. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Thank you very much, Mr. Advocate for accepting my blue card. You said that health care should be exclusively within the state's jurisdiction, that is, it should be within the national framework. I really wonder how you can make a statement like that when you know all the epidemics we have in the world today. We have a World Health Organization, so don't accuse the European Union and the existence of the European Union every time we know how important healthcare is to us, especially when we have epidemics and pandemics on this globe. Do you agree with me that I'm right?

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Well, I can state quite categorically that health is not an EU competence in a Member State. It is as simple as that. It is one of the few things that are not and I do not want to see it happen.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I congratulate the rapporteur on the successfully completed negotiations with the Council and the European Commission on this act important for European and Croatian children. The agreed text finally eliminates the reasons that have taught the Republic of Croatia to participate in the use of European Union subsidies for healthy milk meals in schools. I have pointed to this problem numerous times at the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, but also at this pulpit, and I am glad that my arguments have been accepted.  The Regulation allows agricultural producers a new market through the placement of domestic, quality products in schools. The Regulation also allows Member States to include in their measures a wider range of agricultural products, as well as other local, regional or national specialties such as honey, olive oil or table olives. This program, in addition to having an educational role for our young people about what they need to eat and that they should eat healthy and homemade, it also has a social dimension because for poor children this meal will be the only meal they will eat. (Speaker agreed to answer the question "blue card" (Article 162(8) of the E.S. regulation)).

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – I would like to ask Mrs. Representative, but also a little bit of the others who are dealing with the details of this programme, that although I really believe that there are products in every country that are very, very important specifically – we are talking about national products – but if we look at the volume of this programme and see, roughly speaking, that there is four, that is, four euros per child per year from EU funding, I see that that this is a fairly relatively serious discussion.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – (the beginning of the speech is not heard)... Whatever money we have, if it is intended for our children and their well-being is welcome. I agree with you that surely the amounts should be increased, as €250 million in subsidies for the entire European Union through this kind of allocation and member states wishing to participate are certainly not sufficient for all needs.  I will mention only the example of Croatia. According to the latest statistics, in Croatia 17,000 children are hungry, they cannot afford any meals in schools because their parents are poor. Therefore, this will still be a help because they will receive a twice-weekly healthy meal in schools for free.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I would also like to thank Mr Tarabella and all those who have co-negotiated here, because I believe that something good has come about. Of course, while I can also gain something from the criticism that EUR 250 million is not much, I think it is gratifying that we have a step where we move forward, where a budget has been increased in the interests of the people, especially children. After all, this EUR 1.5 billion for the next six years should not only be a help for agriculture and for the products we produce in Europe, but above all something that helps our children to eat healthily, to learn how healthy products taste, how unprocessed, unprocessed products are of their nature, in their purity.  These are all things that could be achieved with this programme. If, of course, I do not agree 100% with the compromise – because I believe that chocolate milk, etc. is not necessarily something that belongs there – we have managed to take measures in these areas too: that only the milk content is promoted here, that, as colleagues have already said, there must be no additional sweeteners in the future, no flavourings, etc., namely artificial ones. I believe that these are very, very important steps. I would also like to say to Mr Agnew that he may not have read the Treaty of Lisbon carefully. Article 168 states that health is a responsibility, a task, in all policies (health in all areas of the EU) and that it is, of course, also a task to take health aspects into account in all policies. I believe that this is precisely what is happening here. It is in agriculture, it is in education, and it is essential especially for the health sector. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – I thank the Chairman, I thank my colleague. I have listened closely to you and I fully agree with you that this program is very important to ensure healthy food for children in schools, but also an education program. However, do you think that this programme could further help small agricultural producers so that their products are the ones who come to schools because they are the healthiest?

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. The programme provides for just that. It provides for healthy, fresh, unprocessed and, above all, local food to find its way into schools. This is the essential aspect of this health, nutrition and education programme.

name: Jørn Dohrmann (ECR).
text: Madam President! Dear colleagues! This is a good initiative, because there are far too many young people who do not get good, healthy and nutritious diets, but choose unhealthy foods. That is why it is also important for the EU to try to promote healthy diets with a high content of fruit, vegetables and milk as much as possible. Especially because there is some evidence that consumption of dairy products, fruit and vegetables is decreasing. At the same time, food producers across Europe are facing major economic problems and the scheme therefore also allows for further marketing to the sector in need. All good intentions must, of course, be in respect for the budget and for the country's right to decide for themselves whether to be part of such a system. But the Danish People's Party also wants, for example, to give young people a knowledge of how to treat animals, i.e. animal welfare, because good food also requires good animal welfare. Just think of the long transport of animals, they should of course be avoided.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I therefore do not like the proposal to subsidise milk for schools. You express yourself here as saviors or saviors of children, and you brag about how you created an ingenious program.  But I would like to say that the European Union is not a mother to determine what children should eat in schools. And the health of milk is at least questionable. And if you forbid those schools from offering flavored, sweetened milk, you can bet the kids won't drink it. And who knows what they're going to do about it. So what children are supposed to eat should come first, so it would be best to leave the EUR 250 million in the pockets of the taxpayers, the parents of these children, and not for the European Union to deal with it. If you think milk should be subsidised in your countries, then resolve it within your nation states and let us not bring the European Union into this. If you brag that the program is voluntary, the countries that won't participate will actually indirectly subsidize the other states. So I will strongly oppose this proposal. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr Colleague, have you noticed that the European Union does not forbid anything on this matter, that it merely supports a certain type of product? I think it's a good idea to put it in context with your performance.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – We should remember that if the European Union has a programme where it wants to give EUR 250 million to subsidise certain products, and there will be milk in these products that is not sweetened, it will in this way make unsweetened milk for children, and this is, of course, at the expense of other types of snacks and it is at the expense of taxpayers who want something different for children. So it's good that chocolate milk isn't forbidd from Brussels to be bought by the kids, but it subsidizes milk that no one's going to drink. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: "blue card" question. – I have listened to you well. I am actually very sorry that you are taking down this wonderful project for the schools, for our farmers. I'm probably one of the few here in the hemisphere. My children are in a school and we live in a city where all schools participate in these programs. I can assure you: an apple a day keeps the doctor away. So I would like to ask you: put that aside, promote these programmes in schools. I would also like to ask you: promote the fruit sector to all voters!

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Colleague, I don't understand – if you think an apple or milk is so healthy for your children – why don't you buy it for them for a snack? Why do you have to come up with a programme for 500 million Europeans from Brussels? Do we need this European Union to buy children an apple or milk?

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I see that there are a lot of requests to ask questions by picking up a blue card. That is why I have adopted the principle that a maximum of one such question may be submitted to one speaker. This will really better organize and improve our work.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are facing a very important agreement for the whole of Europe. A program that pursues healthy eating habits is always welcome. If, moreover, it is improved and better endowed, even more so.  But there's something else. In addition, this is a programme of particular relevance for the outermost regions – for example, for the Canary Islands, where I come from – and that is that an agreement has been reached that recognizes the need to allocate greater funds for the outermost regions and it is the first time that an agreement outside the framework of POSEI includes specific support for these territories and their products.  The text states that Member States should ensure greater support to these regions in order to take account of their specific situation in the light of the origin of the products and to promote supply between outermost regions close to each other. In addition, the flexibility available to them to transfer aid between the milk and fruit programme is increased for these regions.  And a very important issue for the producers, for bananas: here, today I am still astonished, it has been said that bananas had to disappear from the title because bananas are not produced in Europe. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, bananas are produced in Europe. The Canary Islands produces the best banana in the world and the Canary Islands is Europe, also Madeira, also Martinique. Don't forget it. In the next Plenary I will bring you bananas from the Canary Islands so that it can be seen in particular by those Members who are unaware that bananas are produced in the European Union.  Thank you, thank you very much and congratulations. I think it is important that the special needs of these territories have been understood and that they are supported from this House.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: You have made us, Mr President, taste for these bananas. Probably some of us will benefit from this.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to join colleagues in congratulating the rapporteur on this proposal: Mr Tarabella. I think you have done a magnificent job together with the rest of the shadow rapporteurs; it has been particularly difficult to make the Council see that Parliament's decision was also important.  It is a European programme and that is a very important thing: that the importance of improving the health of European children is taken seriously. Healthy habits in children are a very important thing and that is why this Parliament will bet on it.  We also support European productions: I am particularly pleased and pleased that the distribution of fresh produce is a priority. I think if there's one thing missing from children's eating habits, it's the fresh produce. Therefore, that this criterion is preferable seems to me to be very relevant.  I would also have liked that the distribution criteria in the milk programmes would not have taken into account the historical criteria but the number of children, as in the fruit programme; but I don't think you can have everything.  And I would also like to say that I would also have liked the incorporation – Mr Tarabella, you know this – of olive oil, for distribution also in schools. In any case it has been included in the educational proposals and I am satisfied.  My congratulations on this great program that we are going to approve for the most part.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – I, too, would like to express my thanks to colleague Marc Tarabella for this gigantic work and for the contribution of all the colleagues involved in the betterment of this programme. Indeed, it is essential, it is essential, that the European Parliament address the nutrition of children. This is because the roughly 60 million young people in Europe are in need of additional support for healthy eating. At the same time, I find it a shame that the Member States are doing little or nothing about this. And if the European Union, the European Commission and the European Parliament did not have a clear position on this, many, many Member States, as it is, would abolish such programmes – and I regard this as one of the shames of Europe. But thanks to the European institutions for paying attention to this after all. Finally, one more thing. Some governments collect very heavy taxes on these programmes – for example, the Hungarian Government imposes a VAT rate of 27%, and a VAT rate of 27% on all food, including items of child food. I would ask everyone to consider making food vat-free or very low vat-free in Europe, not only in this programme, but also overall– together.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: – I think that this programme is very positive for our children in the European Union. It allocates one and a half billion to six years and affects 30 million children. Twice a week they actually get a healthy snack, fruits, vegetables, bananas, but also milk. This is very important because the younger generation in Europe, not just in America, is suffering from obesity, and everyone obese will have later difficulties in the field of cardiovascular disease or musculoskeletal disorders, and it is this European programme that can rightly kick-start the healthy diet of our children. I am pleased that an agreement has been reached between the Commission, the European Parliament and that a sensible compromise has been pushed through, which will also have its future, and I am pleased that this will also encourage nutritional habits, that children will not consume the tuned and unhealthy components of the diet, but that this will be based only on local and healthy products.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank Mr Tarabella for the tenacity, conviction and passion with which he conducted the negotiations and completed the work on this regulation. EUR 250 million: an important budget for the future and for the healthy growth of our society.  The schemes for the supply of fruit, vegetables and milk in schools, in fact, concern the health of our children, who should follow a balanced diet that is attentive to their nutritional needs, and school, in this too, plays a central role. The educational aspect is central: in a globalized world where the supply of food products is very high. training informed consumers protects against disease and scams.  Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur for including an aspect which is particularly close to my heart in the Regulation. Products distributed in schools must be local products. Priority must be given to regional production in order to support markets in great suffering, but also because the link with the land and with the agriculture of its territory is rediscovered by traditions and self-knowledge.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what to do about it. Take inspiration from the Nordic countries. We provide children with healthy and varied school meals every day. Meals are paid for through taxes, so children from poor families also get to enjoy good school meals. There won't be a separate payment slip for anyone's home. The best thing about the system is that it pays for itself. Once a child adopts healthy eating habits, they also eat better as an adult. The consequences are known: less overweight, fewer illnesses and less burden on the national economy. I believe that the aid system under way is a step in the right direction. The EU and its Member States should increasingly support healthy school meals.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr. President, there are a lot of positive developments in this report, and it's very good that everything that was negotiated on the trilogue is very good. Of course I would like to emphasize in particular the importance of this report, which speaks about the need to educate young people, about the health of young people, and which emphasizes what is important for a young man. I would also like to emphasize the importance that the need of Croatia in this report has been recognized and that finally Croatian children will get what they really need.  But I want to emphasize something that I especially consider important, which is the fact that they intend to incorporate local products, regional products as something that will be in schools because I believe that this means something special for young people: to recognize their territory, to recognize their region in which they live and through the products that are created in this territory.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the idea behind this programme is positive. However, how it will be put into practice can make all the difference. We do not understand, first of all, why the two programmes were merged, in the absence of the opinion of the technicians, who preferred the existence of two separate and autonomous programmes.  Secondly, we stress here that this programme will only succeed if it is firmly anchored to a local development strategy, a strategy for valuing local production and which can contribute to greater social and territorial cohesion, reconciling the city with its rural surroundings.  Thirdly, it must be said that this strategy will be a failure if we continue with the aggressive presence of fast food chains at school doors, or if we continue to have, even within the schools themselves, machines that are dispensing all kinds of food that are not recommended for healthy eating. The state and public schools are a decisive element in this battle in defence of our children and young people.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, I would like to express my support for the supply of fruit, vegetables, bananas and milk in educational establishments and thank the rapporteur for his work on this important file.  We should use every opportunity to provide healthy alternatives for young people at an early age, teaching the values of nutritious healthy foods and contributing to the solution of a growing obesity crisis. Of course, as our rapporteur has indicated, such schemes also provide an outlet for a dairy market that has seen extremely difficult trading conditions and low prices for some time. This scheme will not only increase consumption but will be important in increasing awareness of the benefits of dairy products as well as fruit and vegetables.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to join my colleagues in supporting this programme. I am glad that he has such broad support across the political spectrum.  It is true that two programmes were originally merged. This will have the advantage that some of the funds can be transferred between programmes, and there has also been a shift in negotiations to expand the range of dairy and fruit products used.  But I think the primary thing is to get kids between the ages of six and 10 to get healthy eating habits. To eat healthy foods. It is true that today's lifestyle in families often does not allow parents to equip children in this way. So it is not about any regulation, but about positive motivation, which should have a positive effect on the health of our children. This should be primarily and, of course, support for domestic agricultural production.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I congratulate the rapporteur, Marc Tarabella, on the result achieved on this important dossier on the distribution of fruit and vegetables and milk in schools. One of the key objectives is to combat the current decline in the consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables and dairy products, especially among children, as well as to educate for healthy eating and to counteract the increase in the incidence of childhood obesity due to eating habits that often contain high doses of added sugars, salt, fats and additives.  I welcome the accompanying educational measures in support of distribution included in the agreement and it is important to bring children closer to agriculture and to encourage young citizens to know about food and their origin, to family with their taste and with the varieties of eu agricultural products, especially those produced in their region, with the help, for example, of experienced nutritionists and farmers. It is therefore an excellent result, to encourage the consumption of fruits, vegetables and milk.  I believe, however, that in order to verify the effectiveness of Member States' programmes, it will be appropriate to provide for actions to monitor and evaluate the results achieved, with particular attention to the medium-term change in consumption.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, malnutrition in Greece has taken on enormous proportions. According to the prevention research institute, six out of ten Greek students in 2013 - 2014 did not have access to food of sufficient quality. In addition, for the school year 2014 - 2015 53% of pupils' families face food insecurity and 21% suffer from hunger. This shows that European aid for the supply of fruit and vegetable products and even dairy products to greek schools is half-measures and not sufficient to tackle child malnutrition in Greece, which greece is now facing in recent years a humanitarian crisis. It must be made clear in every direction that the eradication of malnutrition in schools cannot wait, as children's health is at risk. So what needs to be done is for the troika to take the debt noose out of Greece, to stop the mercely austerity and the suffocation of the Greek economy, especially in view of the critical situation that the refugee issue is causing Greece.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Mr President, I have to agree that it is a very positive step to incorporate the consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables and fresh milk into the diet of European adults. Of course, I very much doubt that these measures alone will bring some effect if they are not combined with a simultaneous learning of the beneficial effects of this diet, not only from children but also from their parents and other adults.  Of course, I would like to point out that with the austerity policies implemented by the European Union this diet will probably be the only one that some Greek children will have access to, since we have a huge increase in unemployment and many parents are unable to offer even the necessities to their children once they have zero income. At the same time, there is no welfare state to care for them, as the few resources available are now directed as a priority to meet the needs of migrants.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – My sincere congratulations to my colleague Tarabella and the other shadow rapporteurs, commissioner, for bringing the fruit and vegetables and milk scheme to the end of the process in a challenging process – and other crops. This is a very important measure. A measure by which, as has already been said, we improve dietary habits in children, which is very important for their health, and, on the other hand, we also allow fruit and vegetables to be on the menu at school and that these habits are later transferred to homes. It is important that resources are increased. Two hundred and fifty million euros a year is very much a resource. For Slovenia, for example, this means three hundred thousand euros more per year. It is in Slovenia that for many years we have also introduced locally produced products into the meals of young people in primary school via traditional honey breakfast. And this measure now allows such traditional high-quality products to be included in this meal. My sincere congratulations and I believe that the Member States will be happy to take advantage of this scheme for the good of the children and all of us.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would also like to join the voice of the rapporteurs of this report. The acquisition of eating habits that promote better health, especially among younger populations, must be part of the public policy objectives. The agreement on the support scheme for the distribution of fruit and milk in schools is a public investment in this regard. In addition, a two-way objective is to encourage the demand for agricultural products from short circuits, thereby favouring local agricultural production.  I am pleased with the positive discrimination granted to the outermost regions, which, under certain conditions, will be able to benefit from a higher level of aid due to supply difficulties or adverse market conditions. This device may prove particularly important at this time of crisis in the sectors in question, particularly in milk, and for the Azores – and here, my dear friend Gabriel Mato, I remember that they also produce bananas – functioning as a contribution to the disposal of products and thus a price guarantee for milk producers.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, healthy eating of preschool and school children is a very important item in public health policies. I am glad that we have developed an awareness of the importance of healthy eating, especially in children because they are rapidly developing. But I must express my regret that we have not equally developed awareness of the harm of support for the global competitiveness of our economy. I agree that we need to facilitate the distribution of healthy foods to educational institutions, especially in passive areas, but I would like us to primarily influence Member States to simplify their tax systems and reduce levies on companies that should then not be over-encouraged to distribute this kind of distribution. I believe that in this home the welfare of children comes first to everyone, but it can hardly be without working parents with decent wages with whom to support these children. I support this programme, but I think in the future we need to look at the well-being of children in a broader context because only a healthy and globally competitive economy can guarantee long-term prosperity for future European generations.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all, I wish to thank all the people who have generally supported the scheme. The scheme needed to be changed because of a Commission evaluation, but also because of a Court of Auditors report which highlighted that there were deficiencies and inefficiencies because of two separate schemes in milk and fruit and vegetables. The fact that we now have those schemes together will save money on administration, provide a more efficient scheme and give more money directly to the educational establishments for our particular products.  It is an important timing for this particular scheme, with market difficulties in dairy and fruit and veg, and there has been a request for a larger budget because there is a higher demand for these very important schemes in many of our Member States. I would like to say to Mr Mach and Mr Agnew that it is a voluntary, co-financed scheme – there is no compulsion for Member States to participate. The United Kingdom, I understand, participates in the milk scheme.  Ms Noichl mentioned that we should have priority given to local fresh products over processed foods in order to generate healthy living and good habits for children at a younger age, and this is exactly what the scheme is intended to do and what it is doing. Mr Frunzulică and Mr Mato mentioned fruit and vegetables and how important it is to have a broad range of products included, and I am particularly pleased to agree with the inclusion of bananas in this particular scheme, which is important for areas like the Canary Islands, but also for our outermost regions, our POSEI regions, which is a great boost to the consumption of those particular internal European Union products.  I would like to say to Ms Grapini that the main target group intended in these schemes is children between six and ten years old, and it will certainly hit the target that she advocated. The importance of having this scheme at such a young age will hopefully, as many speakers have indicated, be able to get young people involved and young children at this early age involved in good healthy habits in terms of their food intake and to be able to deal with the health agenda, particularly in terms of obesity. Mr Jahr, I agree with these sentiments in relation to streamlining the scheme, and the scheme will be reviewed in 2023, as outlined.  Mr Agnew, I know that you used the word ‘cynical’, but as you know, farmers in the UK do not have to worry about any gratitude plaques, because they get GBP 3.2 billion every year from the European taxpayer. I hope they will continue to get that as Members of the European Union in the future, because you cannot be sure how much money they might get from the UK Treasury.  The flexibility of this particular scheme and the flexibility shown by the rapporteur and the rapporteurs all round will help to make this scheme more successful. I would like to confirm to Ms Aguilera that olive oil is included in the scheme, and I am sure that would be a help to the country that she knows best. From the point of view of the French delegation, honey was also included in the scheme. I hope that this flexibility clearly indicates that we have taken everybody’s views reasonably on board, we have had a balanced outcome and have included as part of the trilogues many initiatives and ideas that people had in a very flexible way. So I wish to congratulate Mr Tarabella again and thank everybody and the shadows for their cooperation and I wish the scheme every success in the years ahead. It will, of course, be like any other scheme and subject to a review, which will be in 2023.

name: Marc Tarabella
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, perhaps we must first remember that, indeed, at Parliament level, it has been firmly ensured that the legal basis is the one that clearly allows codecision. In this regard, I once again thank the shadow rapporteurs, who unanimously supported me and who made the legal basis the one we wanted. On the content, I will make five remarks in response to the comments of five colleagues. Firstly, with regard to 6 to 10 year olds: I would like to point out that this is an objective criterion for determining the amount owed to each Member State, but that it is, of course, open to Member States to use the money for children from zero years, i.e. in nurseries, in pre-schools and primary schools, of course, but also in secondary schools. At least it allowed for objective criteria. The second thought concerned chocolate milk. A few grams of sweetness in such a brutal world, it doesn't hurt. Especially since it was demanded that it be real chocolate, from real chocolate beans, without artificial aromas, and that there be 90% milk in the chocolate milk. So, if by chocolate milk, children can ingest more calcium, which is good for their bone build, so much the better! Thirdly, some criticised the Commission - one of them who did so - by saying that Parliament's role is to listen more to citizens. I note, however, that on this proposal the Commission has done very well, I say! As with the bio regulation that is being discussed, the Commission has done a very good job, and it is the Council that is distorting this regulation for the time being. Regarding the reflection on health authorities, on health which would not be a European competence: clearly, the European Union has every right to be concerned that obesity is on the rise among children and that, in 24 out of 28 countries in the Union, daily consumption of fruit and vegetables is insufficient. We are therefore merely suggesting to the Member States: there is a budget of 250 million, free for them to add national co-financing. Fifth point, on the budget: as I have just said, co-financing by the Member States is possible. I conclude, Mr President, by thanking in particular three people beyond the shadow rapporteurs: Alexandra Leone, my assistant, who has helped me well in this matter, Maggie Coulthard, from my political group, and Hélène Cuisinier, from the staff of Parliament's Agriculture Committee, who has been very effective in negotiating.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Tuesday 8 March 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I believe children will gain a better understanding of healthy nutrition and form healthy eating habits by implementation of this programme. People consume too little fruit and vegetables in the overwhelming majority of the Member States and child obesity is a weighty problem. Therefore, children need education on nutrition to reverse this trend. Moreover, this aid scheme will benefit farmers in the European Union. Thus, I believe this scheme will benefit many, if not all, parties involved. At the very least, children will enjoy a healthy snack every week.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Tarabella, for the work that has been done and his perseverance despite the difficulties encountered in this matter since 2014. I am pleased that Parliament and the Council have reached an agreement. I believe that the issue of healthy eating is crucial for the youngest populations in Europe, while the risks of obesity continue to rise. This type of diet is a habit to take from childhood. The scheme to help distribute fruits and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools is therefore, in my view, a useful programme, both for the health of Europeans and for those involved in the sectors concerned. I have already been able to speak on this subject many times, so I will not go too far. I would just like to point out that it is important to me to maintain a distinction between the two programmes, which ensure that the specificities of fruits and vegetables are taken into account on the one hand, and milk and dairy products on the other.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The European Parliament's proposals for amendments to Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013 and Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 as regards the aid scheme for the marketing of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational establishments ensure a higher level of achievement of the specific and accompanying objectives of the programme. They make it more possible, together with the increase in the consumption of fruits, vegetables and milk by children, to stimulate more local production. I find it particularly valuable to offer local and regional products and to the possibility of including other local, regional or national specialities such as honey, olives and olive oil within the scope of the Regulation. Thus, the programme becomes more adequate to the different conditions in the countries and contributes to the development of agriculture. This will help solve some of the problems of Bulgarian farmers. I welcome the proposal to provide more assistance to less developed regions, which is a show of European solidarity and supports social cohesion.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Writing. – If you want to push healthy food in schools, you must also use common sense in the relevant legislation. I am therefore extremely pleased that, in the negotiations on the new aid programmes for school milk and fruit, common sense has triumphed over the morality of some self-appointed health politicians!
