Austrian products such as school cocoa, fruit milk and fruit yoghurt remain eligible. We have also been able to achieve an increase in European funding to a total of EUR 250 million. It is important to promote dairy products at school and to raise awareness of local food culture and agriculture from a young age. At school, our youngest grow up with local products. School milk in particular makes a contribution to healthy, conscious food and is perhaps a final barrier to cola and chocolate bars.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. – Today, there is unfortunately an increasing decrease in children's consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables and dairy products, as well as an increasing incidence of childhood obesity. This is due, inter alia, to consumer habits geared towards highly processed foods. Thus, we believe that the granting of parish aid to finance the provision of selected agricultural products to children attending educational institutions can make an important contribution to the promotion of healthy eating habits and to the consumption of local products. In the same direction, Member States may also adopt targeted measures to address the changing consumption of milk in the population. In addition, it is necessary to adopt supportive measures aimed at the distribution of these agricultural products in order to achieve the short- and long-term objectives of increasing consumption and developing healthy dieting.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. – Healthy eating habits are an important factor in health and lifestyle, and young people are key to shaping them. I therefore welcome the merger of so far separate schemes for the distribution of milk, fruit and vegetables in schools and the granting of an additional €20 million to finance them and finance learning on healthy eating. I regret that few Member States have systematically organised and mandatory and universally available school meals in primary and secondary schools. This is particularly bad for children coming from poorly-fed families, as the quality of packed lunches that parents prepare themselves is highly dependent on the socio-economic situation of families. Therefore, more should be done to promote and promote universal free school meals, e.g. through projects to find best practices in the EU and mutual learning and with financial support from relevant European funds or programmes.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on the recommendation for second reading, drawn up on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, on the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on portable animal diseases and amending and repealing certain acts in the field of animal health ("Animal Health Law") (11779/11779/) 1/2015 - C8-0008/2016 - 2013/0136(COD)) (rapporteur: Jasenko Selimovic (A8-0041/2016).

name: Jasenko Selimovic
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to begin by thanking all the shadow rapporteurs for their fantastic work. This is a complicated and great team, and without your broad support and skill we would not have had the good result that we have got. I would also like to thank the European Commission, which has demonstrated real skill in terms of creativity and flexibility in the negotiations. At the same time, I would like to express my special thanks to the Latvian Presidency. Its dedication to this dossier has given us a unique opportunity to reach a very attractive agreement for Parliament. The result was the first European law establishing the link between animal welfare, animal health and public health. All in accordance with the principle of "one health".  The communicable diseases to be dealt with by law, such as avian influenza, also threaten human health. The same applies to the spread of antibiotic-resistant bacteria. All in all, this new law gives us much better preparedness and better tools to deal with disease outbreaks in the future and to focus on prevention, prevention. The essence of the law's requirements also includes that every keeper should be forced to apply the principles of good animal husbandry and the responsible use of veterinary medicines. In other words, it will be much more difficult in the future to mask poor animal husbandry with antibiotics. The law also tackles the problem of the stray dogs in Europe. When taking infectious disease control measures against wild and feral animals, national authorities are obliged to avoid any unnecessary pain and suffering in the animals. Breeders and sellers of dogs will be obliged to register, and the European Commission is mandated to adopt EU rules on dog registration, should the need arise. In addition, it has succeeded in resolving the horizontal and therefore extra complex issue of delegated and implementing acts. As a result, Parliament retains power over political issues, the most important of which concerns the list of diseases to be covered by the Animal Health Act, while technical decisions are taken on a scientific basis.  This and much more is now part of the package on which we are going to vote tomorrow. This law will be an important step in the fight against antibiotic resistance in animals and humans and in the environment. More than fifty years of EU legislation divided into thirty-nine different laws are now to be replaced by a clear framework law with clear principles and objectives. It is a brilliant example of the fact that it is actually possible to simplify european animal rules. It is my predecessor, Marit Paulsen, who has worked on this for the most part, and I am grateful that I have had the privilege of finishing this work. Recently, the agreed law was approved by a unanimous committee on agriculture. I hope that you too, ladies and gentlemen, will choose to vote in favour of this important agreement tomorrow.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President,  I am very pleased to appear before the plenary here today with a view to successfully concluding our work on the regulation on transmissible animal diseases, more commonly referred to as the animal health law. This is a very important piece of draft legislation. It is the result of a great deal of hard work by Parliament, by the Council and by the Commission. The outcome is, I believe, a credit to all three institutions. We all share a deep and common understanding of the fundamental importance of animal health and its link to human health. Furthermore, we collectively recognise that animal disease outbreaks and even crises will inevitably occur from time to time. Clearly we must ensure we are best prepared to deal with whatever the future holds in store and whatever possible disease scenarios come our way. Good animal health makes a vital contribution to the sustainability of our agriculture and aquaculture sectors. It also underpins our competitiveness in international markets. The new regulation will bring a more efficient and streamlined system to combat transmissible animal diseases, safeguard human and animal health, and contribute to a safer and more competitive environment for our agriculture and aquaculture sectors.  In particular it will clarify the responsibilities of all actors, such as farmers, veterinarians, other professionals and competent authorities, improve our response to trans-boundary animal disease outbreaks and lighten the burdens of certain measures on the agriculture and aquaculture sectors in a measured and risk-proportionate manner.  The One Health concept is now well enshrined and indeed is becoming more deeply and vitally rooted, for example in relation to our work on antimicrobial resistance. The draft regulation in front of honourable Members today is a principal tool to implement the visions of the Animal Health Strategy 2007-2013. Our work has not always been easy but difficulties have been overcome. All the elements included in this new framework are well thought out and have been thoroughly discussed with all interested parties. I therefore look forward with both hope and expectation to a broad agreement and endorsement of this file. Our work will, of course, continue with the development of delegated and implementing acts and through the practical implementation of the new rules once agreed. I am grateful to Parliament for its important contribution, its hard work and its constructive approach throughout the developmental journey of this file. In particular I wish to thank the rapporteurs, Madam Paulsen for the impressive achievement in reaching an agreement in the political negotiations and Mr Selimović for successfully continuing Madam Paulsen’s work and bringing the dossier to this final stage.  I also thank the shadow rapporteurs of the previous and current European Parliament and the teams involved in the negotiations for all the strenuous efforts they have made. I hope that we can now take the final step in bringing this important file to a successful and satisfactory conclusion.

name: Albert Deß
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I too would like to thank all the rapporteurs, shadow rapporteurs, you, Commissioner Andriukaitis, and the Latvian Presidency for the draft. This new regulation on animal health will combine 50 current disease prevention and control rules. This should help to simplify the existing legal framework. Through numerous compromises and the combination of hundreds of amendments, the Committee on Agriculture has managed to find a broad compromise in terms of disease control and animal health. Effective reporting and cooperation within the 28 EU Member States, but also between EU Member States and third countries, will be better ensured in the future. It was important to us as a Parliament to enshrine the criteria for the list of animal and animal species directly in the regulation, in the basic right. General principles are transparent and science-based decisions in the establishment and updating of the list of epidemics.  It is to be welcomed that this regulation will certainly improve public health. Good animal husbandry is also maintained; this means that epidemics can already be combated. My group will certainly vote in favour of this draft by a large majority. Commissioner, I am convinced that you will ensure that the whole thing is implemented well.

name: Michela Giuffrida
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent years we have dealt with a number of health emergencies due to diseases from animals to humans, including victims. Swine and avian plague are the worst cases, those exalted by the media, but there are several diseases, threats of communicable diseases, which this animal health regulation intends to combat. I would like to thank my fellow Members who have worked with me on this proposal, the rapporteur and Mrs Paulsen, who has concluded his term of office with this regulation, achieving great success and managing to achieve broad consensus among all the groups.  There are two aspects that I would like to highlight today: the first is that, at last, we have put it in black and white, that animal health depends on their well-being, that is, on their living conditions. A mistreated animal can never be a healthy animal. Article 13 of the Treaty recognises that animals are meaningless beings and we call for all those who treat animals, from breeders to holders, to avoid their pain and suffering, applying the principle of good breeding, the former, and treatment that meets rules of humanity, the latter.  Then there is the prevention aspect: the transmission of diseases, which is more than opposed, must be prevented through better animal husbandry and the responsible use of veterinary medicines; prevention that also involves a clear responsibility of those who care for animals.  The importance of this regulation lies in its establishment of a single regulatory framework, compared with the 40 different previous pieces of legislation, some of which were from the 1960s. Clear rules on animal welfare as well as animal health are still needed in a Europe where cases of unjustified violence and actual torture of animals are still all too often tolerated or even ignored to date.

name: Janusz Wojciechowski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Selimovic, the previous rapporteur, who was absent from us, Mrs Paulsen, for the very good work that has been done. We are adopting a regulation of very high importance in the European Union. Concern for animal health is important not only for the animals themselves, but above all for public health reasons, for reasons of human health as well.  As shadow rapporteur of the ECR Group, I would like to express my satisfaction that the proposals for a strategy to protect pets and, indirectly, homeless animals have been taken into account. The obligation to register the identification of these animals introduced in the strategy is a very important step forward on this issue, but I believe that we should take the next steps. The European Union should take responsibility for the humane, rational resolution of animal homelessness: adoption, sterilisation, humanitarian programmes should be supported by the European Union, and that is where I call for it.

name: Jan Huitema
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – The risk of antibiotic resistance is still underestimated too much. Antibiotic use is increasing dramatically worldwide, by as much as 67% in just one generation. Since 1987, however, no new classes of antibiotics have been added. Action must therefore be taken both veterinary and humane. The Netherlands proves that this is possible! In just four years, antibiotic use in animal husbandry has been reduced by more than half. It is good that the Dutch Presidency has made this a spearhead. For the first time in history, a meeting of ministers of both public health and agriculture has been organised, the so-called one health approach is essential.  The new animal health law, which has now been negotiated in Europe, is a step in the right direction. The liberal group has left some crucial elements, such as the legal obligation to use antibiotics responsibly. Antibiotic reduction is not an easy task. It can only be done by working together smartly, good management and innovations in stable systems, for example. The cost aspect is important here. It cannot be that one farmer has to invest and the other does not.  We want to ensure a level playing field and at the same time eradicate the problem at the root. Good legislation is one thing, but what is at stake is implementation. The Netherlands is the world leader when it comes to the reduction of antibiotics. It is high time that the rest of Europe followed suit.

name: Stefan Eck
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the On behalf of the GUE/NGL, I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Selimovic, and Mrs Paulsen, even though she is not here today. It is to be welcomed that Article 1 of this draft takes account of the prevention of animal pain, stress and suffering. Another important positive aspect is the mandatory registration of all professional breeders and sellers of animals, which will help to ensure that the illegal puppy trade, which causes so much suffering to the animals concerned, is finally offered parole. Regular puppy factories engage in a massive illegal trade in unvaccinated puppies, whose health is simply catastrophic due to the circumstances in which they are bred and reared. And this fatal ity also poses enormous risks to the spread of disease. Unfortunately, however, I must also say that this proposal does not really serve animal welfare. Although it clearly emphasises the link between animal welfare and animal health, this proposal focuses on dealing with communicable animal diseases. We expect the Commission to present us with an animal welfare framework law, and to do so as soon as possible. It is about sentient creatures and not about lifeless production units. For my group, the definition of domesticated and wild animals also remains a very problematic point. According to this definition, for example, stray dogs are considered to be wild animals. In practice, this can lead to a further weakening of the already deficient legal protection of stray animals. I would just like to remind you of the circumstances in Romania.

name: Bronis Ropė
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Dear Commissioner, honourable colleagues, I would like to take this opportunity to thank you for the work you are doing in this area, and I would also like to thank the rapporteur for his well-done report. Although the draft legislation in question is merely a framework regulatory document, it adequately reflects the main issues of animal health and disease prevention. We support its goals of protecting animals not only from diseases, but also from stress and pain. We support its system for categorising animal diseases, and the requirements of professional knowledge for animal farmers. At the same time, I would like to call on colleagues to draw attention to structural circumstances that can strengthen the effectiveness of even the best animal welfare objectives. I am thinking of the disastrous decline in the incomes of livestock farmers, such as the declining incomes of dairy producers and pig farmers, which prevent farmers from investing the necessary funds in the health and full feeding of cattle. According to my data, dairy cows have been fed under-quality feed in at least a few Member States for the second year. This means that farmers simply can no longer purchase the necessary nutritional additives, vitamins and medicines, and thus, for economic reasons, creates conditions for the spread of animal diseases. I would therefore like to call on colleagues to vote in favour of this report. At the same time, please bear in mind that, without addressing the economic reasons why farmers are unable to obtain the necessary preparations for animal health protection, we will not be able to make animals in the European Union healthy.

name: Philippe Loiseau
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, contrary to what you are saying, recent events have shown us that animal welfare is not so well respected. The practices of some slaughterhouses do not even seem to take this into account. It is therefore necessary to take measures concerning animal health, as the text proposes, but it is necessary that this well-being be respected to the end of the chain, because the issue is also about food security and, therefore, human health. However, it may be threatened by the links between welfare, animal health and food-borne diseases. Stress, possible abuse and the mode of slaughter can promote the development of diseases, such as E. coli or Salmonella infections, for example, and it depends on the humans and how they treat animals during breeding, of course, but also transport, methods of stunning and slaughter. Regarding ritual slaughter, the Netherlands has decided to subject it to stricter rules and has prescribed stunning and special labelling. This is a common-sense measure! For the slaughter of animals that take several minutes to die is contrary to your principles of animal welfare, which, in fact, is not at all respected by these methods of ritual slaughter. The health risks associated with slitting are also known, as this technique facilitates the reflux of germs from the intestines and stomach, germs that escape through the wound and thus promote contamination of meat. I therefore call on the Commission to take the necessary measures to ensure that the intolerable practices of certain slaughterhouses, which bring a difficult profession into disrepute, are no longer accepted.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, firstly, let me say thank you to the rapporteur for the work on this very lengthy and important file. I am giving a cautious welcome to this report, stressing the importance of animal health and, ultimately, the protection of consumers across Europe. However, we still need more scientific evidence in relation to the causes of antimicrobial resistance and how to effectively deal with that resistance. We must ensure that farmers have access to the correct tools to prevent and treat disease in animals. It is imperative that neither animal welfare nor production efficiency should be compromised as a result of the revised legislation. In relation to the reporting and enforcement of this revision, all Member States must comply equally. British farmers need a level playing field and should not be expected to compete in a two-tier Europe, where they face gold-plating of legislation and others across Europe much less so.

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we are voting this week at second reading on the agreement reached with the Council on animal and plant health which we dragged from the previous parliamentary term. The Commissioner was right to recall our colleague Paulsen from the previous legislature. This agreement we reached is, in my case, acceptable. It gives us more agility, and fundamentally gives more agility to the European Commission to act in the event of a disease with a strong impact. Also and fortunately we will have a list of more important diseases, which gives us more legal certainty in that action. Veterinarians will also play a more active role in the fight against the spread of diseases, as well as in the fight against antimicrobials, which is certainly logical in the ecosystem in which we develop. It is true what Commissioner Andriukaitis said in his initial speech. Inevitably, diseases arise from time to time, but it is also true that the more organized and more prepared we are to tackle them, the less they will harm us, the less they will affect us, the less they will affect our animals, ourselves and our economy. I therefore congratulate the rapporteur, congratulate the shadow rapporteurs and all of us who have contributed to this report, thanks to the European Commission and hopefully he will get ahead without problems. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. I myself agree that there are many, many virtues and values to this current legislation. And actually, at that point, I would like to ask you a question that you have indicated with the word flexibility. In particular, in some countries we can also observe the decentralisation of the veterinary system, which, in my opinion, may be counter to the chances of joint action. I ask, then, what danger do you think there is of devolution?

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – It is precisely me, my dear colleague, that I come from one of the most decentralized countries in the European Union, which is Spain, and there are no more problems with decentralised. What has to be there is organization.  If things work well, if they are decentralized but function properly in the chain, there need not be problems. What I am advocating and what the Government of Spain is also advocating is for having an agile system that allows the European Commission to tackle diseases which, as we have seen in some cases, as in the case of annoying xylella, have made it impossible for us to react to deal with these cases which have occurred in the European Union recently.  Thus, decentralization would not have to be a problem. The problem is disorganization.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the inadequate use of therapeutic antimicrobials in veterinary medicine, their use for non-therapeutic purposes and environmental pollution have accelerated the appearance and propagation of resistant microorganisms, with serious consequences for animal and human health. The actions taken failed to contain the growing risk of antimicrobial resistance.  It is necessary to strengthen the measures currently in force and to adopt a new set of stricter measures, in particular, on the prevention of antimicrobial infections, in order to reduce the pressure exerted on the use of antimicrobials and to prevent their greater spread.  Member States must engage in the collection of relevant, comparable and sufficiently detailed data on the actual use of antimicrobial medicines in animals and transmit them to the Commission, so as to allow policies to encourage more prudent use in animals and thus to reduce the risk of antimicrobial resistance.  It would be desirable for the Commission to undertake to publish periodically a report on the use of antimicrobial medicines in the treatment of animals in the European Union on the basis of data obtained from individual Member States.

name: James Nicholson (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the regulation of veterinary medicines is important to ensure their safety, quality and effectiveness and therefore protect animal health, public health, food safety and the environment. I recently met with the local chief veterinary officer in my own region of Northern Ireland as well as local representatives of the British Veterinary Association to discuss the wide range of issues relating to animal health, including potential problems ahead in terms of antimicrobial resistance as well as concerns about bovine tuberculosis in my own constituency. The European animal health law will consolidate 40 different pieces of outdated and often inconsistent European legislation in this field and gives a comprehensive framework for animal health in the next 20 years. We need an approach to animal health legislation that has strong focus on outcomes, regulatory simplicity and flexibility in the management of disease. This simplification and harmonisation of legislation is a good example of better regulation and an important drive away from red tape and burdensome bureaucracy. I would also like to address the rapporteur and pay tribute to Marit Paulsen as well. Unfortunately, she is no longer with us, but she was an extremely valued member of the Agriculture Committee. Maybe you would send her the message that we still miss her, and hopefully this will be a tribute to what she has been fighting for for so long.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I hope that I will also get so much tolerance if, like your group colleague, I am going to go so far over. According to a study in recent years, the number of antibiotics used in animal husbandry is expected to increase worldwide to around 130,000 tonnes by 2030. On the other hand, the trend of antibiotic allocation within the Union is, thankFully, declining. It is therefore right to encourage our domestic agriculture to use medicines in animal husbandry in a responsible and careful manner. However, it is much more important to raise the issue of the use of antibiotics in trade agreements as well. In the Usa, for example, according to a report in the Neue Zürcher Zeitung, the use of medicines in animal production is increasing very sharply.  Food safety and health protection require a global approach by the Union. Our consumers do not want meat contaminated by pharmaceutical cocktails – not even through the TTIP back door.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Mr President, animal health is closely linked both to the way we breed them and to the way we treat them. In this way we succeed in controlling the quality of feed but also in identifying, preventing and treating diseases that are transmitted to them and then transmitted to consumers through the products they eat (meat, milk and cheese). The globalisation of trade and climate change pose serious risks to both animal and consumer health, which is why the European Union should simplify, intensify controls on animals imported from non-European Union countries, so as to ensure food safety, but at the same time not to transmit diseases to consumers.  For the necessity of this, I would like to take as an example my country, Greece, where sheep and goats are often smuggled, mainly from Turkey but also from Skopje, which have not undergone the controls provided for, and therefore pose a risk to the health of domestic breeds of animals and also to consumers. On the contrary, those exported from Greece are guaranteed.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: Mr. President, congratulations to Mr. Selimovic on this report. I must point out that animal health is important for the safety of EUROPEAN Union citizens and we are concerned about the increasing prevalence of bacterial resistance to antibiotics, which has recently posed an increasing public health and safety risk. Excessive use of antimicrobial drugs contributes to the accelerated appearance of new strains of bacteria resistant to new antibiotics. Excessive use of antimicrobials is harmful to the health of animals and humans, but also to consumers' perception of the food they use.  Europe prides itself on a high level of food quality and safety and high standards of animal care thanks to our hardworking farmers. It defends these high standards in international negotiations on international trade agreements. It is this Regulation that is the answer to the widespread and unwise use of antimicrobials in veterinary medicine. It adopts measures such as the collection of relevant, comparable and sufficiently detailed data on the use of antimicrobial medical devices in animals in the Member States. These measures are necessary to make the use of these funds more prudent and to contribute to reducing the risk of antimicrobial resistance. Animal owners are invited in the breeding process to stick to the principle of good master and apply drugs responsibly and under supervision.  This Regulation also has a public health dimension, as, in addition to caring for animal health and welfare, and due to the reasonable and measured use of antimicrobials in veterinary medicine, according to commission estimates, it will directly affect 25 million people.  (Speaker agreed to answer the question "blue card" (Article 162(8) of the E.S. Regulation))

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, thank you for accepting my question. Mrs Petir, you are rightly pointing out that it is important to combat the excessive consumption of antibiotics. However, is it not the Union's agricultural policy that encourages this drift? Indeed, it has done everything to transform traditional agriculture into an agricultural industry. This has led to the creation of giant farms, in which livestock are confined. As a result, the risk of disease increases, antibiotics are forced to multiply and this causes a danger to human health. So isn't this report on animal health really an alibi to raise awareness and hide this terrible failure of the Union's agricultural policy?

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. - The Common Agricultural Policy is the longest-term and most successful policy of the European Union. Therefore, I cannot agree with your statement. In addition, our farmers use antibiotics in a reasonable way, and this Regulation will contribute to continuing to do so. Europe must remain competitive in food quality, and this is confirmed by our inter-trade partners that we really boast about the quality of food produced in European countries. Therefore, if we want to keep this level we must also use antibiotics in a smart way.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to express my satisfaction that, almost two years after the first reading of this House on this Regulation, we will come to your debate today and hope that tomorrow for final approval. In my opinion, this Regulation is one of the most important, after the new reform of the CAP, because it concerns animal health, which is a very substantive element in our livestock, and, of course, for imports and exports. I would like to join in congratulating Mrs Paulsen, who is no longer with us, and Mr Selimovic on the success of this Regulation.  I would also like to remind colleagues of one issue: concern about antibiotic resistance is a concern of all, but there are more regulations that will regulate it, such as veterinary medicines or drug feed, which will soon also be debated.  Finally, I want to say that it is legislation that has very important aspects, such as the prioritization of diseases and health medicine or the regulation of traceability.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I wholeheartedly support the new Animal Health Act. It is a step in the right direction for food safety.  Antibiotic resistance has become a matter of destiny for human health. Many consumers are concerned about the residue of medicines in animals when they eat meat. I welcome the fact that the legislation links animal health and human health and that the focus is on preventing infectious diseases in animals instead of curing animals that are sick.  It is also important to simplify the rules and focus on measures to reduce the use of antibiotics and treat only those animals that are sick. Uniform and fair use of medicines is also important for our farmers to compete on an equal footing. Mr President, it seems it is time for all Member States to make responsible use of medicines for animals. (The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Albert Deß (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her report, We have a very strict application and documentation obligation in veterinary medicine. I would like to ask you: do you agree with me that this strict obligation to use and document should also be extended to human medicine, where far more antibiotics are consumed than in veterinary medicine?

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, as I said, many people are really concerned about the excessive use of antibiotics, both in animals and in human beings. This regulation is about animals, but the link has finally been clearly made, based on science, that it can be transferred. The antibiotics and the medicines that are given to animals can be transferred to human beings. That is why it is so important.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the animal health strategy should contribute to the prevention and control of animal diseases, with particular attention to antimicrobial resistance. This is a public health issue, given the frequency of the same diseases in animals and humans and the hypothetical transmission of antimicrobial resistance between animals and humans, recently corroborated by a study conducted in China and published in late 2015 in the highly regarded journal The Lancet. The way in which this issue is addressed in practice should take into account the specificities of production in different regions of Europe, especially with regard to weather conditions that promote the occurrence and transmission of diseases. On the other hand, the conditions imposed on European producers on animal health should be taken into account in trade negotiations with third countries.

name: Paul Brannen (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the animal health law that we will vote on tomorrow responds to at least two concerns often submitted by constituents to Members of the European Parliament. Firstly, improving the general welfare of animals through enhanced animal health measures and secondly, the issue of stray animals.  On the first of these, animal diseases: just like human diseases, they do not recognise borders. Britain is no less at risk of any significant animal disease outbreak than any other European country and we clearly need a strong European framework to react, to respect common rules in case of disease outbreak. On the second issue, controlling diseases amongst the populations of stray animals: no less important and requires both a clear assignment of responsibility from the national authorities as well as a requirement of humane treatment of stray animals.  This law will see the European Union delivering on animal health and on animal welfare, which is why staying in the European Union is good for animals just as it is good for people. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr Brannen, I really wanted to ask you a question, because I really liked what you presented, namely the problem of stray dogs. This is the key point, in my opinion, and we probably all have our own experiences. My question is: would you see how to manage health in stray dogs? Would you suggest, in the report, how to do this? Because, really, I think that's the problem here, not in dogs that have a owner and understand to treat their dogs. Thank you very much.

name: Paul Brannen (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – It is a good question. Obviously, dogs are unaware of the Schengen arrangements and are therefore entirely likely to cross borders at will where border fences do not exist, and that is the case across the European Union. I therefore think the key thing here is that we need to work together, country by country, across the European Union, because if countries individually try to deal with stray dogs they will not be successful. Only by working together, which is clearly obvious at a European level, can we deal with the issue of stray animals and associated diseases.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Although some colleagues in the previous debate denied that health policy is a European matter, this discussion has clearly shown that health policy is clearly shared policy of the Member States, shared responsibility of the Member States and of the European Union. Because we cannot share health policy between the Member States, but we must tackle it together, whether it concerns humans or animals. And here this health package for animals – the prevention of epidemics, of disease transmission – has clearly shown that we can only fight together here, that we need this cohesion at European level. Animal health presupposes that we have a functioning animal welfare system, presupposes that we have good animal husbandry practices, that must be monitored, that must be monitored and for which we need common legislation. We need common European rules on the use of medicines and veterinary medicinal products. Because all these products and animals are moving across the European Union, and we want to leave that that in the future. A public safety issue, a public health issue, will be effective animal welfare, and will be effective animal health.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, in order to ensure a high level of public health and food safety, measures to prevent and reduce the effects of animal diseases should first be increased. In other words, all Member States of the Union should promote livestock farming and animal welfare practices in order to reduce any threats to public health. In addition, the different types of surveillance carried out by groups active in the field of animal health should be better used in order to make more efficient use of resources.  Finally, there should be a simplified legislative framework in the European Union for the protection of animal health, public health and animal welfare, and this means, among other things, a reduction in the use of antibiotics in livestock farming, the use of appropriate feed and control of the import of animals, especially sheep from Turkey and Skopje, where animal diseases are widespread and where there are insufficient animal health controls. In fact, sheep diseases from Turkey have spread to Evros and other parts of Greece, resulting in the damage suffered by the poor Greek farmers who will have to be immediately compensated and receive the financial support of the European Union.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, animal diseases that harm animal welfare and can, of course, harm human health. Once a mad cow disease, bird flu, today swine fever certainly endangers the animals themselves, but they also threaten human health. That's why I think this regulation, which we want to enact, is a good regulation that works a good balance between what animal welfare means, but especially what human health means. I want to believe that under this regulation we will have far more efficient and better regulation and animal health, and in particular our health, and that is why I believe that the Commission needs to do everything to make these rules live within the EU as soon as possible, and in particular this needs to be done with our partners from whom we import various animal products.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, today, with the increasing mobility of people, animals and food, the risk of emergencies and zoonoses that have been controlled until now is increasing — look at the situation of classical swine fever or African swine fever, which is once again present on the European continent. It is regrettable that, in this period, the European Union has reduced by about 10% the funds available for the fight against and eradication of these animal diseases, when an effort to meet the challenges of globalisation would be expected. Good words are always welcome, but good intentions are hell full.  At the moment when intensive agriculture is being promoted and we are trying to level down all the standards of food safety and well-being in the framework of the TTIP, it would be good that all these guidelines that we are debating here could actually serve something and that this debate is not just another empty initiative of meaning and totally inconsequential.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, if President Obama has made antibiotic resistance one of his priorities for the parliamentary term, it is very important that we, too, respond to this fact. That we are aware of the very significant risk of acquiring antibiotic resistance when it comes to animal husbandry and not just when it comes to animal husbandry. Also regarding, of course, the consumption of products derived from these animals.  One statistic should be remembered. By 2050, more than 130,000 tonnes of antibiotics are expected to be consumed across the board. That's almost 4,000 tons of antibiotics a year. This figure really threatens food safety, consumer rights, but also, of course, animal rights. I am glad that this has been said here in this discussion. We must therefore protect not only food safety, the environment, but indeed the rights of individual consumers, which are indeed threatened by this blanket use of antibiotic products.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the Animal Health Act is an important law. For the first time, it binds animal and human health together. This is looking to the future. Animal-to-animal and human-transmitted epidemics are one of the key safety threats of the 21st century. There is a great deal of good in Mr Selimovic's work, which I would like to highlight in particular responsible animal medication. Excessive use of antibiotics is short-sighted and dangerous. Fortunately, awareness of the risks associated with antibiotics is growing. I hope that this will also be taken into account in future legislative work.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, once again I would like to express my gratitude to the rapporteurs, Madam Paulsen and Mr Selimović, the shadow rapporteurs, and their team for their excellent and tireless work.  I have listened to the views of this House with close attention. The various points illustrate the very strong interest of the honourable Members in this legislative initiative. Some of you mentioned the economic situation, and the Commission is aware about today’s economic situation which, in some cases, will damage animal health issues. Some of you raised questions about stray dogs: the European Parliament recently adopted a resolution calling upon the Commission to adopt rules for the compulsory identification and registration of dogs and cats and some other animals commonly used as pets. The new animal health law is a legal framework and contains basic rules, including those for the identification and registration of animals. It provides more specific rules only for those animal species where the identification and registration rules exist at present. However, the regulation also provides for the possibility to lay down further detailed requirements for the identification and registration of animals of other species such as dogs, cats, and so on, for which specific requirements do not exist at present. The necessity of such future rules will be assessed by the Commission in the course of the years following the adoption of animal health law, and then delegated and implementing acts will be prepared. The Commission is committed to animal welfare and considers it a very important issue, as you just raised in the discussions. However, the scope of this regulation focuses on the transmissible animal diseases and does not directly regulate animal welfare. A number of compromise solutions were found during the trialogue negotiations to clarify the relation between animal health and animal welfare and to address the concerns of the Parliament on animal welfare. It was not always easy to agree to all of them; nonetheless, the Commission understands the importance of animal welfare for the European Parliament and has therefore made a statement confirming its commitment to animal welfare. The Union has a well-developed acquis regarding animal welfare, covering different species (broilers, laying hens, pigs, calves) or activities (farming, transport, slaughter, research, etc.). This animal welfare legislation will necessarily continue to apply.  Some mentioned antimicrobial resistance. Antimicrobial resistance is very important to me, therefore issues of antimicrobial resistance were always included in the Commission’s proposal on animal health. This, together with the future legislation on veterinary medicines and medicated feed, will provide solid grounds to address this issue. Finally, the Commission has also made the statement, ‘The Commission undertakes to publish a regular report as regards the use of antimicrobial medicinal products in animals in the EU on the basis of data made available by the Member States.’ Let me finish by expressing my sincere hope for the support of Parliament for an early second reading agreement on this file, which would pave the way for its multiple benefits to come to fruition as early as possible.

name: Jasenko Selimovic
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for your support and comments. Let me just stress once again how important this agreement is. This is therefore the first time that a European law has established the link between animal welfare, animal health and public health. The new law will give us better preparedness and better tools to deal with serious outbreaks of disease in the future. There is a great deal of suffering both in humans and in animals that can thus be avoided and, to mention it too, large amounts that can be saved for society in the form of reduced health care costs. Money that in these times may be needed for other things. The law, if adopted tomorrow, will be an important step in the fight against antibiotic resistance both in humans and in animals and in our environment. I would also like to mention that it is very gratifying that a whole range of key organisations have supported the law, from the European Veterinary Association to the Copa-Cogeca, the European animal welfare movement and many others who have supported this law, which shows the breadth of our agreement. I sincerely hope that tomorrow Parliament will embrace this law with a broad agreement. I would like to thank you for your good cooperation, both the shadow rapporteur, the Commissioner and the Commission, the Council and all the rest of you who have contributed to the work on this law.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Tuesday 8 March 2016.  (The meeting was temporarily suspended.) Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The protection of animal health at every stage of the food production process is a priority for the health of the citizens of the European Union. The 'Animal Health Law' developed by the European Parliament and the Council, bringing together nearly 40 pieces of legislation, will allow for comprehensive, uniform, flexible and transparent animal welfare legislation. The relationship between animal health (welfare) and public health and food security is indisputable. Health protection at all stages of food production from farming to consumption should be ensured, food contamination should be prevented and food hygiene requirements improved. This is the only way to maintain food security in the European Union and in third countries and to ensure that people have sufficient access to safe, high-quality food.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. – This bill deals with animal diseases and animal health. That is why I would like to stress: this is not an animal welfare law! A new animal welfare strategy is still desperately needed and I still expect a proposal for a Framework Law on Animal Welfare from the Commission!  Fortunately, the proposal stipulates that pain, stress and suffering in animals should be avoided in the implementation of animal health regulations. This legislation also introduces a mandatory registration of professional breeders and sellers of dogs. In this way, we can tackle the illegal puppy trade, which now leads to countless harrowing examples of animal cruelty. There are still "puppy mills" where puppies are illegally and unvaccinated on the assembly line. This has to stop! Proper identification and registration can help.  However, a major sticking point of the law remains the difference between loved animals and wild animals. Stray animals and runaway animals fall within the definition of wild animals; as a result, the presence of the owner or caretaker of an animal determines the degree of protection against diseases (such as vaccination) and against disease control measures. It was never intended that healthy stray animals should be killed "preventively" under the guise of disease management measures.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the report by Knut Fleckenstein, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for access to the market for port services and financial transparency of ports (COM(2013) )0296 – C7-0144/2013 – 2013/0157(COD)) (A8-0023/2016)

name: Knut Fleckenstein
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Since the beginning of the debate on Port Package 1 15 years ago, there has been – and rightly so in my opinion – in this House, no majority in favour of the port package.  I am convinced that today's draft is better and that it can be approved, because it is very different from the previous port packages. Approval and a mandate for negotiation in the Council are possible because the draft no longer abuses the desire for competitiveness for radical market ideologies.  The focus is no longer on the forced opening of markets – at whatever cost – but on the better organisation of ports, even with a limitation of port service providers where it is necessary and sensible.  Today's draft is about strengthening competitiveness, about greater transparency, about the autonomy of ports, about better information and involving port users, in order to provide serious but unbureaucratic supervision in the sense of a complaints body. Strengthening competitiveness also means that there are good jobs in ports. In the 21st century, there should be no more day labor work in our ports.  I know that these issues cannot be resolved by the regulation. But a hint for those who could regulate it is necessary and useful. This relates to training and training, to working time models that could be developed to enable better and better jobs. Today's solution was possible because, unlike her predecessors, Commissioner Bulc took a very cooperative and pragmatic approach. It has also become possible because we have spoken to many stakeholders, some of them on the ground. Of course, we have not been able to convince everyone. British ports say that because they are private ports, they are not affected – unlike the private ports on the continent. The Polish terminal operators are against this because too much transparency is not easy for them to discuss. European shipowners are rightly unenthusiastic, because their dream that Filipino sailors will be able to load and unload the ships themselves in ports in the future has finally been dreamed up with tomorrow's vote.  We will start negotiations with the Council quickly if the plenary decides tomorrow. But there will only be a successful conclusion if both sides – including the Council – move in terms of content and if Commissioner Vestager joins in with a sensible draft on the block exemptions in the context of the debate on state aid to ports. We will also examine them intensively. I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their constructive support, the Commissioner for the pragmatic approach she has chosen and from stakeholders from all sides – a thank you, because the will to achieve a good result was evident. I know that we have not been able to satisfy everyone. However, I am presenting this report today with the firm conviction that this is a good compromise, which I would ask tomorrow to adopt.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission welcomes the report that we will discuss today. I sincerely thank the rapporteur, Mr Fleckenstein, for the important and future-oriented work he has accomplished. Thank you also to the shadow rapporteurs and the Committee on Transport and Tourism for the good quality of the report. The port services regulation is an important piece of the European transport policy to foster investment and push further modernisation of ports. You know about the crucial role of ports for the transport system and our economy. They are Europe’s gateways to the world. They provide employment in ports directly and in related sectors. They are hubs for short-sea shipping which we must strengthen as part of our decarbonisation strategy. In short, ports are valuable assets which we must preserve and strengthen. That is what the regulation aims at and that is why it is one of the Commission’s priority files for 2016. The regulation will ensure transparency in the use of public funds in ports. We need to ensure a level playing field between European ports, many of which receive considerable financial support from both national and EU budgets. Financial transparency is crucial for this. Financial transparency will also allow us to simplify the application of state aid rules. The Commission is working on the general block exemption regulation; it should exempt certain port investments from state aid rules and focus the Commission’s work on critical cases in order to establish a genuine level playing field. A first draft, proposed, was published today for consultation. And today the public consultation has started. The port services regulation will provide an important input into this work, provided it gets your support. The port services regulation will also bring more clarity for the organisation and tendering of port services. It will end today’s unclear situation where ports policy is not decided by the legislator but defined on a case-by-case basis by the European Court of Justice, only according to the Treaty principles. The adoption of the regulation will therefore mean more legal clarity and legal stability for both port workers and investors. The regulation is also important for our decarbonisation strategy, which after COP21 we are even more committed to. Making ports more attractive is essential to developing alternatives to congested motorways and avoiding unnecessary land and sea traffic. We need to diversify maritime routes and promote short-sea shipping. The report got broad support in the Committee on Transport and Tourism. All major organisations representing the European port sector stand behind it: the trade unions, port authorities, port terminal operators and port service providers. Let me stress that the Commission fully supports the social dialogue as well as better training and safety for workers. Let me also stress that the regulation does not impose a one-size-fits-all approach. We know that every port in Europe is different. The draft regulation respects this. It is compatible with all forms of organisations, including private ports. It does not impose one model. Your vote tomorrow, to start the trilogues, is essential for advancing with this important piece of legislation. The Council already adopted a general approach in 2014. This was one of the major successes of the Italian Presidency. It is time for Parliament to enter into negotiations with the Council and conclude this file. The Dutch Presidency is very interested in negotiating and concluding the file still before summer. I am inviting you all not to lose this opportunity.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, ports are undoubtedly one of the most important levers of economic growth but also a source of prosperity for the Member States and Europe. It is no coincidence that 75% of the European Union's trade and 38% of intra-Community trade are carried out by sea, which indicates the importance of the sector.  That is why the regulation that we will be voting on in plenary aims to enhance the performance of European ports and improve the overall quality of port services with a view to modernising them. It also creates conditions of fairer competition, reduces legal ambiguities, strengthens transparency and better allocation of public resources. Only the creation of a stable legal environment governed by a fair playing field and specific transparency rules can attract investment in ports, contributing to the development of the European Union economy, particularly in times of economic crisis.  At the same time, the new legislation gives ports greater autonomy over the definition of port charges. This strengthens competition both between European ports and between European Union ports with third countries. In addition, it provides for a number of favourable provisions for small ports in order to avoid a disproportionate administrative burden and additional fees and costs. Europe needs such legislative initiatives that highlight common interests between Member States and strengthen the single internal market.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr President, dear colleague, i also appreciate that this is an extremely important report, as the Commissioner also told us. I would specifically ask a question. It did not come out of your opinion. The difference between what the Commission has proposed and what the rapporteurs propose in connection with the setting of taxes in ports. Do you think it is good as is now foreseen in the report: the abolition of the Commission's proposal to set up a committee with the representatives of the operators to determine the level of fees, or would it be better to set the ports themselves the fees for operators?

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη (
text: PPE), answer to a question with a blue card – Thank you very much for the question. I will tell you that our text is perfectly balanced precisely in the area you have raised, because it also provides for a fair distribution of fees and costs for the smaller ports, which have so far had a burden.  I answer your question that the text also sees this parameter fully, and indeed with balanced amendments, which were made after many discussions between the political groups.

name: Lucy Anderson
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, there over 300 ports in our European network, even leaving aside the very small ones, and more than three million jobs depend on the port sector directly or indirectly. Especially given the diversity in size, operations and governance of EU ports, we should only regulate this sector with the utmost care.  Now, I should say that I am not saying this on behalf of the S&D, but I and other Labour MEPs are not opposed to the idea of progressive balanced EU measures on ports. These could help improve standards in the sector, in the UK and across the whole of Europe, on port safety and security, terms and conditions of workers, environmental protection, as well as provide a secure framework for investment.  The problem is that, despite the commendable efforts of our rapporteur, this proposal, even if amended as he suggests, simply does not quite achieve the goals that I have mentioned. There are good provisions on training. There are good provisions encouraging good practice on minimum requirements on tendering, but it is not enough overall.  The draft regulation is in fact an example of the spectacular double standards of the so-called better regulation agenda; for instance, the provisions to regulate port charges will undoubtedly still be an administrative burden for ports and do not give legal clarity if you read them carefully – you are still asking yourself questions about what they mean. They are also unsupported by concrete evidence from the Commission of major problems in charging practices in many ports and the report by PwC – the management consultancy report that looked into this – did not uncover major problems.  There has also been no updated impact assessment since at least 2012 despite the new institutional agreement on better regulation saying that these things should be updated. Equally the right for trade unions to take legitimate industrial action is not sufficiently protected in Article 8 and Article 10 fails to provide for the compulsory transfer of staff. We were looking for something that improved workers’ rights, including in relation to how agency workers are dealt with, but it is just not there.  Ports will not specifically also be required to consult environmental experts and local communities.  So in overall terms, please reject the Commission’s proposal.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Ms Anderson, you mentioned something about your doubts concerning social issues. To what extent are you not satisfied with the social package in this Commission bill? Second, what is your opinion of European added value concerning this particular bill?

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Well, in terms of the social elements, much more could have been done within the articles to reinforce the importance of that issue – for example to mention the social dialogue. Although the social dialogue stakeholders think that this could have been worse and they say that overall it could be negotiated on, they are still not entirely happy. If you look at their previous positions about what they wanted, this is not what they wanted and they could quite happily live without it. I think there are very real concerns on that.  In terms of the European added value, at least we are talking about the issues and that raises awareness, but I think that is as far as it goes.

name: Peter van Dalen
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Firstly, my heartfelt congratulations to rapporteur Fleckenstein. He stuck his neck out and got to work realistically. As a result, the PPE, ALDE and ECR Group have now achieved an excellent result with the rapporteur. I am thinking of the following points: firstly, less bureaucracy and less social burden on ports. Initially, the proposal was full of social provisions, such as the requirement that port companies should provide training and training to port workers. But many port companies are not about that at all. That is rightly out now. Secondly, ports now decide for themselves how they want to be organised. Mandatory market access is no longer an issue. Europe is now in line with the situation in the regions in the Member States, not the other way around. Port companies decide for themselves how they want to be organized, and rightly so. The situation in Rotterdam is very different from, for example, in Vigo, Spain. Subsidiarity and sovereignty have really come into their own. Thirdly, there is an exception for private ports. We have taken extra account of the situation of the British private ports and they can now arrange services themselves, such as towing or mooring ships. They also do not have to go through complicated procurement procedures, so that too is very nice. Some here are calling for the proposal to be rejected. That would be very stupid. It is stupid, because the Directorate-General for Competition will come around and Commissioner Vestager will have the provisions on competition also apply to ports. Well, then we'll be a long way from home until that bag of tricks is pulled open. It would therefore be very unwise to reject this and I call on everyone, including in my own group, to support this proposal.

name: Gesine Meissner
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. Thank you, above all, to Knut Fleckenstein as rapporteur. Ports in Europe are different. We have already noticed this, and it makes it so terribly difficult to get a suitable port package. This is the third attempt, and I hope that this time it will really work. It is perhaps quite nice that I can now speak about S&D and ECR, because we have already noticed how different the positions we have been arguing about are also natural with us. The S&D said that too little attention has been paid to social matters, too little attention has been paid to workers' rights. The ECR said that there is actually too much of it. That is why I have to say that this shows that the rapporteur has reached a really very good compromise. It is, of course, the case that no one is 100% satisfied with a compromise. Even here, the Liberals, some are not entirely enthusiastic, because there are exceptions that come out of this regulation. The fact that not all services are covered, that handling services and pilots are taken out, that smugglers and moorings have special clauses – these are all things that we would not have liked to have had. But it is now the case that we think it really is a compromise, something that is a viable way to move forward. In my view, something is very important: press releases have of course been issued in advance, and both the port operators and the port trade unionists are in favour of this compromise and ask all of us to agree to this here in plenary, so that we can continue to negotiate and thus for the ports, which are really hugely important for Europe and for future flows of goods – we want to stay on the pulse of the times. , really have semi-uniform rules, have transparency about financial flows, in some areas a bit more competition, but very good conditions also for the workers, and then also incentives for investors to really invest in the ports. All this is entirely guaranteed. I know that it was difficult because the Commission's proposal and what the rapporteur initially had did not really fit together. Now we really have a middle position, and I can only encourage all those who are still thinking about voting against it at the moment: there is a whole lot in it, no one can have anything. And I think that what we have now should be negotiated with the Council, in the interests of the ports and in the interests of Europe.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, it is good that we have managed to set a specific operating framework. The scope of the Regulation was limited to the organisation of ports and the transparency of financial transactions. There are no regulations on deregulation of industrial relations and uncontrolled market opening. Many stakeholders and most trade unions supported our work. We have managed to distance the result from the Commission's original objectives.  On this basis, the proposal to be negotiated with the Council provides good protection for workers in safety and health matters, strengthens the right to education and training and will act as an embankment in the face of further attacks on working conditions. It provides for the environmental sustainability of port services, all in conditions of transparency. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work. I urge you to vote in favour of the compromise amendments, adopted in blocks, and to give Mr. Fleckenstein the mandate to open negotiations with the Council and the Commission. Now Member States and governments must demonstrate their readiness for strong commitments against social dumping and in favour of defending safe working conditions at ports.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – I see what you are saying about how full market liberalisation is no longer in this measure but, nevertheless, it does have detailed and prescriptive rules for ports to follow on contracts with service providers and public service obligations. Your Group in particular is often very keen to protect public services. Do you not think that to present it simply as a harmless transparency measure is maybe slightly misleading?

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (
text: GUE/NGL), answer to a blue card question – I do not believe there is an attempt to mislead Parliament. I believe that there are good and bad compromises, and here we are dealing with a good, decent compromise, which defends basic rights.

name: Keith Taylor
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, following two fairly spectacular failed attempts at liberalising port service provisions, the Commission has greatly scaled down its ambitions on services in an attempt to finally create a sector-specific legislation in this area. However, yet again, the port services regulation has failed to tackle the real issues in Europe’s ports.  It is clear that maritime transport, to which ports are vital, plays a crucial role in achieving greater sustainability in the transport sector. The Greens’ political objective is to embed seaports into the wider framework of a sustainable transport policy that addresses safety, social and environmental standards, incorporates cross-border cooperation and coordination between seaports and aims to account for external costs.  There is also no doubt that public finance needs transparency. We cannot talk about port services without looking at the public money flowing into the ports for their infrastructure and operations. The port services regulation could have facilitated some of those aims. Unfortunately it seems clearly to fail to meet its own objectives of ensuring a more sustainable and interconnected transport network. On financial transparency, the one valid point it does contain, it still does not do enough to ensure much needed legal certainty for the sector due to the strong link between financial transparency and the Commission’s envisaged state-aid guidelines and/or block exemptions for the ports. Both proposals should have been developed in parallel. Having first announced this initiative some 11 years ago, the Commission’s news that it will not now adopt state-aid guidelines before 2017 is frustrating but somehow unsurprising.  If Parliament accepts this report it needs to be prepared for some serious criticism, having backed a piece of binding legislation that does very little to tackle anything at all. This legislation is undeveloped and ineffective, and I therefore call upon Members to reject this report when they have the opportunity to vote tomorrow. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Do you agree with me that this package, although improved, presents some of the same dangers as the proposals rejected by Parliament by a big majority in 2006? It imposes additional administrative burdens on our ports, whilst not ensuring adequate protection for fundamental rights or safety at work.

name: Keith Taylor (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – I think you are entirely correct in making that assumption, and do not forget that Parliament has rejected these proposals, or something very similar, twice before. There is no recognition of environmental requirements – all the references to environmental assessment, bird life, habitat, Natura 2000, etc., were deleted. This is just a failed attempt to push on to Parliament another unwelcome version of basically the same thing, and we should say the same: ‘No’.

name: Jill Seymour
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the port services regulation is not required or wanted in the United Kingdom. Unlike most of continental Europe, the UK has very competitive ports, with the lion’s share in the private sector. The EU has tried to regulate ports without success on two previous occasions and this is the third attempt. As the majority of ports in the UK are privately owned, successful and efficient, it is not for the EU to regulate British ports. With the Brexit referendum on 23 June, the people of the United Kingdom will vote to leave and we will free ourselves from the excessive rules, regulations and red tape imposed by this place. We will then rejoin the rest of the world and take back our freedom to run and operate our own businesses. Britain has a long and proud history trading with the world and our ports are the doors to our prosperity. This port service regulation will do more harm than good, and the UK will be better off out.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the liberalisation of port services is an old European sea snake. Although the European Commission has already suffered two failures in the early 2000s, it is back in charge: never two without three. The commission's proposal is unacceptable. On the one hand, it tries to standardise the major European ports, which have different organisations, effectively preventing Member States and port managers from framing these services based on experience. On the other hand, under the pretext of competitiveness and with a view to attracting more investment, it emphasizes the need to liberalise certain services. This would have the negative effect of preventing States from requiring certain services to be performed under the national flag for security reasons. Replacing qualified sailors, pilots or tugs with under-qualified persons, underpaid because they are employed on a flag of convenience vessel, is not an option. The amendments of the Committee on Transport are positive, but at the end of the day, this regulation will be an empty shell. So why would you want to continue to harmonize and privatize at all costs? Do we want our ports, strategic elements of our economy, to be bought out little by little by foreign investors, as was the case recently in Piraeus, taken over by the Chinese group Cosco? For these reasons, we will vote against the Commission's proposal and against the European Parliament's proposal.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the subject has been and is still being hotly debated. There are diverse and divergent views on some provisions. An encouraging compromise has, however, been reached: the regulation will enable job creation, development and increased competitiveness of the important economic sector formed by ports; allows autonomy in setting tariffs, creating better conditions for competition and better quality services at affordable prices; introduces financial transparency, ensuring equal conditions for all actors and means of combating illegal state aid. The regulation will apply to all ports included in TNT. Member States, however, have the flexibility not to include ports in the global network in peripheral regions. Small ports have flexibility in avoiding red tape and disproportionate costs in order to strengthen the efficiency and quality of services. The economic situation and competition in the sector require a decision that has been discussed for more than ten years. Negotiation with the Council is necessary and may lead to the elimination of the current controversy.

name: Ismail Ertug (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Fleckenstein, for the difficult work he has put behind him. It should not be forgotten that we were dealing with a proposal from the European Commission from the so-called Kallas era, which aimed at turbo liberalisation in all areas. In this respect, it was all the more difficult for the rapporteur to find a compromise. As the name suggests, a compromise is not 100% what everyone wants. Nevertheless, we must be prepared to compromise. If we now look at this paper that is on the table, we see that the forced liberalisation that should have come in the original version of the European Commission has been prevented. If we go within ourselves, we see that the ports can now decide for themselves how they want to offer their port services. What, for me personally, was the main argument for ultimately agreeing to are the so-called minimum requirements that the rapporteur has negotiated, minimum requirements, for example, for the withdrawal of so-called good reputes in the event of non-compliance with social and labour standards. The fact that the right to strike has also been negotiated in a binding manner is a win. Because I remember many other dossiers where we did not succeed. If we look at the merits, or at least what has come out of the area of transparency, we can summarise all these points and conclude that, if I may say so, the glass is half full and not half empty and, in that respect, agreement is perfectly fine.

name: Jacqueline Foster (ECR).
