text: – Mr President, first of all I would genuinely like to thank Mr Fleckenstein for his hard work, enduring work, on this dossier, but regrettably I do not believe that the changes have gone far enough.  It was actually a Conservative government in 1981 that began the process of privatising the ports in the United Kingdom, and therefore I will not support anything that would jeopardise the success that this has brought to the UK economy and on growth and jobs. I would also just like to assure an earlier speaker that we are not inundated with thousands of Philippino workers who are loading and unloading our ships.  Both Conservatives and our Polish colleagues and others will support a rejection of this Commission proposal. We believe that competition between ports rather than prescriptive regulation on ports’ internal operations is a greater driver for efficiency. The Commission’s proposal was overly-bureaucratic and does not fit well in our UK system of privatised and market-driven ports. Whilst we welcome some improvements in the Committee position, I am fully aware that both our UK port owners and trade unions remain firmly opposed to the proposal as it stands.  The present text could still interpret the open port duty in the UK as imposing public service obligations on private ports whilst we believe that the proposal on private and trust ports does not go far enough to guarantee their exemption from the regulation. Moreover, it is feared that the social provisions introduced by the rapporteur and others would gold—plate existing EU legislation dealing with the transfer of staff due to a change in the service provider as well as current ILO training and labour protection guidelines.  In addition, we are disappointed that the rapporteur’s compromise package did not include smaller ports from the provisions on market opening. It is for these reasons that I have re—submitted amendments which would exempt small ports from the regulation as well as amendments reflecting competitive market exemption in order to allow a fully competitive industry to be free to procure goods and services commercially, and lastly, an amendment which would exclude all private ports from the regulation. I hope they will have majority support, although my preference will be to reject the report.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, some colleagues have said that they are not entirely happy, and I need to say that nor am I – I think that many of us would not be. But the question is, what are the options? What we clearly know is that we need better access to ports, and we need better management, and for me that means we need better organisation. The question is also whether we, for another period of time, should ask public and private stakeholders to stay in legal uncertainty. So while I am not entirely happy with the proposal, and there are definitely issues that have to be addressed, I believe it is high time to submit the proposal for negotiations and do the fine-tuning during the negotiations. Sometimes, less is more. That is why, with this strong message, I will skip my time and give you five seconds extra. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Now I have got my colleague in trouble because he was almost gone. Yes, mr Teliska, it has now been just five seconds less, but I still have one question: it has been said on several occasions that there is too little transparency here, that too little flexibility is possible for the Member States, that too little attention has been paid to the fact that ports are very different, that too little has been done to allow private ports to take private decisions. How do you feel about this? Is it really too little flexible and too little transparent and all this?

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – She might have done it on purpose because she knows that I am late for a meeting! I need to say that I see an improvement, definitely. I think that this is the degree to which I can subscribe to it. The question is what is in it that is not sufficient? I am sure that some of the elements are yet to be addressed, but I am sure that with good, solid effort we can make it happen. I would have a number of other issues, but for me the progress so far in comparison to the previous efforts is definitely sizeable and I am ready to support it and raise a hand in favour of negotiating and fine—tuning the proposal as it stands today.

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, there has been a very nationally coloured debate around the Port Services Regulation. So I dare to describe the situation from the point of view of my country, Finland. Our port airport has undergone a major transformation in recent years since moving to act as private law organisations operating under market conditions in the form of a limited liability company at the beginning of 2015. The objectives set out in the regulation under discussion are therefore already commonplace in the operations of our Finnish port operators. I think it is particularly important that everyone in Europe should have an equal regulatory framework for the organisation of port services and the transparency of public funds when making port investments.  As far as the regulation is concerned, the outcome may not be complete or complete, but for me it is good enough. I would like to thank the rapporteur, as well as the shadows of the various groups, for their persistent work, and I hope that Parliament will maintain its cold-heartedness until the end and vote forward tomorrow.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE).
text: Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this is the third time that the European Commission has tried to impose the liberalisation of port services in Europe. Although we have changed the name "port services organization", we are not lying, again, it is a question of competing with services such as lamanage, towing and piloting in a whole set of ports, even though many of them are very different from each other. What works in Rotterdam, Hamburg or Antwerp, which together account for 20% of europe's freight transport, does not necessarily work in a port like Le Havre. Unfortunately, your impact study does not take into account the specifics of the ports. Worse, it imposes a uniform vision in defiance of reality, in defiance of people's experiences, in defiance of environmental demands, in defiance of social demands.  Our aim should be to preserve coastlines and security at ports, on the one hand, but also to protect employees, on the other. All this is now put at risk by your project. The main demand of European ports is not liberalisation. What they are asking for is a clarification of European rules, for example on state aid. However, the Commission has for years refused to publish the specific guidelines for state aid for ports. Although some exemptions from liberalisation were obtained in the negotiations, this text does not present sufficient safeguards, real progress, to be supported. In these circumstances, we can only vote against this project.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the report seems to have understood the differences between the various European ports. The most significant innovation of the report is the removal of the provisions on market access for port services in favour of more flexible organisational models and greater discretion for The Member States. There can be no single legislative solution for all European ports, given their diversity.  But it is important to ensure autonomy, to establish transparent rules and to make ports more competitive. Although the report has undergone a number of changes, it is nevertheless an important change, enriching the European Union's port policy, with a significant social dimension.  I am pleased that the report recognises the role of the sectoral social partners in dealing with issues such as automation and technological innovation. The social dialogue must play a crucial role in the fight against precarious work, which, alas, is widespread especially in the countries of southern Europe.  We will do our utmost to ensure that the principles such as social rights, transparency over public funds, State aid, the exclusion of small ports and excessive administrative burdens are maintained by the text that will be signed.

name: Luis de Grandes Pascual (PPE).
text: – Madam President, ports are a key component in the creation of an integrated and efficient trans-European network, at the service of citizens and industry in the European Union. The European Commission is aware of this, and has therefore made two attempts – this will be the third – to improve its functioning. But what it initially pursued (more competition, transparency, equal treatment, freedom of establishment, social protection and efficiency) has been transformed into a bespoke, cheating of exceptions, opaque, designed for certain ports and disconnected from the reality of the logistics chain. In addition, the report interferes with the competences of the Member States which are part of its essential economic constitution. In the case of Spain, ports are in the public domain. Therefore, the fees for their use cannot be fixed by negotiation between private operators, negotiation to which the rapporteur added opacity. I am sorry. The Spanish delegation of the People's Party will vote tomorrow against this report for leading to the isolation of ports from the transport network, not responding to the general interest and not respecting the constitutional provisions of the Member States. We're sorry. Some say this third attempt is going to be the only viable one; But, Commissioner, it will not be because of your ambition, but quite the opposite. The modernisation of ports in Europe will continue to be an outstanding subject and with this will not be possible the comodality, that is, the symbiosis between the different modes of transport.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the text on port services has long been a mythical creature that we have heard a lot about but which we never see in the end. However, after months of work, Knut Fleckenstein, our Socialist rapporteur, has managed to draw up a text for which we will be called to vote tomorrow. This text is the result of long and painstaking negotiations to reach compromises that have radically transformed the Commission's initial ultraliberal proposal. Together with other colleagues, I myself have done an important task of amending and I am pleased that Knut Fleckenstein has taken up much of it. This refers to the requirement of a national flag for the most sensitive services, which will stabilize the legal situation of ports that already comply with it. Public service obligations are also written in black and white in the report, which is in line with a more social Europe. Financial transparency is an essential point of the text, which will allow for fairer and healthier competition between European ports, but the smallest or most vulnerable ports will not have as many administrative obligations as the large ones, to prevent them from suffocating under the weight of bureaucracy. In its version adopted in the Committee on Transport and Tourism, the text provides the necessary social guarantees for us socialists, while guaranteeing Member States the flexibility to allow them to retain their national models. Indeed, there is a very wide variety of port organisation in Europe, and a single standard should not be imposed by force, which would also be less likely to work better than existing models. The current text is satisfactory, and it should not be damaged in a trilogue. It is the position of the representatives elected by the citizens that will have to prevail. That is why Parliament must arrive at the negotiations with the strongest possible position, and this will require the most unanimous vote possible. Indeed, tomorrow, it is a question of voting for the text that will serve as the basis for the trilogue: it is not a question of having a text at all costs, but of having a good text. The question will rest when an agreement has been reached with the Council and the Commission: if the result were to be disappointing, then Parliament will be able to exercise its power of codecision by rejecting it, because it is better, in this case, not to have harmonisation rather than poor harmonisation.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, the efficiency of European ports is one of the keys to the Union's competitiveness. That is why we support this report which adds efficiency, financial transparency and autonomy to the management of these infrastructures, promotes efficiency and competitiveness in equality for all, wants to lighten customs bureaucracy without losing control, better protects the rights of port users and workers and ensures that some essential services, such as piloting, fulfil their public interest functions without private interference.  We hope that port autonomy, expressed in different management models, professionalism and free competition will promote innovation and the creation of new and better services. We therefore oppose allowing exceptions allowing some States to centralise pricing policy through fees, a practice that prevents ports, without losing their status as public, from setting their tariffs with full autonomy. European professional associations also consider this obviously in the interests of the competitiveness of those who suffer from this restriction and a threat to the autonomy and transparency of all ports of the Union.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I would like to point out an element which for our group is fundamental and is that the centre of gravity of this report has been shifted from the obsession with liberalisation towards the labour and social aspects. Liberalization— better called privatization — of ports, trains and public services in general does not, on the contrary, condemn the social model, because profits are only obtained by deteriorating working conditions and quality of service. When the interests of large companies are put before those of people, the result is that the social dumping of the most socially dumped competitors within Europe is being fought. That's not our model, that's not our solution. The way we have to work is to achieve more efficient, transparent and environmentally sustainable ports without degrading working conditions or quality of service.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht Koch (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I can well remember the liberalisation of port services. After 2001 and 2004, we now have a new, third port package, and we have been doing so since 2013. Although the composition of Parliament has changed considerably since then, the House has remained true to its high standards. Even with the report we are de-debated today, there will be no unconditional need for liberalisation for competing suppliers. I would therefore like to thank the rapporteur, who has not lost sight of our objective and has always worked for freedom of organisation of port services. Because of the very different levels of ports in Europe, it was probably also difficult to produce a coherent text. I believe, however, that the rapporteur has managed a good middle ground. In particular, I welcome the clear call for transparency, both in the choice of providers – there must be no discrimination here – and in financial relations and in charges for the use of port services or port infrastructure. I particularly welcome the need for good training and continuous training for workers in this sector to maintain the safety and competitiveness of our ports. I am seeking approval.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the Commission must listen to the firm position of this House and port workers against the liberalisation of the sector and must act at once against those States which ignore the European norm when new social standards are defined.  We believe that this proposal improves working conditions at ports, something we are already asking for in the opinion of the Committee on Employment. Port workers are required to train workers safely and healthily and collective bargaining is supported, while enforcing port companies to respect social and labour minimums.  But we warn: these rights should apply equally to workers in public or private ports. We strongly oppose the exclusions now being asked of the right.  And there are still fringes to be addressed: for example, insufficient protection of workers in the event of transfer of service and obstacles to public financing of ports. In this respect, we find it particularly serious that the need to ensure public control of key infrastructures such as ports can be questioned.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you, Commissioner. I would particularly like to thank Mrs Vozemberg, the shadow rapporteur for my group. The efforts that have been made in trying to bring together the many different needs of the many European ports are to be welcomed, even if the answer is not – as so many of my fellow Members have said – always satisfactory.  And what are the points on which, during the trialogues' negotiation phase, we will be careful and will ensure that the strengths of the presence of ports in the European development system are guaranteed? The first point is that it is clear that not all ports, as we said, are the same. And there is a clear differentiation between what is happening in northern European ports and what is happening in southern European ports. In my country, Italy, we have a huge number of passengers, including in the tourism sector, who have about seven to eight million visitors a year, almost 23%, of movements at continental level.  We are aware of the huge numbers that pass through European ports in the field of goods – more than 75% between imports and exports, over 37% of the internal market – and therefore we know how necessary and complicated it is to bring all needs together. From this point of view, therefore, also in the social field, we call for care to ensure that ports continue to be the point where major investments converge for the future of Europe. So we say yes to negotiation and yes to this report, but with particular attention being paid to ensuring that all these different needs converge towards a great common objective.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, ports and port work have long been under attack by the great capital and its political representatives. Forcing the devaluation of the labour force is vital to reduce costs and increase profits, in a context of increasingly fierce global competition, increasing liberalisation and deregulation of markets and the progressive privatisation of the port sector, driven by the European Union.  The situation in Portugal is paradigmatic. Protected by the interference of the troika and its hand-held government, the patronage foresaw an opportunity to return to the time of the houses of tale, of unbridled exploitation. Not satisfied with the precariousness already existing are never, want to go further, always want to go further in exploration. Thanks and worth everything, until creating a puppet union, but it was also worth the unity and combativeness of port workers. Let us have no illusions, this is what can stop the European Commission, its interests and its grieving intentions, defending workers' rights and the national interest.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The rapporteur said that today's proposal is better than the two previously rejected. I think that, after fifteen years, Europe deserves very good rules in this area that leave no doubt of interpretation. Mr Rapporteur, i would like to thank you for your comments. Poland has no problems with transparency. Poland, we have concerns that are raised by the provisions of this regulation which do not take into account the specificities of ports in the countries of the European Union, on the basis that one common European approach is better than action taken at Member State level. We cannot agree with this approach. Nor can we support legislation that increases bureaucracy and necessitates changes in the competences of many Polish institutions.  In Poland, we have very good regulations that guarantee financial transparency, freedom of business, competition, proper supervision. Polish ports are developing very well and we are afraid that these provisions will disrupt this development. The Polish delegation will therefore vote against this solution, appreciating both the efforts of the rapporteur and all the alternates.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would also express my hope that this third attempt to pass this report, or this legislation, will be successful.  I welcome and appreciate on this proposal that, to some extent, it is retreating from certain provisions within the social part. This can undoubtedly be appreciated. However, I consider it important that the Commission continues to enforce, as is the result of the proposal, uniform rules for the functioning of the port.  To create sufficient competitiveness and competitive tension, because today we are also seeing a situation where the market is being abused. When the situation is abused precisely in transport and goods performances in transit.  So it is essential for us, even though we are a landlocked state, the Czech Republic, that these rules are truly competitive in the future, in order to set up a transparent, simple network for the transport of goods.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Madam President, these coast ports which I represent are a major engine for jobs and growth: one million square feet of new distribution space last year at Felixstowe, Britain’s biggest container port; a new port at London Gateway; GBP 100 million investment in the port of Tilbury, adding to modern crane facilities provided with the help of the EU motorways of the sea; the port of Ipswich playing a major economic role for the Haven gateway, and Great Yarmouth for the economy in Norfolk. That is why I reiterate to my friend Knut Fleckenstein a call to use the negotiation to promote competition between European ports. To ensure a genuine level playing field for state aids, I am worried about the proposed exemptions. I think we have to heed the warnings of the European Towage Association, which predicts environmental catastrophe. I do not ask him for different arrangements for the UK; instead, while the British Government opposes the social and employment aspects in Articles 10(2) and 10(a), I ask him to defend them and to support Amendments 146 and 147, which I co—signed, on enhanced safety and collective bargaining rights. The Port Service Regulation has been refused twice, and if jobs, employment rights, investment and safety are not guaranteed, it should be rejected again.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, the report presents quality changes to the European Commission's proposal. In particular, I welcome the rejection of the single management system, as I believe that we must respect all the diversity of the Union port system and strengthen the port service organisation models currently in place across the continent. I am pleased that the committee responsible has distinguished the potential arising from this diversity and put emphasis on common minimum requirements and their effective implementation. Unfortunately, this house too often insists on poor universal solutions, so this report is a welcome exception to be supported. In my view, the report also sufficiently emphasises the importance of financial transparency in the use of public funds, and insisting on the principle of proportionality when collecting a fee whose amount will no longer be misunderstanding the economic value of the service provided also represents an important step in the right direction.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, this port regulation is a very good attempt to set a level playing field for all European ports and also to enhance their competitiveness. Business as usual in some Member States has until now protected the interests of the centralised port bureaucracy of some Member States instead of the interest of consumers, enterprises and economic growth. Europe needs to be successful in sharing best practices, like the ports’ fiscal autonomy, among the more reluctant reformers of the European Union.  As a Catalan MEP I welcome this report and I hope that this legislation makes it through with minimum changes in the negotiation with the Council.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – That regulation, according to the applicant, is therefore to improve competitiveness, trasparentity, less bureaucracy for users. In the Commissioner's view, it offers a view to the future, the modernisation of ports.  Of course, ports mean a gateway to the world. The problem of jobs has also been mentioned several times today. Of course, we are not just talking about jobs here. We, of course, want decent jobs for decent pay and therefore a proper continuation of collective bargaining, because of course, safety and, of course, social rights are also in the first place.  Given that the commission is also trying to achieve the most equal situation in relation to the European budget, I expect that the Commission will also take care, as far as possible, of the balanced development of ports, given their diversity and advantages.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, Tilbury Docks, in my constituency, is linked to one in ten jobs within Thurrock. The success of those jobs relies on the success of the port. At DP World within Thurrock Borough, trade is growing, and this would be the worst possible time to put more regulations on them, especially as trade is growing with the rest of the world outside the EU.  This is a case in point with our referendum coming up: why should EU rules affect non—EU trade that has absolutely nothing to do with the European Union? We will be opposing it for those reasons. The best people to govern our ports are the people that should govern our laws – the British people themselves.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Madam President, I want to speak tonight on behalf of Northern Ireland’s ports, which would be devastated by these proposals. This is yet another example of the EU trying to impose a one-size-fits-all solution.  Ports in Northern Ireland are already part of a thriving, competitive independent UK sector. Belfast Harbour handles goods valued at GBP 30 billion annually, 700 companies are based in the harbour estate, over 22 000 people are employed there. Foyle Port supports an estimated 1 000 jobs, representing wages of GBP 26 million annually into the local economy.  No political union should seek to jeopardise these benefits for local people. What we have in this proposal are bureaucratic obstacles to growth and job creation, the imposition of excessive regulation and oversight. It penalises the ports as being service providers. Of course we all know that if this gets through, it is simply the beginning. Tomorrow I will be voting to reject this approach and to protect Northern Ireland’s economy. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, can you give me two or three examples of what you mean if you want to protect the Northern Ireland economy? What is particularly endangering this economy? I believe that the Port Industry of Northern Ireland could very well benefit from this, because it will not be forced to change anything.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you to the rapporteur for his question. I want to absolutely confirm with the rapporteur that I have consulted at great length with the Northern Ireland ports, and the Northern Ireland ports are absolutely opposed to these changes. They see them as being anti-competitive, they see them as blocking growth and job creation and, in a place like Belfast which is relatively small, support for 22 000 jobs is absolutely vital.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, coming from the island of Ireland, ports are obviously very important to us, and thankfully we have some fine ports both in Northern Ireland and in the Republic of Ireland. Post COP21, the role of the maritime sector, shipping and ports are going to be very important in helping us to meet our targets regarding emissions, and particularly the development of the motorways of the seas. For that reason, it is important that ports are functioning properly and that there be transparency, intra-port competition, and that the rights of workers, etc., be protected. But we also need to develop the core network corridor, especially for ports like Shannon Foynes in my own constituency, which is one of the deepest ports in Europe – and with the Panama Canal now doubling its capacity, deep ports are going to be required. By the extension of the network corridor, this would be a huge asset both to Shannon Foynes and, indeed, to Europe generally, and I think that is something we should consider.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it is the third attempt to Europeanise ports and I would like to ask what the meaning we give it this time. For Commissioner Kallas, who put the initial text on the table, it was to apply competition rules within ports, imposing dynamics of competition on the various services of the port, including vital ones, such as practice, which must meet demands for safety, the environment and even the fight against the labour exploitation of crews. That is why this is the case with the rapporteur and Parliament. I welcome the exclusion of them from a rule that put everything in danger. For southern ports, it was also an opportunity to establish a system of transparency to avoid unfair competition between those in the north, who are historically rich because they are financed by strong state aid, compared to those in the south, who do not have this aid. What was not my surprise when I saw this morning that Commissioner Vestager has raised the exemption from aid for port infrastructure, obviously for those who have a chance. Hence my vote, also in view of the problems of port fees in the Spanish system, cannot be positive.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: – Mr President, this is a good proposal. Sure, it's watered down, delayed and partly incomplete, but at the end of the day, it's more good than bad. EU ports need uniform, non-discriminatory rules of the game. Transparency and transparent procedures are in everyone's interest. The proposal now being put to the vote, for its part, strengthens these rules. That is why I support it.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank everyone for this most interesting debate. I have listened carefully to all of the comments, but some of the information in the debate is a bit outdated. State aid exemptions have been published today. The focus is now on the modernisation of ports to make them greener, more socially responsible and more innovative. The benefits are for all ports, not only a few in the north. The text is based on clear complementarity between EU and national levels, leaving ample room to adapt to local environments. The vote will decide if it is a stable legislative framework for ports. The momentum is there to improve the functioning of the trans-European transport network to create growth in ports and through ports, which also leads to new employment opportunities. Regarding some of the comments by the honourable Members Anderson, de Grandes Pascual and Ayala Sender as regards the autonomy of ports in setting infrastructure charges, I am open to working with you constructively to find a solution during the trilogues. Like the Council, some of you think that the regulation should not prevent Member States from having their say on charges and port management. I hear you; be assured the Commission is willing to look at this question during the trilogues. To honourable Members Seymour and Foster I would say that as regards private ports, we are open to solutions, but they must not allow private undertakings to abuse their dominant position or distort competition with other ports.  In response to honourable Members Taylor, Delli and Šoltes, allow me to highlight again the benefits the regulation brings for the environment. The internalised external cause the regulation will serve to develop a method for varying port charges according to the environmental performance of the ships. More generally, financial transparency and clearer rules on access to the market will encourage the investments which are dearly needed to make ports greener. I therefore see no disagreement with the objectives of the Green groups. As regards Article 10 on the transfer of rights, let me be very clear: the transfer of staff should not be regulated at European level, but left to the Member States. We must respect national labour laws and the arrangements which have been developed by social partners. I am confident we will be able to clarify these during the trilogue. I hope this answers the call of honourable Member Anderson. With that, I want to thank again the rapporteur and his shadows for their perseverance. The support from all major organisations show that the report on the table strikes the right balance, and that is what we have a chance to achieve tomorrow with positive support: a chance for a balanced agreement on ports, an agreement that can further strengthen the single transport area and the single market which has been a great achievement of the EU. I therefore encourage Members to support it; I believe we are ready for trilogues that can bring the final solution.

name: Knut Fleckenstein
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which There has been a long and intense discussion – especially with the port authorities, the terminal operators, the trade unions, partly on the ground in Piraeus and Koper, in Trieste and Rijeka, in Barcelona and Antwerp, in Porto, also in Hamburg. We knew that, after the disastrous history of the port package, a viable compromise can only be reached if as many stakeholders as possible are involved. After 15 years of discussion, after political strikes even in Germany, a damaged exterior of the Strasbourg Parliament – if the elders remember – a great deal of goodwill and hard work has now succeeded in reaching broad agreement. I would like to conclude by reading from an e-mail we have received in recent days: 'On 8 March the European Parliament will be voting on the Fleckenstein report on the proposal for a port regulation. The European organisations representing the ports appreciate the efforts that have been made by the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs to reach a balanced compromise text thanks to an inclusive dialogue involving different stakeholders. We strongly believe that the work achieved so far by the rapporteur and the shadows should be supported in the plenary and is a solid base for opening the negotiation with the Council.' This is written by the Secretary General of ESPO, the Secretary General of FEPORT, the Political Secretary of the Dockers and Fisheries of the ETF, the Secretary General of the Boatmen Association and Captain Dirk Vael of the Pilots. My question to the critics is: could it perhaps be that all those who are supposed to work with it in the future and recommend our approval are not completely wrong?

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, March 8, 2016. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Jobs could be lost at the Port of Tyne and Teesport if PSR is passed in this Parliament today. The proposed PSR will have a substantial impact on privately-owned ports. Most continental ports are in public ownership but 75% of British ports are in private ownership, so the United Kingdom will be the most affected. Ports will be forced to contract out services and appoint at least two service providers, even if only one is required. This will undermine the competitiveness of local ports in a tough market. The proposed PSR would also undermine commercial confidentiality. I am very concerned at the impact the regulations would have on Teesport: it is another kick in the teeth for hard-working people. Our local economy is under severe strain, and our transport links are a huge part of the fact that the North East is a net exporting region. We simply cannot afford to risk further loss of jobs at a time when our region already has the highest unemployment in the country. This proposal is a timely reminder that staying in the EU actually carries a substantial risk to local people’s jobs. The UK has Europe’s second-largest port sector, with 344 000 jobs across the country.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Ladies and gentlemen, I invite you to vote in favour of the report on the proposed regulation establishing a framework for market access for port services and financial transparency of ports. I believe that the future regulation should increase efficiency and reduce the cost of services provided in the European Union's seaports.  In this report, I take a few questions. First, the need for transparency in port accounts with respect to public funds. It is normal, if not essential, for the citizen to be able to easily identify public funds in port accounts. Another point I wish to stress is the right of staff to enjoy working conditions based on binding national, regional or local social standards and relevant training.  Now I also expect the european Parliament's negotiators to insist on these points in negotiations with the Council for an ambitious final settlement for the benefit of all, including workers and citizens.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I would have liked for the report to be more ambitious on the financial transparency aspect. Due to the complex nature of port organisation, especially of the larger ports, the transparency rules need to be strict on paper in order to achieve the desired effect in practice. Even in relatively small ports, such as the port of Tallinn, there are cases of corruption in which the political parties in power benefit from the corruption, and yet remain relatively insulated since their tool of choice is exercising control over the state-owned company. If, due to lack of transparency, these kinds of activities take a while to be discovered in small ports such as Tallinn, we can only imagine what the situation in larger ports could be. name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I am critical of the proposal for port services. I would also like to announce that I will consistently vote against the current version of the report. In my opinion, EU Member States already have sufficient competence to improve the quality of port services, modernise port facilities and increase the financial transparency of ports. Contrary to the intentions, the draft regulation may result in a deterioration of the operating conditions of ports. The envisaged new powers of port authorities to reduce the number of port services available are also of concern. After all, this directly affects the principle of freedom of establishment and competitiveness. I base my position on numerous discussions with specialists, including the port management in Gdansk, Gdynia, Szczecin and Świnoujście.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on the report by Benedek Jevor, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on the 2014 annual report on the protection of the EU's financial interests - Combating Fraud (2015/2128(INI)) (A8-0026/2016).

name: Benedek Jávor
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, the report on the protection of the EU’s financial interests is one of the most important reports that we discuss on a yearly basis here in Parliament. Not only because this is about money, a lot of public money, but also because in the troubled times that we have right now, building back confidence in EU institutions is a key issue for the European institutions and for every responsible European politician. We have to assure citizens of the European Union that their money is used properly, is transparent and is spent in a way which is in line with the EU regulation. The report which we discuss on a yearly basis generally mirrors the opinion of the Commission and this year we had a good and quite detailed report. Of course Parliament as usual has its own priorities and issues to be raised in the debate. The report we voted on in the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) has wide backing from different political groups and was voted for almost unanimously in the CONT Committee. Basically we concentrate on two levels of protection of the EU’s financial interests. The first is protection of the revenue of the European Union, the own resources of the EU. From this perspective I think that it is very important to emphasise that VAT fraud is clearly an EU competence as VAT is part of the EU own resource system. The VAT gap is varying too not only at European level but also at Member State level. The VAT gap reached EUR 168 billion in 2013. So we welcome that the Commission supports a strong PIF directive, including VAT in the scope, but we have also to include it in the directive or the regulation on the European Public Prosecutor’s Office to be effective. A couple of days ago too the European Court of Auditors published a special report on VAT issues and this supports our view that the EU system on VAT is not effective enough: Data coming from the Member States is not reliable; exchange of information among the Member States is not working properly; tax authorities do not cooperate effectively and the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) does not have competence to investigate cross-border VAT fraud, so it is an important issue. But we also have to point out the problems with the recovery rate because in 2014 it was at the level of 24% which is a historical lowest point and this has to change.  The second level of the protection of the financial interests of the EU is proper spending of EU resources. The Member States and the Commission have shared responsibility for implementing approximately 80% of the European Union’s budget so the Commission has a lot of things to do here. We need sound financial management while spending EU money and it should be combined with a ‘best use of every euro’ approach. We accepted a new public procurement directive but it is also important to check its implementation. I also have to mention the corruption index in our report. I have to raise the issue of the biannual anti-corruption report of the Commission, which we are eager awaiting in Parliament and we hope that this year it is going to include the 29th Chapter on the EU institutions as well, and better protection for whistle-blowers in the European Union and in the Member States as whistle-blowers are a very important part of anti-corruption activity.  I think that we had very good cooperation together with the shadow rapporteurs. We have prepared a report which I believe can count on well founded grounds on your support in the vote.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, on behalf of the Commission I would like to thank the Committee on Budgetary Control and in particular the rapporteur, MEP Benedek Jávor, for the 2014 Report on the Protection of the EU’s financial interests, and also to express our gratitude for the strong commitment of Parliament to the fight against fraud. We fully share this commitment and welcome the report’s analysis, as well as many very valuable recommendations which we will thoroughly follow up on. Let me flag up some of the key recommendations and how we are going about them. First, reporting on irregularities. Parliament has requested, and rightly so, to improve the comparability of data reported by Member States so we can actually have a picture that is understandable and allows us to draw conclusions from it. We have adopted in 2015 a new regulation concerning reporting on irregularities and on that basis we have launched with the participation of national experts the preparation of new guidelines on reporting. On that basis, data would now feed a new improved version of the irregularities reporting systems and I am very pleased to inform you that we expect this new improved system to be operational in the second quarter of 2016. Secondly, national anti-fraud strategies. As the rapporteur pointed out, we have obligations together with Member States. Member States are becoming increasingly more effective in fighting fraud and this is visible by the increase of detection and also prosecution of fraud cases: 1 649 cases overall. This is more than in 2013, but the recovery rate has to be beefed up, it has to be improved, and we believe that a lot more can be done in prevention, detection, reporting, prosecution and sanctioning if we are to have Member States embracing what Parliament is supporting very much, namely national anti-fraud strategies. So far this is not mandatory, it is voluntary. Five Member States have adopted such strategies. We encourage others to do it and we work already with those who have done it so we can actually improve the actions on the basis of exchange of best practices and experience. Third, the rapporteur mentioned public procurement following the special report of the Court of Auditors on this issue, on public procurement. The Commission is looking at how to improve the functionalities of the irregularities management system which I mentioned, and the possibility to have interoperability between different databases so we can make best possible use of information and, of course, enhance transparency. We know that transparency is the taxpayers’ best friend, so the more we can do in this area, the better for the protection of the financial interests. There is a proposal to publish beneficiaries, and I want to clarify that the current legislation already foresees this and lists the type of information that needs to be published. Fourth, corruption indicators. Concerning statistics and indicators on corruption in the Member States, there are significant differences in terms of definition and statistical recording practices, so we have to work on that over the medium term so we can have greater availability of corruption information, and I want to use this moment to respond. Yes, we are working on the biannual anti-corruption report so it will be available in 2016. Fifth, the follow-up of OLAF recommendations at national level and the establishment of a European Prosecutor’s Office. We agree that comprehensive prosecution of crimes against the EU’s financial interests is essential and that more has to be done in Member States to follow up on OLAF’s recommendations and also to provide feedback to OLAF on actions taken. We think that the establishment of the European Prosecutor’s Office will help us in this regard and we also believe that the evaluation of Regulation 883/2013 governing OLAF’s investigations, to be completed by 2017, will provide an opportunity also in this regard. Like the rapporteur, we believe that VAT fraud should be part of the work of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, it should be covered by the PIF Regulation. We also believe that it is essential that the mandate of the EPPO is clear about that and that discussions between the co-legislators should be brought to a successful conclusion as soon as possible, so that we have the best possible EPPO we can design. Finally, there has been a question in the committee on what we can do specifically on the independence of OLAF’s supervisory committee secretariat. I want to take the opportunity to report that on 4 March we have taken a decision in the Commission and we adopted a proposal for an amendment of the OLAF Regulation to transfer the Supervisory Committee secretariat to the Commission and we hope that there will be swift action by the legislator to adopt this proposal, so any appearance of a conflict of interests, any perceived conflict of interest can be eliminated. I thank Members for their attention and I look forward to the debate this evening.

name: Sander Loones
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. – It is a shame to waste taxpayers' money, but it is a living shame to defraud with taxpayers' money. And that is what the report we are discussing tonight is about. I do have some comments. 1. I call on the Commission and the Anti-Fraud Office OLAF to step up its efforts. When I saw the amounts in the report, I was somewhat surprised. We all know the stories of fraud in the context of, for example, cohesion policy or agricultural subsidies. 2. I believe that this report could give a little more attention to prevention, because prevention is better than cure in the context of fraud. 3. Finally, I note that the report calls for the creation of a new European agency, another European agency, a third agency alongside Eurojust and next to OLAF. And I genuinely wonder if this is really necessary and whether this can't be done much more efficiently.

name: Mercedes Bresso
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to remind you that maintaining the confidence of European citizens in the Union's institutions and their adherence to the project of European integration must remain one of the main objectives at the heart of the policy for the protection of the Union's financial interests that the committee pursues. Corruption and fraud against the EU budget are directly proportional to a lack of transparency in the procedures for allocating and managing and spending European funds.  In my opinion, therefore, a clear distinction must be made between fraud and error, and information must be given on both fraud and the most frequent errors, including concrete examples, so that users of European Union funds and managing authorities are better informed and it is therefore better to make a clear distinction between fraud or error, perhaps due to difficulties that we will try to temper and reduce with the work on the better lawmaking project.  But, in the meantime, I believe that making this clear distinction between the two types can greatly help users and also make it possible to find those who are really fraudsters.

name: Julia Pitera
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab  It is the duty of the institutions, both European and national, to take care of taxpayers' money.  They must uphold the correct spending of EU money. Therefore, the fight against all pathologies in this area must be a priority, especially as fraud and corruption are a source of funding for organised crime and terrorist groups – and, very importantly, undermine citizens' trust in public institutions and democratic processes. They also have a negative impact on the Union's competitiveness in the global economy.  The fight against irregularities and fraud is hampered by the diversity of member states' legal and administrative systems.  commission's action must therefore be intensive and systematic.  Effective recovery of funds unduly disbursed from the Union budget, more efficient collection of own resources and the establishment of uniform reporting rules are indispensable elements of effective action.  The projects selected for implementation should serve economic growth and job creation.  At the same time, the Commission should promote rules on the protection of whistleblowers, promote access to information and transparency of lobbying activities.  On the other hand, the proposal for financial support for cross-border investigative journalism, which, when receiving budget money, will lose its independence and which journalists will have to disclose which methods and means they have used when settling grants is well founded.  To conclude, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his good cooperation.

name: Georgi Pirinski
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I agree with the rapporteur that we have had a very useful process of preparing this report, and I do believe that the result is such as to contribute to the increasing confidence of citizens that their financial interests are being protected in the proper way. I would like to point out three items from our report and ask the Commissioner to comment.  The first has to do with the interruptions and suspensions. I believe it is very important to highlight what is in the report that these should be used in accordance with the relevant legal basis, and in the context, Madam Vice—President – something I find very important – is that you have adopted a new early warning mechanism. I would like to invite you to comment on the expectation for the creation of a comprehensive system of early detection and exclusion which the Commission is to propose. I fully agree with colleagues who have pointed out that prevention is the important element.  Secondly, the question of directly managed funds, Madam Commissioner: it is highly worrisome that there is a four-fold increase in the fraudulent irregularities in 2014, something which the Commission should provide a detailed explanation for and outline the action it will take. Thirdly, you highlighted the issue of correct reporting. I would only go along with colleagues and what is in the report that the situation now is highly unsatisfactory – we do not have a clear enough picture, so we very much rely on those efforts which you have pointed out to really make a change, even for next year’s report.

name: Monica Macovei
text: on behalf of the ECR group. – Madam President, in 2014, the Member States reported 1,650 frauds, amounting to EUR 540 million. That's the figure we're talking about and it's only for a year! This is not European money in an abstract way, but it is European citizens' money, it is our money. The Commission must take full responsibility for the recovery of this money. The Commission must also maintain strict rules for the interruption and suspension of payments. Indicators for measuring corruption in Member States should be used. This is one of the minimum urgent measures that need to be taken. Another urgent measure: the protection of whistleblowers, so-called whistleblowers. The experience of those who work in European institutions and who have revealed illegalities has often been traumatic and, as such, there are fewer such whistleblowers, which makes us lose money. The regulation must be amended and these people must be protected. Another measure: the publication of agreements with tobacco companies, with all tobacco companies. The agreements must be published in order to prevent, to the greatest extent we can, tobacco smuggling. I also call for that 'VAT carousel' for European funds to become a criminal offence in the Directive on the protection of financial interests and to stop this assault by the Member States, of most Member States which do not want this carousel of VAT, the fraud of European VAT money, to be a criminal offence. A mandatory and urgent measure is also the adoption of the Regulation on the European Public Prosecutor's Office. All our money is in the same basket and, if it is stolen in a Member State, it is actually stolen from all of us.

name: Nedzhmi Ali
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like first of all to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Jávor, for the well done report, and thanks also to Commissioner Georgieva for her detailed statement. In real Europe, cases of fraud raise public attention and damage the reputation of the Union. It obliges us to ensure sound financial management and to put in place all necessary measures to protect the EU budget. The annual report of the Commission on the protection of the EU’s financial interests presents the functioning of preventive and corrective mechanisms and actions taken by the Commission services to protect the EU budget from illegal or irregular expenditure and irregularities related to their revenue.  While the EU and Member States are sharing responsibility for protection of the EU’s financial interests in fighting fraud, it is essential that the Commission and the Member States work together to protect effectively those interests. Here I can say that the Commission is working in that direction, as has been stated by Commissioner Georgieva. The report presents the real situation in the area of financial interests of the Union, to include the status of detection and reporting of irregularities, revenues and expenditures. Problems are also identified and a number of measures are presented in the areas of reporting and control. The Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT Committee) suggests the development of a system of indicators to measure the level of corruption in the Member States, amending the EU Staff Regulations to protect whistle-blowers and enhance transparency of lobbying. Among the policy areas considered at risk are public procurement, tobacco smuggling and counterfeit goods. The CONT Committee suggests enhancing cooperation among EU institutions to tackle fraudulent behaviour in the use of EU funds. Investigations and the role of OLAF are highlighted. Well-developed is a chapter related to performance-based budgeting and the value—for—money approach. Finally, it is important that anti-fraud measures are undertaken and should find the balance between control and the desire not to discourage beneficiaries. We need to secure not only a better revenue part of the budget ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, when governments, which call themselves pro-European, have to take measures to protect the interests of European taxpayers, they immediately become sceptical and, in order to share the money in the shadows, are prepared to postpone the adoption of important decisions on cooperation and the exchange of information and transparency, such as those contained in the directive on the protection of financial interests.  We can no longer accept easy waste and fraud of European regionally run funds, the lack of transparency in the documentation relating to contracts awarded directly, national supervisory authorities appointed by the control bodies in conflict of interest, which certify their expenditure and, above all, the unwillingness of governments to cooperate seriously in the exchange of tax and banking information. This is essential if we are really to combat major tax evasion and avoidance and money laundering. A recent Eurodad report sees Juncker's Luxembourg as the European champion in this regard. Finally, I find the lack of transparency on the Turin-Lyon project scandalous, where many Members have been asking for access to documentation on projects financed from European funds for several months and receiving negative responses. I urge the Commission to give answers.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, it is important to institutionalise the existence and operation of anti-fraud services and mechanisms in the European Union, but it is more important to take into account the results of the reports and conclusions on policy-making and how to deal with the wrong texts. For example, it is self-evident and necessary to simplify the rules and procedures relating to public expenditure and revenue from own resources in order to limit non-fraudulent irregularities, which for 2014 amount to a total of EUR 362 million and EUR 176.2 million respectively .  However, it is self-evident and necessary to revise the Council and Commission's decision on aid amounting to EUR 3 billion. In turkey, when the anti-fraud report points out that it is the main protagonist of the blatant irregularities linked to pre-accession aid funds, in particular those relating to cross-border cooperation. The Union is moving to the limits of deceit when the anti-fraud office is sounding the alarm about Turkey's credibility. Do The European institutions and the leaders of the Member States still believe that giving funds will reduce migration flows to Europe? How many more want to be told that Turkey is a crook?

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Jávor, on his very comprehensive work.  With the EU’s annual budget we are talking about roughly EUR 150 billion of taxpayers’ money. Citizens quite rightly want to know that this money is not being fiddled with. The bad news is that, in 2014, EUR 538 million of EU expenditure and revenue were affected by fraud. This is unacceptable and must be corrected. Controlling the use of money and punishing fraudulent acts is of the utmost importance. To achieve this, at least three things have to be done. Firstly, the Commission must be as proactive as possible in following the use of our money. Secondly, the Member States must consequently be held more accountable for tracking the projects and providing correct data to the Commission. Thirdly, logically, the Member States must have a common goal in fighting fraud. This may eventually help achieve the long—unfulfilled objective of making the EPPO finally materialise. But these things need to be delivered, not just talked about here in Strasbourg, so I hope the Member States are listening. I know the Commission is.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I would like to put a question to Mr Sarvamaa. We currently have OLAF. What is wrong here that OLAF cannot provide this service? Why then do we need a new agency here, or should OLAF be redesigned?

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Unfortunately, there was no interpretation, but my German is probably fluent enough to understand that you asked why we need another agency and when we already have OLAF, why we need the European Public Prosecutor’s Office. Greetings to my German teacher of 40 years ago! Well, as it is, OLAF does not actually have jurisdiction to deal with fraud inside the Member States, and only the national authorities have that right, but they cannot go over the border. So there is obviously a gap, and this is what I believe the Commission is trying to fill, and we have been waiting for this to happen for about 15 years. The time is now ready for that.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we have once again, this year, the debate on a budget that is becoming more precarious and with more and more pressure, more urgencies and more ambitions. I would the least like to thank Mr Jávor for emphasizing the protection of income, which I started a while ago. He has made this clear: in 2013 alone VAT fraud amounted to EUR 168 billion, or more than the entire budget for 2016. And it's absolutely impossible for that to continue to hold.  It is therefore so essential that, via OLAF , but above all with the PIF Directive, which must include VAT and must be approved as soon as possible – there is this possibility of combating that fraud which entails these multimillion-dollar losses for a budget that needs more.  (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, if this report is on the fight against fraud in the EU then we are losing. We have got billions a year in irregularities, the time lapse between detection and reporting is now three years, four months and on the way up, and we have got traditional own resources fraud up by 191% in a single year. We hear a lot about VAT fraud here, but actually part of the problem is that VAT is one of the most bureaucratic systems of tax collection known to humanity.  So we actually need to look at the problem rather than what always happens in this place, which is calls for more Europe, calls for the EU to get more involved in criminal justice, more involved with a Public Prosecutor’s Office at EU level. What an instructive example of the problem. Every problem: the solution is supposedly more and yet more EU. I will tell you one thing: if people back home in the UK knew what was really going on here, how much power this place really wants, they would vote on 23 June to leave for good.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I thank my colleague Benedict Jávor for the material presented. From the EPP's position, I have to say that this is a very high-quality text.  Corruption is a fundamental problem and phenomenon that significantly affects Europe's financial interests and thus every European citizen. We lose EUR 120 billion a year due to corruption and fraud. I am afraid that the fight against corruption is neither simple nor unequivocal. However, it is the responsibility not only of the Commission, but also of each Member State, and I stress this, to be involved in combating it, because corruption comes first and should be combated by awareness-raising and harsh sanctions.  Member States need to start taking more responsibility for European money and make effective attempts to ensure the objective and maximum added value of European money. And if this money is not properly used, it must be severely sanctioned.  This report, which we are discussing in Parliament today, is a balanced document that offers a quality solution, and I would like all actors to commit together to implement this solution.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Firstly, I consider it a value that you are shaping our Community awareness of the need to protect our common financial interest. This awareness is not so obvious at all. Secondly, the fact that you are showing that there are our Community finances and those of the Member States and the protection of interests at both levels is a move in the same direction, that is, towards the common protection of the financial interest of the Union as a whole. Another thing: a great deal of things will not depend solely on you, Mrs Georgieva, but on the Commission as a whole and on all of us. Starting from this – when we are rightly talking about the expenditure we are making – that if we continue to consider it a virtue that it is better to spend money from the budget rather than to invest, it will be a problem. And look at the Court of Auditors' position: out of EUR 650 million for airports, at least EUR 125 million spent incorrectly.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE).
text: – I have always believed that in this chamber they should take the preponderance of objectivity and professionalism over ordinary political competitions. Moreover, I am happy that this report does not point to good or bad, but points to much more – the need for a common approach in the control of European funds.  Just as we have a common approach in their collection and distribution through European funds, we also need a common approach in their control. Moreover, I am happy that we distinguish between error and between abuse, because much of the mistakes are due to long and difficult procedures. It is no coincidence that many beneficiaries prefer to borrow instead of going to european funds. That's why we need more money for technical assistance, simple and simpler and lighter rules so that people understand them and be able to implement them without a problem.  I am happy that my country is also one of those cited as an example for reporting the errors even before an audit of the European Commission. It is also important to say that in the previous term there were much worse results in terms of control of EU funds and errors, so we must also take into account Vice President Georgieva's work in this direction for these better results.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D).
text: – Dear President, honourable Vice-President, I was the rapporteur for the 2010 report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests, but since then fraud and irregularities have not decreased, but have increased, and already in 2014 the European Union has lost more than three billion euros as a result. However, so far, a small proportion of illegally diseducated cash has still been recovered from Member States. As I have said many times, the main problem remains that the Member States are not obliged to provide comprehensive and comparable data on their use when receiving huge cash from the European Union. It is therefore necessary for the Commission to harmonise the principles for reporting fraud and to establish a clear reporting system to determine how Member States implement the recommendations of investigations carried out by OLAF and to provide for penalties for non-compliance. Such a situation must not be tolerated and it is therefore necessary for the Commission to take full responsibility for the unlawful recovery of european funds paid.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I listened with interest to the whole debate and also to the Commissioner's speech. It is very good that the report distinguishes between intentional irregularities and technical irregularities. I want to say one thing that I personally consider important. A new office - the European Prosecutor's Office - is presented here as a proposal for a solution.  I, Commissioner, have been dealing with the reform of the Czech judiciary in the Czech Republic for ten years, and I must say that the subject of this office has always encountered great resistance from the professional public. And I personally believe that we're bluffing a little bit here, that we're going to create a new office and solve a problem.  It must be made clear that doubts and problems will continue to be decided by national courts. This means that the European Prosecutor may oversee the processing of the action, but national courts will continue to decide, and cooperation between member countries should therefore be strengthened. I think that's more important than setting up a new office.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I consider the report extremely important, given the level of fraud that exists in the internal market. Fraud generates corruption and corruption, obviously, it affects the Member States, the citizens, in fact, in the Member States, creating costs of hundreds of billions of euros annually. Very serious is that, in addition to reducing national budgets, corruption can help finance the activities of terrorist networks and corruption ultimately undermines citizens' confidence in democracy. I believe that there is a need to improve controls, but, Commissioner, I believe that prevention is more important. That has been said before. It is harmful to the citizens of a State when funding is cut off or payments are suspended, because, because of a mistake, it bears the consequences of all citizens of the country. I believe that more simplification of procedures is needed, because there are so many errors, not intentional mistakes, in the spending of funds and, of course, in the reports that are being made. I don't believe in additional institutions. Therefore, I do not support the European Public Prosecutor's Office. I believe in prevention a lot.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, according to the report, the European Union budget can be secured through OLAF, which has the role of identifying and investigating cases of fraud and corruption as well as other illegal activities. However, the total number of irregularities reported for 2014 amounts to around EUR 3.24 billion, while the financial impact of the irregularities reported is 36% higher than in 2013. Moreover, OLAF, while set up by the European Union to combat corruption and fraud within its Member States, does nothing to help combat tax fraud taking place in the European Union and in cases of tax evasion by multinational companies in tax havens and their transfer of profits to them. It is therefore necessary for OLAF to contribute more actively against multinational tax evasion and to contribute in practice to combating any illegal activity affecting the European Union.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – Congratulations to my colleague Jávor on his good work and report. I'm only going to touch on two problems myself. Firstly, illicit trade in tobacco is, of course, a global problem, which is why EU Member States lose large sums of public revenue annually, estimates show, up to EUR 37 billion. The thing is that, of course, we also damage the welfare of European taxpayers in this way. And the second is the field of public procurement. It seems to me that, from year to year, we are just repeating that there are a lot of errors, irregularities in this area, I just think that we could also get calculations of how much the effects of these irregularities are actually on the European budget, and, of course, also take action, but the dream of the General European Prosecutor is, of course, still a long way off, and by which time, the competent authorities of the Member States must also do more in prosecuting crime and corruption in this area.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Respected Commissioner, in your speech you pointed out that transparency is the best friend of taxpayers. I agree with you and I would add, best friend of the fight against corruption.  That is why it is important, now in the 21st century, to enable the public, namely all Member States, that clicking online can provide information on who has been paid the funds, who are the project promoters and who are the suppliers of project service providers. This is what matters because in this way, by these mechanisms we will prevent those who have a conflict of interest from entering into the use of public money. Dog watch and the reaction of our citizens will also be afraid.  Likewise, the Committee on Regional Development pointed out that education and the establishment of a base on irregularities for cohesion policy is very important so that we can identify the frequency of types of irregularities that occur, in particular for preventive action. These are essential messages of the report.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank everyone very much for all the comments and suggestions they have made. I will try to answer everyone, especially those who have put forward questions to the Commission. Let me start first with the role of prevention. As Mr Pirinski indicated, we are putting in place early warning systems that allow us to integrate different databases so that, as in the last intervention, we can actually see where money comes from and who the beneficiary is and then trace the route of the money. We now have multiple systems, and they do not always talk to each other, and that is a problem we are concentrated very much on resolving. In the budget focus for results initiative, we also want to create a way for us to see not only the movement of money, but also what we are getting for the money – what the benefit is, what the impact is. This will take time, but the efforts are structured and consolidated and, as I mentioned in my opening comments, already in the next quarter we will see some operationalisation of a better integration of these systems. Secondly, there was a point made on the importance of separating irregularities and fraud. Of course, fraud is the most dangerous – it is cancerous in societies – but it is also the more difficult to catch, because in fraudulent activities there is usually a lot of effort and smart investment to hide what is being done. What does it mean for us? Two things: one, to simplify the rules so that it is more difficult to create misinformation, and that simplification certainly would not only reduce fraud but also would reduce irregularities. Secondly, in the analyses we do to sketch more clearly the lessons learned when we catch fraud, what does it mean in terms of the systems in place to prevent it from happening? Here comes the point on institutional capabilities. We are currently missing a hammer when we know from the work of OLAF that there is irregularity and, more importantly, there is fraud because we send the information back to national authorities and it is up to them. In countries where the legal system is strong, action is taken; in countries where there are difficulties in the legal system, it may not be taken. We know that people here recently reflected on only 24% being claimed back – this is, by the way, not only about fraud, but also about irregularity. Our thinking in the Commission was that, with the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, we will provide this extra hammer to go after fraud. We put forward the proposal, but unfortunately what we have seen is a watering down of the original proposal. We are concerned about it and have expressed our concerns, including the fact that VIP fraud now seems to be excluded from the mandate of the EPPO, which of course would mean a big chunk of potential abuse being out of action. Of course, it is for Member States to complete their deliberations on the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, but I would agree with those of you who have said that it has to be value added for us to fund it. We do not need institutions for the sake of institutions; we need them for effectiveness, for doing the right job. There has been a very important point made that we are strong when we equip people with the opportunity to speak up. In that sense, protection for whistle—blowers is critical. We do it for staff in the Commission, and the question is: what more can we do to support Member States in enhancing their whistle-blower legislation? That is a conversation still to be had – what is our responsibility? We want to be sure, we want to be prudent, and we do not want to step out of line of what is our responsibility. We heard a comment that if we do not respect sovereignty and subsidiarity there could be more trouble than benefit, and we are, of course, very mindful of this. Let me finish by saying that we hope next year will come, Mr Pirinski, with a very good analysis of why the level of fraud has gone up. Is it because we detect more, so we catch more, or is it actually bad news, because more is taking place? Hopefully we would already integrate that analysis into the action by the Commission.

name: Benedek Jávor
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her contribution and all the Members who participated in the discussion tonight for the lively debate.
