Very briefly I would like to say – as a short reaction to the different issues which were raised – that I believe that there are four basic elements in the fight against corruption and fraud in the European Union. The first – and this links to the question of prevention – is full transparency. There is no fraud and there is no corruption if there is transparency. This is, for example, about the mandatory lobbying register in the EU, but there are also some worrying developments in the Member States regarding transparency. This is also about better reporting by the national authorities.  The second element is enhanced cooperation between the Member States. Mrs Macovei mentioned that it is impossible to fight against carousel fraud – VAT fraud – without good cooperation between the Member States and the Member State authorities, which is not happening right now. The third element is strong institutions. When we talk about OLAF, of course we can criticise it, but OLAF cannot be effective without the rights it needs to be effective. That is why we need to strengthen OLAF, for example by checking how OLAF’s recommendations are respected in the Member States. We also need more institutions such as the European Public Prosecutor’s Office.  The fourth, and last, one is the question of sanctions. I think that there are serious shortcomings here in the European institutions. How can we make sanctions? How can we enforce that the Member States respect the rules we set up? This is essential. Without this there will be no effective fight against fraud and corruption.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, March 8, 2016. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. Stimulating sustainable economic growth is a priority objective to be achieved through budgetary consolidation and rigour, which also includes the fight against fraud, in all its manifestations. As I have also pointed out in my other speeches, the combination of possible policy instruments must be accompanied by the effective application of existing legislation and effective compliance with international commitments, including anti-fraud and anti-corruption clauses. I therefore welcome the annual report, which show that the strategy on international fiscal policies is not separated from coordinated action at EU level. The benefits of the internal market must also be enhanced by relentless pressure on tax fraud and evasion. The use of interconnected databases on irregularities in cohesion policy, including public procurement, must also be developed at their respective levels, and the awareness of every institutional body, at European, national, regional and local level, must be strengthened. Public sentiment in general must change. I also share the concerns about the expected losses in the collection of VAT in the EU, estimated in 2013 at EUR 168 billion, a level that is still constant and unsustainable.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The defence of the Union's financial interests must be a priority and it is an issue that needs to be addressed in a concrete and effective way. In addition to irregularities, which are, however, a problem that must also be addressed by simplifying the rules and procedures so that they can no longer be considered a mitigating factor, the amount of fraud is very high. A large proportion of these relate to the funds, but the report presented, which follows a critical and attentive approach to all problems, underlines the growing importance of VAT fraud. In the absence of a single levy system, in fact, the single market lends itself to so-called 'carousel' fraud, which, in 2013, had already cost EUR 168 billion. In this respect, the report therefore calls on all Member States to participate fully in Eurofisc and to facilitate the exchange of information on eurofisc, in order to gradually limit the problem. The proper use of public money and the fair contribution of all citizens to the budget are of paramount importance and we will therefore continue to keep a high level of attention in this area.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: Written. – The protection of the EU's financial interests and the fight against fraud are important elements of a functioning economic policy. In this context, I would also like to highlight tax evasion, which is one of the most difficult problems facing the Union. Let me take a practical example from Finland. A power grid company called Caruna avoided taxes by recycling its money through the Netherlands. Only EUR 800,000 was paid to Finland from profits of EUR 50 million. After the profits were faded from the ledgers, the company informed consumers that it would increase electricity transmission prices by just under a third. This attracted a lot of criticism from the public – and entirely for a reason. I wanted to raise this case in this House, because there is currently a package of measures on the Council of Ministers' table to prevent tax evasion. I hope that the Council of Ministers will not now water down the Commission's proposal. The protection of the EU's financial interests requires not only the fight against fraud, but also the prevention of tax evasion.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on: - the oral question to the Commission on the Commission's communication entitled "Towards a Prosperous Data Economy" (COM (COM(2014)0442) by Jerzy Buzek, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (O-000021/2016 - B8-0116/2016) (2015/2612 (RSP)), - the oral question to the Commission on "Towards a prosperous data economy Vicky Ford, on behalf of the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee (O-000040/2016 - B8-0351/2016) (2015/2612 (RSP)).

name: Jerzy Buzek
text: author. – Madam President, big data certainly has enormous potential to push Europe’s economy forward. Europe needs to be ambitious, to lead, on big data but Europe should also lead in protecting our values.  First of all, privacy and data protection. In order to lead on big data Europe needs to set an innovation friendly regulatory framework that ensures, first of all, both data security and privacy. Secondly, to encourage private investment in both infrastructure and research and development. Point number 3: creation of a true digital union with all the standards: intellectual property rights and open public data. Point number 4: foster start-ups and SMEs in the data driven economy. And point number 5: involve society so that it can benefit from big data and be empowered by it.  We call on the Commission and the Council to make all the necessary efforts so Europe could become a global leader on big data. I would like to thank our colleague, Barbara Kappel, for her crucial involvement in the preparation at committee level for this oral question and the motion for a resolution. And let me say, I did not mention a very important point, of course, which is consumer protection and consumer rights, but this is the responsibility of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) and certainly Madam Chair, Vicky Ford, will speak about that.

name: Vicky Ford
text: author. – Madam President, the digital world is a borderless world and to solve questions it raises means that we need to work with others, both across Europe and across the rest of the world too. Big data helps businesses to manage logistics, to target sales, to reduce costs and thus to increase their competitiveness. This is key to driving our economic growth. But the regulatory environment must work for both businesses and consumers. Good regulation can bring benefits. Clear rules on how personal data is used can empower consumers. Clear competition rules can give businesses, large and small, a level playing field and helps to bring confidence to investors and innovators. In the digital space new entrants emerge rapidly and new sectors like data brokers, raise new questions on transparency and accountability. So what is the Commission doing to monitor these new entrants, and how do we make sure that any rules we pass are technologically neutral, future proof and do not just lock in old monopolies? Big data also brings big benefits for health with next-generation medicines, for the environment by saving energy and reducing waste, and can help make our public services more efficient. But to achieve all of this we need smart procurement to unlock smart technology. So what is the Commission doing to help our Member States and their public services to share best practice and to enable savvy – tech-savvy – procurement? My committee first tabled these questions last summer. We are only debating them in March. This is not good enough. In the months in between Parliament negotiators have agreed new rules on data protection, but outside our Brussels bubble there is still a lot of concern about the details. If the data protection authorities are overly cautious when they implement the regulation they will put a straitjacket on the data processing. But to unlock the benefits of big data, data needs to be processed. So, Commissioner, we need clear guidelines, they need to work for businesses and for consumers, for innovators and incumbents, for scientists and service providers. Just agreeing the regulation is one step. Now we need to work on the implementation and clear guidelines too.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for the questions we will debate today. They show that it is time to put the right conditions in place for Europe to leverage the growth potential of the data-driven economy. The EU data economy is growing fast and is expected to reach at least 3% of GDP by 2020. It must become the building block for our entire economy, creating new jobs, services and business models. In the recent public consultation on platforms, the Commission aimed to improve understanding of the role of data markets, access to data and the free flow of data in the European Union. The Commission will map existing restrictions on the free flow of data and assess emerging issues related to businesses’ access to data, the use and reuse of data, and the ownership of non-personal data. Data is the new oil. Standards and interoperability are its new pipelines. The Commission is working on a set of priorities for standards and standardisation actions in key technology areas for the digital single market, which can guide the standardisation of organisations in their work. Regarding cloud, the Commission will promote the rapid adoption of cloud computing in all sectors where we are convinced that cloud can boost productivity. In order to digitise public administrations, the digital single market envisages a new e-government action plan. Under the action plan, I aim at accelerating the implementation of open, innovative and collaborative government. They will support interoperability and cross-border digital public services. An effective regulatory framework on personal data protection, complemented by revised e-privacy rules plus cyber security and consumer protection, will help to build trust in the data economy. By enhancing legal certainty and providing more uniform rules, it will also help to guarantee equal conditions for businesses to compete across the European Union. The specific situation of SMEs has been taken into account in the proposals for the general data protection regulation. The Commission has been careful not to impose undue administrative burdens on them. SMEs will benefit from the simplified regulatory environment that the regulation provides and the one-stop shop mechanism of the national supervisory authorities. But this is not only about data. The right skills are needed to process data properly and to create new businesses. The Commission has included a New Skills Agenda for Europe in its 2016 work programme to promote skills development and maximise the potential of digital jobs. One question raised the issue of data brokerage. The Commission is following closely the emergence of data markets and brokerage in Europe. To assess the need for policy action, we first need a better understanding of the mechanisms for finding the right price and composition of data to be traded, as well as their effects on the data economy. Particular attention will be given to transparency, accountability and non-discrimination.

name: Michał Boni
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, what is the objective? A data-driven economy can give us more efficient products, user-friendly services and personalised solutions. We can say: data-driven governance, science, thanks to analytical algorithms, data-driven cities known as smart cities, medicine which can change the model of healthcare from reactive to preventive, and a data-driven industry with communication between things, robots and people and, as a result, an internet of everything for everybody. It is also the best leverage for making SMEs more competitive and cost-efficient, scaling up their businesses.  What do we need? A better framework, both regulatory and non-regulatory. The new technologies require much more soft law. This should be with respect to privacy and security, but also flexible for new opportunities for data processing concerned with solving the problem or the ownership of data. Open data as a basis, accessibility of many kinds of data and the possibility to use them for public and commercial purposes; efficient infrastructure; future 5G for digital industrialisation, a network of high-performance computing centres and cloud development; a well-educated workforce, new e-skills development in the whole system; coverage of standardised and interoperable solutions all over Europe.  All of these create the opportunity for the new European competitive advantages. We have no time to lose, so we await consistent proposals from the Commission.

name: Patrizia Toia
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the objective of once again growing the European economy, of making it more prosperous, more competitive, can find a great opportunity in the data-driven economy. But this – as we know very well – will not happen automatically and spontaneously. It must be the result of a European strategy. It will not happen by miracle if things are allowed to go spontaneously. We have a long way to go, because we know that the United States is way ahead, we know that Europe is not big in this big data economy; it may become so, but much needs to be done.  Much needs to be done from the point of view of investment, as has been said, from the point of view of interoperability, so that machines and sensors and all the technical accessories can talk to each other, involve SMEs, society for its uses, preparation of the skills, very integrated, diversified that are needed, all things to do.  But to do this we also need foresight. President Buzek said that Europe must look ahead, be innovative but defend its values, affirm them. Therefore, we need a regulatory framework that is forward-looking, capable of stimulating innovation but that addresses the problems and risks involved in this economy based on the value of information, for the thousand treatments that can be done, not only with regard to privacy, which is also very important, or data protection but also ownership.  There are important legal and also, Dare I say, ethical aspects, which are also linked to developments in democracy. We have heard very worrying things about the possible combination of data and its use if there are no clear rules that do not want to limit progress and innovation, but want to safeguard, in progress and innovation, Europe's values.

name: Evžen Tošenovský
text: on the ecr group. – Madam President, at present, flawless functioning of information systems is essential for our economy and society as a whole. The amount of data processed in real time is increasing, as is the need for technical infrastructure to transmit it with the highest security requirements. Increasing capacity and transmission speeds becomes a condition for further development.  However, we must not forget the system background, without which it would not be possible to manage large amounts of data in a tolerable time. This applies to cloud computing, but also to the dynamically increasing demands on supercomputing systems. These are capable of a huge number of computing operations on large amounts of data. We need new approaches, whether it's parallel counting or new mathematical methods. However, this data processing infrastructure is very costly and we should therefore work closely together and make effective use of EU programmes and funds.

name: Kaja Kallas
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, in the time it took to bring this resolution to plenary we also adopted the digital single market report, where we were quite clear what we want to see regarding big data.  Firstly, Parliament quite clearly asked for the business environment for growth and innovation in the data-driven economy to be improved, and secondly, we also called on the Commission in the digital single market report to carry out a broad and transparent review of big data. So the aim is not to have another study but to review what needs to be done in order to improve the conditions for growth and innovation, and to understand and address the potential challenges so that we can encourage take up, because what is crucial is to create scale in Europe as this is the only way to benefit from big data the most.  There are two issues regarding big data. One is data protection, and the other is skills, so firstly, data protection. I hope that now that the data protection framework is soon to be adopted the Commission will come forward with the free flow of data initiative because restrictions on the flow of data go against the single market, but also the purpose of data- driven technologies. And second, I think it is important that we do not talk about personal data because big data is not about personalised data, but data in a big format that makes companies able to draw conclusions from it. As the Vice—President pointed out, it is about open public data and also machine-generated data.  Secondly I wanted to talk about skills. If big data is there but there is nobody to use it because nobody knows how, and no businesses know how to apply these things, then there is just no use. We therefore await the key recommendations in the e-skills strategy. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. –Dear colleague, in your speech you asked several questions, but I want to add one more. The Commissioner was talking to us about the importance of SMEs, and I would like to ask you: do you think that the regulations relating to the big data, the Small Business Act, take into account the need to think first on a small scale and not to make regulations 'to the pile' and, again, SMEs to bear the consequences of a regulation not specific to them?

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – As the European economy is based on small and medium—sized enterprises, it is very important to take this into account. Also, when we try to discuss the regulations and only keep in mind the big companies, we actually design regulations that are fit for them and not fit for the small ones. So I think we have to keep this in mind all the time, and I hope that the Commission will do that.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, the use of new digital data must have the primary objective of prosperity and enhancing people's quality of life. Unfortunately today the potential of technology is being used to serve the interests of multinationals and large capital, to increase competitiveness and business profits. That is why we need to redefine the objectives and focus on putting the needs and interests of society at the heart. The European Union must support Member States to promote state subsidies and public investment to make full use of new digital data. The aim should be to promote research, innovation and development, create new quality jobs, ensure free and free access to the Internet, protect personal data and strengthen consumer rights. It is equally important to support small and medium-sized enterprises so that they can use technology to strengthen their market position and facilitate their access to finance.

name: Roger Helmer
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, I have served in this Parliament for 17 years. I was here during the Lisbon Council of March 2000 and I well remember the target we set ourselves: to create the most competitive and dynamic knowledge-based economy in the world by 2010. Yet, retrospective studies of the first decade of this century show that in fact the EU’s relative competitiveness slipped back during that period. But here we go again, undaunted. This time we seem to have created a sentence without a verb: ‘towards a thriving data-driven economy’. At least there is no target date, so we shall not quite know when we have failed. Can we at least learn the lessons of past failure? We do not achieve competitiveness with fine words in carefully crafted regulations: we achieve it by creating incentives and removing obstacles. We achieve it by setting free the entrepreneurial spirit of business and industry. I call on the Commission to keep this in mind and to pursue its laudable objective, not by detailed and prescriptive legislation, but by flinging wide the gates of opportunity.

name: Barbara Kappel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Our everyday life becomes digital: no service and no process remain analog, no company, no consumer remains unaffected by digital change. This also applies to the market for mass data, i.e. big data. Big data is growing at around 40% or €15.4 billion per year and is growing seven times faster than the ICT market. Big data, cloud services, and the Internet of Things are key drivers of Europe's competitiveness – a competition in which the US is still clearly ahead today, with much more industrial capacity and better financing opportunities. The application possibilities of big data are manifold. Whether this is the new IBM software that can distinguish real refugees from terrorists based on big data analysis, detect terror cells and fend off imminent attacks, or self-driving cars, or optimize viticulture with IOT-based real-time information on soil and climate conditions, or precision agriculture, where harvesters can accurately record yields with precise GPS positioning, soil-based sensors and increasingly measure nutrient and water content. , or even Industry 4.0.  Big data has enormous potential for the telecommunications and automotive industries, for climate policy and resource efficiency, for health, energy and intelligent transport systems and much more. The extent to which the potential of big data is raised depends on investment in digital infrastructure and research and development. The development of digital skills and reliable regulatory frameworks, especially in terms of data protection and data security – big data creates growth and employment in Europe, 3% of gross domestic product by 2020. Let us seize this opportunity!

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I read here that we are in danger of being left behind, that people are chasing us... I understand that the United States is chasing us. I would ask myself if in the United States someone is doing debates in parliament, or simply allowing thousands, hundreds of thousands of private companies to build data sets, and just making sure that all this happens as decently as possible. The illusion that we are the ones to build data sets, not private companies, is absolutely an illusion.  You have never done anything great.  All inventions come from private companies.  And I would also like to forewar you that the real data does not come from datasets.  Everyone has access to datasets.  The idea is that real data is collected from private information, from watching TV, from reading data. We don't realize the importance of information outside the datasets. We simply lock ourself in an ivory tower. I agree with the opinion that this is done mainly in the interests of big companies.  More besides, I believe that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the big data market represents both an opportunity for growth and a real danger to consumers. My opinion on this issue has focused on three main aspects that I believe are essential to take into account in this balance of interests.  First of all, it is essential that all companies, from small and medium-sized enterprises to multinationals, have the same opportunity to take advantage of the explosion of the mass data sector. It is therefore necessary to create a level playing field in order to avoid monopoly cases, which are all too common in the IT sector.  Second, the use of big data in the public sphere is likely to facilitate and speed up the administrative process. Let us seize this opportunity in order to innovate and make our public administrative services more efficient.  Last but not least, the big data market is a major issue for consumer protection. It is therefore imperative to put in place a legislative framework to avoid the risk of fraudulent behaviour and the use of citizens' data for harmful purposes.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are used to the Commission's methods. There's always a gain. We are made to dream: through pooling, you will increase productivity, growth and jobs. But is this pooling done on behalf of and as part of a European strategy? Is there a desire to build stand-alone platforms that can compete with Google, Facebook, Amazon and Skype? Is there an industrial policy to create sufficient data storage capacity? No. The European strategy is to open up to Us-dominant technologies and large private companies, which hold a monopoly on this data. I would like to raise a substantive issue. Private data is sold. The raw material is man. Should we not prohibit the sale of this data? Instead of making it private or state property, would it not be appropriate to make it truly a collective citizen-owned property? That is the issue of freedom.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I think it is important to underline one thing and that is that the data-driven economy is nothing new. That change has already taken place, and in those parts of our economies that are the most data-driven we see most of the growth and development of prosperity. That is how things are, so let us not talk about this as something new and magic. It is rather about ensuring that we can be the best at processing data, because data is knowledge. Knowledge can be distributed, allocated and used in a way that we have never seen before in the modern economy. For us this is much more about catching up regarding cyber—security and securing the free flow of information, combined with the rules on privacy, consumer legislation and copyright; adapting our society to be a strong society benefiting from these opportunities that are already there. I think it is quite easy in one way and that is that, if we want to, we can decide that we should be the best. Of course, earlier speakers, Mr Schaffhauser and others, think we are living in the 19th century. We are not. We can decide to take the lead, have the best 5G, the best fibre, open up the best capacities and enable our society to be the best. That is a decision we can take and I think we should take that decision.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – I have been watching the debate from the outset and agree with the objectives that you have set. It is important for European industry and the economy, but it is also important for the European citizen to have the issue of data protection. One thing has not been said in this Chamber is that we need to protect data not only from large companies, but also from powers who are otherwise interested in weakening Europe. Do you see a danger, for example, in Moscow, where it is often as if there are also ties to the refugee crisis here, that such powers may also pose a threat to our data? Can we fight this together? You said that knowledge means power, data can mean knowledge – that's your sentence, and that's why I'm stuck asking, can someone else use our data?

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I appreciate that question very much because it gives me the opportunity to underline another thing. Data is not a magic digital issue. It is knowledge, and knowledge has the character that it can be distributed very rapidly and it can be divided very many times. I can give you knowledge and you can give me knowledge and we will still have the same knowledge with us. That is the magic of knowledge, it is not about data. My feeling and understanding is that most of the data is, for example, the internet of things and the internet of everything – that is not personal data. But in the data-driven economy we can safeguard the personal data that we want to safeguard at the same time as we can increase the levels of cyber security, and still on the aggregated level use the data for the development of health, research, science. A lot of people over there and maybe over there do not want that, but I think we can reach a common understanding on how to use data, the knowledge, safeguarding privacy but also safeguarding European leadership.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D).
text: – Mr President, right now the EU does not have much to contribute to the digital economy. Think about your homes and offices: do you have European devices in your pocket and handbag, or do you use European programmes? Europe must pull itself together, otherwise we will buy equipment and content from the United States in Asia and we will produce nothing ourselves. I'm glad we can do something. For example, in infrastructure-side construction, our cyber companies are among the best in the world and gaming companies and security companies are conquering the world. But will we have new work from big data?  The EU is needed to create a digital single market. We urgently need standards and more uniform consumer protection and data protection legislation. In particular, they help small businesses and start-ups, as well as, of course, people. We can help European businesses by investing in broadband, innovation policy, workforce training and data centres. The EU can also be the best user of open data and good information security can make a European brand. Owning and reassing data may yet be unclear. We can make Europe a smart and fast player on the digital world market and we can create millions of jobs in Europe, but we must act now.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I think we are living in a fascinating time. We are moving from the real world to the virtual world. The real world is reflected in the virtual world, and it is a great challenge to find the algorithms and the mathematical basis for us to find our way around this new world. That is why I believe it is necessary that we also create a new platform for mathematics, computer science and algorithms – best enabling technology – in our framework research programme in order to remain the leading edge of the world. I think it is clear that we currently have around 200 billion e-mails per day. This generates a knowledge that has never existed before in this time. We have 800 million tweets, we have over 1 billion Facebook posts, we have 30 billion WhatsApp messages and we have 2.6 billion mobile phones. The bits we are currently producing are more than grains of sand on this earth.  This, of course, creates enormous opportunities. We see that the amount of data has doubled annually in recent years. What is clear is that the volume of data, the data analysis, the finding out what is behind this data – that is the new gold, and that will secure the new jobs in the future. I therefore congratulate Commissioner Ansip on this strategy. Here we need to be faster, better and, as he told us, more efficient.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D).
text: – Mr President- I take the opportunity to speak Estonian, as there is an exceptionally high percentage of Estonian speakers in the hall. I would like to thank the Commission, which has given a very good statistical overview of how the development of the data economy is progressing. A special digital economy and society index has been created, which I think is very eloquent. That is great, but the picture that opens up from it is not great, because it shows an extremely large inequality in Europe between different countries. If we compare the countries of northern Europe on the one hand and, on the other hand, Italy, Greece, Bulgaria and others, the differences in practical data and computer skills are mountain heights. My question is that education, i.e. the development of all the necessary skills, is in fact organised by the Member States. Countries where this development is currently lower are probably not able to foresee what to do to make progress faster. If that remains the case, then in fact the targets that have been set, we will not achieve across Europe.  I therefore have a question about how the Commission intends to bridge this gap and achieve the harmonisation of the skills and knowledge that will enable the data economy to be a pawn of success across Europe.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Madam President, digital data collection and processing of human activities, industrial processes, research and various other areas keep growing on an unprecedented scale. Big data size has developed from a few dozen terabytes in 2012 to many petabytes of data today. As the Commission has pointed out in its communication, this development could have a very strong impact on a large number of fields ranging from health and food security to resource efficiency, energy, intelligent transport systems and so on, but it also represents an enormous economic potential for companies, the creation of new jobs and the development of new business models.  The fields of big data offer the possibility for Europe to gain a foothold in an advanced ICT sector with strong growth. This is why the European Union must step into the existing possibilities as quickly as possible and close the gap compared to the US. In this sense, in order to create the necessary conditions for the thriving single market in big data it is essential to improve coordination in matters of interoperability and standards and to boost investment in the ICT sector in areas such as the internet of things, high-speed broadband networks, research and education. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I wanted to say thank you, because I think it sums it up very well. Do you think that new search engines could also open up opportunities for citizens and privacy to track where their data ends up and what benefits their data bring accordingly? Especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, for family farms, it is a great challenge to keep up.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Yes, of course. The little ones always have a disadvantage in the fight with the big ones. That is the only problem.

name: Julia Reda (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, big data can have a great, positive impact on society when carried out responsibly and with full respect for data protection. I think this ethical dimension becomes very clear when I hear some of the very worrying ideas from some of my colleagues about screening refugees. To make sure that all the people can benefit from this trend – an internet of everything for everybody, as my colleague, Mr Boni, put it – Europe needs an open and accessible research data infrastructure and a legal, level playing field. I was therefore quite surprised to read in the Commission’s communication on copyright that it plans to legalise tax and data mining of copyright-protected material only for so-called ‘public interest research organisations’. How does the Commission expect to unleash the full potential of big data if innovative companies, citizens and science projects continue to be faced with legal uncertainty from an outdated copyright law? Is it not contradictory that, on the one hand, the Commission is suggesting that public-private partnerships are the way forward for big data when, at the same time, compliance with copyright rules is made impossible for big data projects with private sector involvement? Many of these projects require the mining of publicly accessible content held by thousands, or even millions, of different copyright holders. Only by drastically simplifying the rules for all big data projects, regardless of whether they are commercial or non-commercial, can we unleash the full potential and make sure that copyright does not become an obstacle for Europe’s big data ambitions.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, a number of aspects of the data economy have been mentioned here. Whether it's privacy versus data business, data. Or whether it's the safety and security of ownership and the requirement for flexibility.  However, I would like to mention one more question that did not fall here. This is a question of copyright protection versus the requirement for a quick obtaining of consent. There is no doubt that copyright protection must be safeguarded. I subscribe to this request.  But the problem is the speed of consent, which is also related to how data will be shifted in the economy. And here I think there is still a great shortage at EU level. The internal market does not work here and collecting societies are bound by national legislation, and in this respect, too, the European Union should certainly add.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have been the author of numerous questions, speeches and statements on the development of the Internet and the strengthening of big data, in order to modernise the economy and public health. I have also highlighted, however, the aspect of the coin: the harmfulness of wifi radiation, cybercrime, drug trafficking, computer fraud.  I see the Internet as the real challenge of universal services to ensure public utility services, and I am thinking, for example, of e-Health. But this power must be well calibrated. We need greater protection of personal data, greater respect for the Charter of Fundamental Rights, because only defined rules generate positive social and cultural impact and create a digital single market with equal conditions for businesses and citizens' security.  I therefore agree with the question and would add that three days ago the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, Zeid Ra'ad Al Hussein, urged the United States to proceed with great caution on the Apple-FBI affair, given its potentially negative consequences for the human rights of people throughout the world. What answer does the Commission think it can give on this matter?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, we have pointed out many years ago that the funds invested in the field of new information technologies in the European Union fall short of the investments made in the United States and Japan. However, the coverage of distance must not be based on the Chineseisation of wages and working conditions. Surely European legislation must adapt to the cross-border architecture of the Internet in order to bridge the differences of the fragmented European market. However, it must also protect the citizens of the Member States, which is why further liberalisation of the market must be stopped, particularly in the area of services attempted by TISA. In other words, the European Union must, among other things, recognise and propose a clear framework for addressing the risks associated with the digitisation of the economy for workers, both in terms of their jobs and their mental and physical health, by taking care of citizens' accessibility to the Internet, issues which are not addressed in the oral question.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank everyone again for their questions and comments. The Commission is committed to maximising the growth potential of the data—driven economy with its digital single market strategy and other initiatives planned for this year. I agree with Vicki Ford, who underlined the importance of really transparent e-procurement.  According to analyses prepared by the European Parliament, if we are able to implement e-procurement across Europe we could save EUR 50 billion per year, which is a huge amount of money – and, I am sorry to say, we do not have this money. We have to implement and introduce e-invoices in all the Member States. We have to use digital signatures more proactively. Of course, we have to pay attention to privacy issues. We have to protect everybody’s privacy, but we have to allow free data flows across Europe. Governments have to open their data in all the Member States. All of the companies, all the players, have to get access to data – it does not matter whether they are small and medium-sized companies or bigger players.  The digital divide is a real issue in the European Union. This divide is not only between our Member States, but also within Member States, even in those Member States where IT is highly developed. We can see that there is a real digital divide between downtown and rural areas, between men and women, and between young and elderly people, and we have to deal with all those issues. You gave me just a minute, and I have already been speaking for two and a half minutes – I am so sorry, we don’t have time. The Commission will propose all those legislative proposals during this year. We have to hurry up, because while yes, of course we have some risks, the real risk is to lose this competition.  I would like to thank Members for today’s debate. I look forward to working swiftly and efficiently with the co-legislators to design and build the necessary conditions for a data-driven economy that benefits everyone in society – individual people, public bodies and the private sector.

name: President. –
text: The next item is a short presentation of the report by Angelika Mlinar, on behalf of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament [(2015/2230(INI)] (A8—0034/2016).

name: Angelika Mlinar
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, the final goal of gender mainstreaming is a tool to realise real gender equality in our society. To reach such a result, concrete ideas of how to effectively put in place gender equality has to reach the hearts and minds of people. Gender equality needs to become a natural part of daily life, but the truthful acceptance of gender equality means major changes in mindsets and behaviour, not only concerning the treatment of women, but also concerning the understanding of equality between humans in general. It is the fear of such broad and deep implications that is the reason why it is still so widely opposed. It is mostly women who engage themselves, lead the discussion and do the essential work toward strengthening the scientific and strategic base for the steps which are still so necessary to implement gender mainstreaming into everybody’s reality. Therefore, I would like to warmly thank all the colleagues who contributed to the report, co-operating in a highly constructive and fair manner. I would like to name them: Julie Ward, Sirpa Pietikäinen, Eleanora Forenza and Monika Vana. Only though productive and horizontal cooperation do we now have such a shared and balanced text. However, for public opinion, gender mainstreaming is still an unknown and generally contested concept. In practical terms, the concept means the integration of a gender perspective into the preparation and design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of policies. It includes and needs spending programmes with a view to promoting equality between women and men. The report presents undeniable reasons for the necessary steps of building awareness and changing realities.  The three main points why we need to emphasise gender mainstreaming are the following: firstly, gender mainstreaming is a process to promote gender equality in the policy field, and no policy is exempted since the need for a balanced effect of policies is horizontal. This is one of the true dimensions of the concept. The other concerns the representation of women and men in the given policy area and for it to definitely make a difference to the policy outcome. Unfortunately, international recognition did not give this concept a concrete impact on the decision-making process in both dimensions.  Secondly, Parliament – further to several resolutions on gender mainstreaming – gradually developed a gender mainstreaming structure. However, analysis shows that the system is fragmented and not particularly efficient. It is time for corrective measures, as well as an efficient feedback and evaluation mechanism, if we want to prevent this resolution from remaining a dead letter.  Finally, the best way to promote gender equality is to set a good example, to live its essence, and to show how it is done. Gender mainstreaming and gender equality are principles that are enshrined in the Treaties. Who, if not the EU institutions, could be the best example when it comes to implementation? That is why we tried in the report to build an interinstitutional network involving, among others, the Council and the Commission. I personally believe that gender—sensitive policymakers should consider how gender relates to the content of policy measures to gain a better understanding of how women and men would benefit from gender equality. Parliament is not even close to reaching the targets in both dimensions.  I hope this report will be an instrument to raise awareness on the topic and initiate the implementation phase to reach more and more ambitious targets.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Mlinar, for presenting the report, because I believe that it is right for the European Parliament, as she herself has said, to set an example and assess the opportunities it gives women, both politically and in senior administrative positions. We find serious shortcomings in this area, and we therefore recommend that the European Parliament's management deal with this situation in order to achieve a higher representation of women, especially in those higher administrative posts, where it should be up to 40%, and to create conditions for women to perform this function as well. I think these are all very correct measures.  Unfortunately, there are proposals in this report that I cannot agree with. For example, for gender mainstreaming to be the subject of training, certified courses, so that each committee has to develop an action plan for this inclusion on its agenda. I am afraid that this is a large administration that would not fulfil that purpose, so if these amendments are adopted, I will not be able to vote in favour of the report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, today is my birthday. Tomorrow, 8 March, is International Women’s Day, and also by chance, my mother’s birthday. I am so proud that in the midst of these auspicious days, celebrating different generations of the fight for women’s rights and gender equality, this Parliament will be voting on a report that I have co-authored, a report the promotes the highest standards and sets a best practice example in respect of institutional and interinstitutional gender equality. From its initial foundation, women’s rights and gender equality have been at the heart of the European project. It is therefore very fitting that on International Women’s Day we take a good hard look at how we do things here, at who makes the decisions and whether or not we can see ourselves reflected in the power structures. Gender mainstreaming requires commitment from both men and women to effect change. I commend this report.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I absolutely support greater social and political engagement of women, as this would give us extra latitude and achieve greater success of public policies that for the most part relate equally to both sexes.  I also believe that our societies must provide women with equal treatment in the business world because it is only the right thing to do, and I am convinced that it would also be very useful for European companies because by increasing the involvement of women they would expand the pool of talent from which they draw hardworking and quality workers for responsible positions. The European institutions must take the lead in this process and give women the opportunity to prove themselves with their knowledge and work in all positions. But I can't support this report because it's going in the wrong direction! I have never heard a more scandalous proposal than the introduction of measures to reconcile work and private or family life. We cannot allow politics to interfere in citizens' private lives in this way and regulate relationships within their families. Politics didn't allow it in any totalitarian systems, which says enough about this proposal.

name: Monika Vana (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In other words, quite contrary to the previous speaker, I would like to fully endorse the content of the rapporteur, Mrs Mlinar, that the report presented tomorrow and to be voted on, which is a very important and very fitting one for International Women's Day, will also hopefully be adopted by a large majority, as will the FEMM Committee. It shows the great need for action that we have in this House in the context of gender mainstreaming, whether it is in the representation of women by increasing the proportion of women – not only among employees, but also in the committees and committee chairmen – but also with regard, for example, the proposal for the introduction of a gender impact assessment, i.e. a gender impact assessment, our own decisions and decisions here in the House. , but also the implementation of gender budgeting, as has been provided for a long time in decisions of the Council, but also of the European Parliament.  It is also important, however, that, after tomorrow's vote, the fine words should also be followed by deeds and that the demands are actually put into practice – in particular, the strengthening of the gender mainstreaming network in the House and the inclusion of the amendments on gender mainstreaming in the Rules of Procedure, and also that the Commission finally present a real equality report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – Of course, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her good work, and there is probably a chance tomorrow that it is Women's Day, but we should touch this topic several times, not just on such days. We have made quite good progress recently, but there are still quite a few inequalities in certain areas, and I would like to highlight, above all, the area of entrepreneurship and the area of representation of women in management positions and in the boards of large companies. We must abandon these stereotypes that arise in the business world, in politics and in society in general and, of course, allow women to participate more in decision-making. This, in my view, would also help to make businesses more and more GDP more. However, we will, of course, only make real progress when we no longer need quotas and artificial promotion to improve women's participation, but that will in itself be self-insoud.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D).
text: – Madam President, assessing the gender impact on public policies is not just a matter of modernising public policies. Assessing how different public policies affect men and women differently and making and promoting measures for equity, in order to achieve equal opportunities between men and women, is a fundamental right, humane and social justice. There are no neutral policies that are put in place without a gender perspective. That is why I welcome and welcome this resolution which calls for all the work of the European Parliament to be accompanied by an assessment of gender impact and, of course, also budgets, because that is a better understanding of society: more efficiency, more transparency, better redistribution of resources and opportunity for greater participation and, above all, greater democracy.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: – Reading this report is quite incredible. Please note some of the following absurdities: Gender mainstreaming must include the rights, perspectives and well-being of LGBTIQ people, as well as persons of all gender identities, as well as addressing the issue of the representation of men and women and persons of all gender identities in policy areas. What are all the identities the rapporteur is thinking of here? Existing or one that has yet to be brought in? Furthermore, that EU policies represent boys and girls, men and women equally, as well as other gender identities. Aren't these people boys and girls any longer? It also stresses the importance and positive impact of the use of gender-neutral language and calls for specific professional courses on the use of gender-neutral language for translators and proposes the establishment of an internal monitoring body. And what else do we want to watch here, I ask. Colleagues on the Women's Committee, I don't think you're serious about this. I believe that each of us understands the true nature of equality between women and men and that we are equal. I therefore ask you to support Amendment 4, which is an alternative to this report, in the vote tomorrow.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I congratulate you and all women on tomorrow's International Women's Day. However, this report will contribute nothing to make him happy. This report will not contribute to improving women's position, reducing their unemployment, adequately valuing their work at work and at home, reducing abuse and discrimination against women. With this report, the Committee on Gender Equality will become a super board, superior to all other committees, which is contrary to the democratic and legal procedures of the European Parliament. Unfortunately, this report will contribute to generating additional procedures, paperwork and more red tape and will contribute to fewer and fewer Europes, less transparency and less and less concern for women's problems. Therefore, I cannot support this report, unfortunately.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is about the implementation of gender ideology in the internal organisation of the European Parliament, the Mlinar report. The report calls for guidelines for the HUMAN Resources department to improve the well-being of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex and cross-sex EU civil servants in the workplace. You don't have to comment on that, you just have to remind you of that at the next election. We are doing this with great success, especially in Germany. The Mlinar report has two advantages: it becomes clear which taxpayers' money is being wasted and how much gender ideology is being wasted, and the report provides us with a lot of arguments. The text confirms all the prejudices that are circulating about the non-worldly EU Parliament. Thank you very much for that.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would first like to congratulate Ms Ward on her birthday – coincidentally, I share the same birthday as my mother as well. Ireland joined the European Union 1973. At that time, women who got married had to retire from working in the civil service. The European Union insisted that the rule be changed, and of course it made sense and it has been that way ever since. So the European Union has form in trying to promote gender equality, and I agree completely with that. Incidentally, we have just emerged from our general elections. We had a quota for women candidates for the first time ever – it had to be 30 % – and while many people were against it, it was significant that far more women were elected to the next government – or the next Dáil as we call it – than the previous one. So while people might not agree with quotas, this does seem to work, and it is necessary until we get proper equality between men and women.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Ms Mlinar for this draft report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament. Gender mainstreaming is an important tool to achieve real equality between women and men. For the EU, it is Article 8 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union which states that: ‘in all its activities, the Union shall aim to eliminate inequalities, and to promote equality between men and women’. Gender mainstreaming is therefore not a choice, but an obligation. All major institutions, including the European Parliament and the Commission, are confronted with the permanent challenge of putting gender mainstreaming into practice and continuously improving its effectiveness.  The so-called ‘dual approach’ of specifically targeted gender equality actions, on the one hand, and gender mainstreaming on the other hand, has proven successful not only at European level, but also at national, regional and local levels. The Commission also follows this dual approach in the recently published strategic engagement for gender equality 2016—2019. This strategic paper, in line with the principle of gender mainstreaming, emphasises the need to integrate a gender equality perspective into all EU policies, legislation and funding programmes. In practice, this is translated into constant efforts to integrate a gender equality perspective into every aspect of EU intervention. It means assessing the impact of Commission action on both women and men and taking responsibility for adjustment if necessary, so that equality between women and men is promoted and equalities are not perpetuated. In order to monitor the implementation of gender mainstreaming in the Commission in practice, the strategic engagement announces that the Commission will consider issuing a report on gender mainstreaming in 2017. The Commission’s inter-service group for equality between women and men, managed by the DG for Justice and Consumers, plays a key role in implementing gender mainstreaming at the Commission. Finally, let me congratulate Ms Ward on her birthday today and wish all of us a good Women’s Day tomorrow.
