name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. – Gender mainstreaming in the European Parliament is necessary in order to promote gender equality and combat discrimination and rights violations against women in different EU Member States. Especially at a time of the financial crisis, gender discrimination is particularly pronounced in the labour sector, where the pay gap is 16.4% and the pension gap is 39%. It should be noted that in countries such as Greece, which are affected by the memorial policies, women are the biggest victims. Therefore, in order for the EU to eliminate these differences, it should impose transparency on the labour sector and pension systems as well as ensure that it strengthens the Commission's influence on women's rights and gender equality when drawing up aspects of the EU budget linked to gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament. Finally, in order to eliminate gender discrimination, the EU should put an end to austerity policies that are primarily affecting women's rights.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – Gender equality is a concept that came into force on the European Agenda in 1996, with the Commission's commitment to develop a dual system for addressing gender inequalities. After 20 years, neither the European Commission nor the Member States have been able to agree on the principle of equal opportunities and gender. It is said that women who want to be equal to men are not ambitious enough, which may be a suitable quote for a feminist cause on International Women's Day, but it is by no means a quote that reflects reality. The reality is that a significant number of women are still discriminated against in the EU on gender grounds; the reality is that certain areas, such as transport, remain inaccessible to many women; the reality is that we have failed to integrate genuine education on gender equality into European public policies. We need concrete solutions, programmes properly developed and funded to integrate women into decision-making positions in all European institutions.

name: The President. –
text: The next item is the one-minute speeches on matters of political importance (Rule 163).

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Dear Colleagues, As Vice-Chairman of the Committee on Culture and Education, I think it is important to stress that on 28 February the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and the world's most prestigious film award, the Academy Awards, were presented. After 34 years, we Hungarians were excited again for this year's awards, as hungarian films were also nominated in the best foreign language film category. László Nemes's film Son of Saul brought the expected Hungarian and European success – he won the golden statue. The work already boasts several major awards: the Cannes Film Festival Grand Prix, the Golden Globe Award and the Independent Spirit Awards for Best Foreign Film the day before the Oscars. This Academy Award crowned the hungarian film successes of recent years, which also enriches European film culture. It is of the utmost importance for the EU and the European Parliament to support European works, and this European film success is the unified success of Hungarians and Europe.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D).
text: – Madam President, hepatitis C is a silent disease affecting at least 14 million Europeans, taking into account the number of known cases, as only 25% of infected people know that they are; the rest do not know, but they are at risk of transmitting the disease in a blood, sexual or maternal-fetal way.  As you know, the consequences can be devastating, because this disease – as I say, silent – ends in many cases by developing liver cirrhosis or liver cancer.  At the moment there is no protocol at European level that allows or enhances the detection, registration, prevention and coordinated treatment by Member States. In many cases, there is not even a registration as such in these Member States.  As you know, there is currently an innovative medicine that is capable of ending this disease in 97% of cases, but is a major challenge for health systems – in the case of Spain, 18% of the pharmaceutical budget at the moment.  Therefore, and given that it is a devastating disease that can be eradicated, I would ask the European Commission to coordinate an eradication plan that will end hepatitis C in Europe.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for In the near future, we will be dealing with the so-called VW scandal on several occasions in this House. We have set up a committee specifically for this purpose. VW scandal - that's what it's called. But the whole thing is a little more complicated. The International Council on Clean Transportation (ICCT), which brought the US authorities' attention to the VW scandal, has now come to the conclusion in several tests that there also seem to be problems with other car manufacturers. In particular, Citroen, Opel and Fiat are to be mentioned. Two of them, Opel and Fiat, belong to American car companies. I would therefore like to draw your attention to this, so that you realise that this is about much more than the misconduct of a single car company, namely that it is a question of an economic war being waged here, among other things, by the US authorities against European corporations.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, today I received an email from Carmel Nic Airt, who is a primary school teacher from West Cork in Ireland. Carmel is volunteering on the island of Leros, assisting refugees. The refugees are being held in detention camps with no provision for food supply or waste management. Voluntary organisations, already totally overstretched, are being asked to help them. Carmel is absolutely shocked that the most basic needs of these refugees – food and water, sanitation – are not being met, and she has written to all Irish MEPs to ask for help. I had hoped that today’s Council meeting would provide some solutions, some framework or some hope, but once again we see no resolution; nothing. I am disappointed and despondent. Estimates suggest that by the end of this month there will be 130 000 refugees in Greece just this year alone. Only coordinated and concerted EU action can begin to address this issue. If our leaders cannot frame a solution, extremely difficult though that may be, not only will the migrants suffer, so also will the EU itself.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the neoliberal policies of the European primary sector are at the root of the suffering of the people in the agricultural sector and fisheries in my country in Galicia. The distribution of quotas under the enclosure, the proposal for a French aquaculture law, the non-obligation to label the country of origin in canned fish, as may be the case with mussels, the non-regulation of agricultural production and agricultural markets, as is now the case with milk, low prices of agricultural products are a good sample of the deep and long crisis we endure in the agricultural and fishing sectors. The European Union can and must react. The Common Agricultural Policy and also the Common Fisheries Policy need to be changed to safeguard the way of life of thousands and thousands of people, the future of the Galician people and the poor in southern Europe. There will be no future for the European Union if it continues with these policies of annihilation of peoples.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, today, once again, the European Union-Turkey meeting on refugees. If these talks do not take into account certain actions and certain realities of the current situation in Turkey, we will not be able to support any new agreement. In addition to condemning all violent practices, also those of the PKK, can Europe look and not see what is happening in South, Sisre or Diyarbakir? Can Europe hear but not listen to the cry of Kurdish citizens imprisoned in their own homes or subjected to starvation? Can Europe know and, at the same time, ignore the closure of newspapers or the detention of journalists and lawyers? Can Europe continue to contemplate the continued arrival of refugees, dead or alive, on the beaches of Lesbos? Worse, can Europe return Turkey to those held in Greece for the so-called 'closure of the Balkans'? Europe pays a police state, Turkey, to guard the gates, and punishes a member country, Greece, which can only act as an immense prison for those who manage to enter but cannot leave. And with it, it is Europe itself that disappears, in fact.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I would like to raise a constituency issue and put forward my strong opposition to the proposed new Thames crossing in Thurrock. This is not about whether the EU is good or bad, but about what is best for Thurrock. This new crossing will increase pollution above domestic and EU levels, will increase traffic and congestion, breaking Thurrock’s road network, and will take away people’s homes. This government and our Tory MP may want to dump on Thurrock, but we will fight this all the way. The government can pick a fight with the people of Thurrock, but I guarantee to you that the government will come off worse.  Thurrock is not just my constituency; it is my home, and together, united, we will fight this new crossing all the way.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF).
text: Madam President, eight hundred is the number of whales that are currently slaughtered each year in the Faroe Islands, with the utmost indifference. Whales are killed in far greater numbers than is necessary for the consumption of local populations. Moreover, the consumption of whale meat poses a risk to human health, as it contains mercury and toxins. Children are even allowed to watch the later killing and cutting.  Although the Faroe Islands are legally autonomous from Denmark and I attach deep respect to traditions and food needs, it is more than urgent to enter into negotiations with the Faroe authorities and Denmark to better regulate grindadr-p and avoid any health risks, and then gradually cease this despicable practice. The degree of civilization of a people is recognized by the way it treats animals, Gandhi said. It is therefore time to react and stop endorsing these massacres with complicit silences.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: – Madam President, a teenager was still dying a few days ago in Caracas waiting for a life-saving medicine. A terrible case—and I'm sure there are many others we don't know—that shows the very difficult situation that Venezuela's people live in, where shortages of commodities, from medicines to food, are causing dramatic situations. This is a humanitarian crisis, before which we cannot remain impassive from Europe. Venezuela does not deserve what it is living, nor do people who continue to be imprisoned or under arrest for their political ideas: Leopoldo López, Antonio Ledezma and so many other politicians, but also more unknown people, such as the Canarian Andrea González, who has been locked up since last August. All of them are true political prisoners, and that is why I am disgusted and ashamed that there are people in this House who do not recognize this situation, while they do consider a person like Arnaldo Otegi, whose liberation they celebrate as a democratic achievement, ignoring their link with the terrorist gang ETA, for which he was convicted. For political prisoners in Venezuela and anywhere in the world, freedom and all our support. For terrorists and their friends, the greatest of our contempt and the entire weight of the law.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Madam President, in the last 100 years garbage production has increased as much as 10 times. A significant part ends up in the sea and seriously endangers the exkosum and human health. Marine litter is the result of purely human activities - it knows no borders and poses a constant problem that spreads far from the source of pollution.   That is why I want to talk about the problem of marine litter in the coastal area of Croatia. It is found in large quantities on the beaches and the seabed, brought by the currents and winds from neighboring Adriatic countries. Waste collection is mainly carried out at the initiative of local communities and associations, as recently as in trstenik. In addition to the ecological cost, marine litter has a socioeconomic impact since it affects coastal communities, because the clean coastline has a key importance for tourism. While this is not enough, it is worth commending the MARELIT and DeFishGear projects. The aim is to cooperate with countries to solve the problem of marine litter more efficiently in order to achieve together the important goal of good, ecological status of all sea waters by 2020.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Today, I would like to appeal to all the European institutions to ensure the clarity and transparency of the provisions adopted when creating the law. Unfortunately, there are still cases where the law being created, rather than facilitating it, hinders the functioning of different actors and introduces legal ambiguity that hampers the development of innovation and the competitiveness of the European economy. I am talking about this today, bearing in mind the plans of the European Commission, which announced tomorrow the publication of a draft revision of the Posting of Workers Directive. In preparing the new legislative proposal, the European Commission has completely ignored the fact that the implementation of the 2014 Implementation Directive is currently underway and has ignored numerous signals from many social partners, including Member States, who have requested that new initiatives be halted pending implementation proposals. The Commission has also submitted no proper public consultation, and the revision of the Directive is to take place in isolation from the revision of Regulation No 883 on the coordination of social security systems. The separation of work on these two documents may ultimately lead to further legal inaccuracies and inconsistency.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the internationalisation of SMEs must not be a slogan. Facilitating SMEs' access to third markets is a determining factor in economic growth in the European Union. Experts estimate that 90% of global growth will come from outside the European Union, and developing markets will account for 60% of world GDP by 2030. The Commission is therefore required to create a specific process to support SMEs for internationalisation. At the moment, the EU is negotiating two important agreements, TTIP and investment agreements with China. The Commission must take these agreements into account, first of all the possibility for SMEs to operate in the two markets. In particular, in order to be able to internationalise SMEs in the European Union, it must take into account, in negotiations, trade agreements, the spirit of fair competition and the existence of reciprocal trade defence measures in external markets. Otherwise, the internationalisation process is very slow and SMEs will not be able to operate in markets other than the internal market.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, my one minute speech this evening is about the security of gas supply and I must compliment Commissioners Šefčovič and Arias Cañete on their proposals in this regard. They are very practical and sensible. We need to diversify supply and, of course, with the outcome of COP21 the need for renewables is more and more necessary. But renewables need backup and the ideal backup is gas. Now, with the development of LNG right across the water, particularly in the US, Australia and the Middle East, the proposals by the Commission are very sensible – to build LNG terminals across Europe. One of those is in my own constituency, Shannon LNG, which would be a wonderful hub locally, and of course would help to utilise particularly gas coming from the US because we would be the closest port to it, to transport it off into Europe. I would hope that we will see this happening and particularly to get the PCIs developed across Europe. That is the key for now.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I wish to draw attention to the dire humanitarian situation of refugees living in appalling conditions in makeshift camps inside the European Union and on our borders. Exposed to the elements, refugees in camps such as the Calais and Dunkirk ‘jungles’ have had their rickety shelters flooded and destroyed and have received limited support to survive the winter. Their plight is in direct contravention of the basic universal norms of human rights and dignity that this European Union was founded upon. In the meantime, women and children in these camps lack the basic facilities they need, including health care, sanitation and education. Whilst we do not help them, unscrupulous traffickers step in. Instead of a humanitarian response, we have seen police violence and aggression and forced evictions. It is tragic that those who have had to flee the horrors of Daesh in Syria and have had to risk their lives on perilous journeys in search of shelter must now encounter such callous treatment by our fellow Europeans. We, as decision makers, must take the time to see these camps with our own eyes and to speak and to listen to some of the refugees ourselves, as I have done.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE).
text: – Madam President, in the current economic and trade context, the European and national institutions must act effectively and in a coordinated manner to stimulate the growth of the successful sheep breeds. I raise this problem because the European Union is facing an annual shortage of around three hundred thousand tonnes of sheepmeat, as consumption in this sector is constantly increasing and the global demand for sheep and lamb is constantly expanding and the overall deficit is already estimated at 20%. Ambitious recovery targets and effective policies are therefore needed to improve the competitiveness of the sheep farming sector, in particular in Member States where production is poor in relation to sheep herds. This is also the case for Romania, which has the greatest growth potential among European Union countries. I strongly call on the European Commission to support concretely and consistently the growth of the breeds of performing sheep in Romania and in the other countries where it is necessary to improve the yield in order to ensure consumer needs and to exploit European export opportunities.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Today, EU and Turkish leaders met for the migrant summit. Austria and the balkan countries are showing us how to do it. They want to close the Balkan route and send the signal: we are closing. There will be fewer. You want to turn off the magnet, and that's the only way to do it. But Turkey has no interest in this. If the Balkan route is closed, Turkey will probably be able to blackmail the EU only less or less. Then Erdogan will not get billions, then people will again be interested in human rights violations in Turkey, then they will be interested in freedom of the press in Turkey and in newspaper closures, in the Kurdish question and in the persecution of Christians. Turkey is not and cannot be the solution to the refugee crisis. It is true: friendship with Turkey: yes, criticism of Turkey where it is necessary: yes, but in the migrant crisis build on Turkey: no!

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the laws of the market, the volatility of agricultural prices and food goods are currently endangering agricultural activities whose scope and nobility go far beyond their purely economic and commercial dimension. Thousands of farmers are now on the verge of bankruptcy and demand immediate and vigorous action. We must free agriculture and farmers from the forces of the market economy to which the European institutions have surrendered.  We require the restoration of public pricing systems. No more deceiving farmers with false solutions, such as contracts with large distribution or financial risk hedging instruments, to cease the TTIP negotiations that will only further aggravate the situation of our farmers. Only the public regulation of supply can save our productive model, based on small and medium-sized family farming, the only one truly socially, environmentally and territorially sustainable.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – I am pleased that the statistical indicators in the European Commission's report for Slovenia are better than they were, but citizens do not yet feel this improvement. This confirms the assumption that statistics are not always the most realistic representation of the facts, because the structural problems remain with us. There is an urgent need for the continuation of pension reform, changes to the health system are needed, and tax relief on the economy and the middle class of the population is also necessary. Much-needed changes in the judiciary and in public administration. Privatisation is taking place here, but not the way we wanted it to. We recapitalized the banks, but the banking system is not working. The current refugee-migrant crisis, however, must not be a reason for the reforms to endure, or even a cover for political staffing in many state institutions. The same structures that have already done damage are returning to the management of state assets. Dear Sirs, I am really concerned about my country, Slovenia.

name: Paul Brannen (S&D).
text: – Madam President, what are the pros and cons for UK farmers of our EU membership? According to Agri Europe, a UK-based agricultural consultancy, only 10% of the most efficient UK farms would survive in their current form once the common agricultural policy subsidies are removed. The UK Government has no contingency plan for what would happen in the event of a ‘Leave’ vote. CAP subsidies currently provide 50-60% of UK farm inputs. This means a ‘Leave’ vote would be a leap in the dark, a journey without a map. Yet from the farming point of view, the EU is not only about the CAP: UK farmers also enjoy the benefits of trade and the free flow of labour. UK agriculture is highly dependent on access to the EU single market to sell its produce. Close to two thirds of UK agricultural exports go to the EU. With the UK leaving the EU, our producers would potentially face tariffs ranging from 11% to 48% to enter the single market. Farmers should vote to remain in the European Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the refugee crisis in Greece has now taken on explosive proportions, as the number of refugees trapped so far is 40,000 and their number will increase by an additional 100,000 at the end of the month. Turkey continues to support the slave trade networks for the transfer of refugees to the Aegean islands and relocation has been left on paper after fewer than 400 of the 60,400 refugees have left Greece.  The European Union with its policy has turned Greece into a vast refugee Dachau. Only solution: To support the Greek people now in their own forces. Greece must therefore withdraw from Schengen, so that it ceases to be a magnet for refugees coming to my country instead of going to Bulgaria, because Greece as a Schengen country grants refugees Schengen-type travel documents, which allow them to reach Germany. In addition, Greece must suspend Dublin III, impose an economic embargo on Skopje and Albania in retaliation, in order to force these countries to open their borders to stranded refugees, which have been illegally closed, UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – It was no great surprise that there are democratically elected Members here, including in this Parliament, who believe that there are no national minorities in their country. And anyone who dares to talk about their situation and draw attention to the wrongs is attacking a Member State. It is much sadder, however, that there are member parties of the largest political groups in this House whose positions are not much different from those which they have already classified as extremists. I would like to believe that Article 2 of the Treaty on Union, according to which the Union is based on respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities, remains valid. There are Member States that are in breach of this provision. The Commission should monitor not only the fulfilment of macroeconomic appropriations or compliance with food safety standards, but also the implementation of fundamental rights in the Union. Talking about problems is a fundamental element of democracy. There should be no taboo subjects or uncomfortable questions that some would sweep under the carpet.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D).
text: "Watch out, Europe, because history can repeat itself! And among us, among men, there will always be those who do not interpret leadership as service, but become maniacs of power and do their utmost to control and prevent the functioning of democratic institutions, albeit in democratic circumstances. And these political leaders, they can make an incredible life out of chaos. And now that Europe is indeed in many respects an institutional crisis, prime ministers in the European Council are unable to agree with each other. Hungary prime minister comes home proudly by inging a process that no longer legally functioning the National Electoral Office, the institution that conducts the referendums. Last week, some of the beaters on behalf of the government - bald, hardened people, skinheads - prevented the opposition from going to society with a political issue, a referendum question. Here we are: chaos in Europe and a frenzied mania of power in Hungary.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, following January’s debate on British citizens and other nationals imprisoned in India, including my constituent Nick Dunn, their bail application has not been granted while they wait for an appeal hearing. If – and it is a big if – there was any wrongdoing, then surely the company should be held liable, not individual contractors who found themselves simply in the wrong place at the wrong time. These men are highly qualified security guards who were doing a valuable public protection job, and I have seen those qualifications. I have here copies of the export licenses which show that the firearms were legally exported and that this was done within the timescales.  I have nothing but respect for the Indian Government’s fight against illegal firearms, but in this case they simply have the wrong people. So I call on the Indian Government to urgently review this case and to secure the immediate release of my constituent.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the situation at the Greek-Macedonian border has long been absolutely intolerable. And this is not surprising, because Greece has so far failed to carry out checks on incoming refugees entering the country. Rightly, no one should set foot in the European Union without control. Unfortunately, the reality is different. We cannot therefore be surprised that thousands of people have now accumulated at the border with Macedonia, which has been a transit country for a long time as it travels further west.  We must finally stop closing our eyes to problems. The European Union's leaky external borders have enabled the arrival of people who may be dangerous to Europe. And the flow of people heading to Europe without any documents must therefore be stopped immediately. Finally, let me thank all the translators and all of you who have stayed here until late in the evening.

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the successful access and use of European funds represents for many communities in my country, especially those in rural areas, perhaps the only chance at development or the only chance for a better future. However, this parliament, together with the European Commission, must also take into account the realities on the ground and the problems faced by these localities. We must jointly call on the Romanian Government to take urgent measures to facilitate the access of rural communities to programmes financed by the European Union. Introducing simplified procedures, template projects and a national co-financing fund for communities that cannot afford this co-financing are very easy to do and even quickly. After this year's local elections, all mayors, local and county councillors must concentrate all their energy on accessing this funding. We cannot afford another budget year in which we lose European funds. Moreover, we need to look for partners in the Member States to access the fund directly from the Commission. Thank you very much, Madam President, and happy birthday to all ladies and ladies!

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done The European steel industry suffers from high energy prices, which are further exacerbated by the consequences of emissions trading, in particular the increased carbon leakage measures. Energy prices in Europe are twice as high as in the US because of taxes, levies and subsidies. In addition, the US steel industry has managed to reduce its CO2 emissions without ETS, and the government is not thinking of automatically giving China market economy status. Chinese steel producers are sitting on 400 million tonnes of overcapacity, a result of state intervention and a planned economy. This figure is 2.5 times the EU steel consumption of the previous year and the situation is getting worse. For china, the economic outlook is currently falling, which means less domestic demand and more export pressure. Just last week, the US Department of Commerce imposed anti-dumping measures on cold-rolled steel from China. In the case of China, punitive duties amount to 265%, while the European Commission's anti-dumping measures are just 14-16%. Even before the interaction of ETS and possible market economy status, the World Steel Association assumed that Europe would have to reduce its industry by half. We will see in the next ten months whether the steel industry in Europe can survive.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, the leaders of the twenty-eight members of the five hundred million Europe are meeting today on the wreckage of a united Europe. Ladies and gentlemen, the European Union, even in its present form, cannot exist without respect for common struggles, common responsibilities and joint commitments. It is at least ironic to talk about a united Europe with closed borders, poor peoples and thousands of impoverished refugees.  Unilateral decisions against the principles of solidarity and the division of responsibilities taken in the name of micro-political interests of national consumption only succeed in growing intolerance and fascist elements. Joint decisions and commitments are not implemented. International treaties have turned into rags and the European Commission is limited to wish books. Ladies and gentlemen, Madam President, do you really think that Greece can take responsibility for the whole of Europe for the refugee crisis? Do you really think the solution is financial consideration? The only solution is safe routes for refugees and their proportional hospitality of course by all the states of the European Union.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF).
text: Madam President, hare hunting with galgos is an ancestral tradition in Spain which, however, leads to unacceptable excesses. Injured in their heart by a dog considered less efficient than the others, thousands of hunters, supposedly to wash their honor, indulge in barbarism by mistreating their animals. Every year, 50,000 galgos are victims of the worst punishments: beaten, amputated, burned alive, skinned or starved, this is the sad fate reserved for these poor beasts. The most sadistic masters even go so far as to hang the animal with a rope, neither too short nor too long, so that the asphyxiation lasts as long as possible. Dogs that have not been killed immediately will end up in the pound, a real animal hell, to be gassed without even being offered for adoption. Very few are eventually taken to shelters. These abuses are intolerable. They offend our compatriots, and the European animal welfare texts oblige us to consider the issue. The philosopher of the enlightenment Kant said that cruelty to an animal is a violation of a human duty to himself. It seems essential to make young people aware of the situation of galgos through education programmes, to support associations working for their protection and to really enforce the animal protection rules passed by this assembly. Pueblo espaol, detén esta atrocidad.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – A few months ago, I said here, from here, that President Martin Schulz is the man responsible for the successes of the National Front in France. This has been treated jokingly, but I have experienced some satisfaction, because yesterday Michael Gove, The United Kingdom's Justice Minister, declared that the European Union was responsible for the successes of nationalism in Europe. And that's true. Unfortunately, in Europe, schools do not learn cybernetics, they do not learn that there is a reaction to every action and society is a living organism. If you push one way, it obviously corresponds to a reaction in the other direction.  More besides, I believe that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: President. –
text: That concludes the item.

name: President. –
text: I declare closed the 2015-2016 session of the European Parliament.
